mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means stomach.

You're sitting on your stool again!!? Imagine your super comfy, state-of-the-art stool. You take it everywhere with you, and you're always sitting on it. Again, and again, and again. You love that stool.
mnemonics.reading: Your friends are starting to worry about you, because you're always sitting on that stool. "What is the matter (また) with you?" they scream! You might want to imagine that all your friends have Jamaican and/or British accents to make this one fit a bit better! Imagine your friends getting more and more annoyed with your constant stool-sitting habits! They really don't get it. What is the matter with you?! Why can't you just stand like everyone else? Don't you know sitting is the "new smoking"!?

mnemonics.meaning: We must stop the moon. That, at least, we can come to an agreement on. There are a group of people pointing at pictures of the moon coming closer to earth. They are the world's leaders, and although they don't get along normally, this new attack from the moon has united them in agreement: we must stop the moon.
mnemonics.reading: "We have agreement," the world's leaders all say. "We will work together to stop the moon, and we have agreement on who we will follow, Emperor こういち. The world has united against the moon, and they have made Emperor こういち their temporary leader.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to have a tsunami at your wedding, you need to make sure you have it at the bay. Anywhere more inland, and the tsunami won't reach it in time. Picture the tsunami coming towards your beautiful wedding as you stand by the bay. It's not safe, but it's memorable!
mnemonics.reading: How did you get a tsunami to show up in the bay in the first place? By throwing a bunch of uranium (うら) in there, of course! Its highly unstable nature can make any body of water, especially a calm bay, turn violent. Imagine throwing buckets of uranium into the bay. It only burns your hands a little. And now they glow green, just like the bay does!

mnemonics.meaning: Your fingers have husband horns. They are there right between each of your fingers. Imagine little husband horns (the horns your husband has) between all your fingers. Emphasis on _between_.
mnemonics.reading: What is between your fingers? Your husband (はさ) horns. Husband, between. Between, husband.

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami hits a dollar the water will instantly start to boil! Imagine standing in front of an incoming tsunami. Suddenly in the distance you see someone throwing dollar bills into it and it starts to boil. Ahh!
mnemonics.reading: The boiling water crashes onto the land and you realize your foot is in it! No, not one foot, both your foots (ふつ)! It hurts so much that you can't even remember the word for two foots. Feel your poor little foots burn in the boiling water. You really want to know who that jerk was that threw dollars into the tsunami to make it boil!

mnemonics.meaning: A lantern with horns that can hold ten thousand drops of water is sitting on the ground. You get closer and realize it's not a lantern, it's a bottle. It's got horns, and a weird handle, but it's definitely a bottle with water inside of it. Picture this horned bottle sitting on the ground. You don't know who left it here or why, but it's here and the weirdest looking bottle you've ever seen.
mnemonics.reading: Even though you're not the one who left this bottle here, you decide to do the right thing and throw it in the trash bin (びん). It's not right to leave a bottle just sitting on the ground, you know. Imagine picking up this weird bottle with your bare hands and putting it in a trash bin. You did your good deed for today! Yay!

mnemonics.meaning: The call radical and the call kanji are the same. This kanji can also mean eat, because why would you call someone if not to ask them to eat with you?! Call your mom or dad and ask them to go out to eat with you right now.
mnemonics.reading: You are called to come eat by the Shougun (しょう). He's been really impressed with you lately and he wants to chat over drinks, he says on the phone. Imagine getting a call from the Shougun himself. He's come to your house before, but he's never asked you to eat with him. This is huge!

mnemonics.meaning: You try to put your toe inside a shellfish, but it just won't open. That's because this shellfish has sworn an oath of chastity. "No, I won't open up until I meet the toe I will marry," it says to you.
mnemonics.reading: "Chastity is really important to me," the shellfish says. "But, maybe if you give me a tater (てい) tot, I'll change my mind." You give the shellfish a tater tot, and it breaks its vow of chastity, opening up for your toe. You look the other way, but you can hear the sounds of passion below.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a special type of meditation where you put a lid on your mouth and touch your forehead down to your legs. If you can do this pose, everything in life will become completely clear. Everything will clear out of your head too. You should try it. Imagine this pose, imagine everything becoming clear. Clear your mind. Clear your head.
mnemonics.reading: Your mind is as clear as a sparkling clear pond. On this pond you see yourself in a row (りょう) boat. A single row boat on the clear pond that is now your mind. Picture the row boat on the clear pond in your mind. Watch the clear water flow over the row boat's oars.

mnemonics.meaning: The spirits of the two trees you destroyed with your jackhammer live on in the collar you made out of them. You took the shredding tree bits and carefully molded them into a nice collar to go with all of your shirts. But now it's haunted.
mnemonics.reading: The collar keeps whispering, "Eric (えり)!" into your ear. Your name isn't Eric (I mean it could be, in that case wow, weird, right?), so you assume one of the trees you killed was named Eric. But that's the only name you hear, so maybe they were both named Eric? It's weird. Whenever you put on your collar you hear a constant stream of, "Eric, pssst, hey Eric, hey!" and you just have to pretend it isn't happening.

mnemonics.meaning: So my building has a big splinter, right in the corner. So what? Imagine a huge splinter coming out of the corner of the building. It's in a really dangerous spot, but the owner doesn't seem so worried about it.
mnemonics.reading: That corner is dangerous, but what are you going to do, sue me (すみ)? Actually, please don't sue me. I'll fix the splinter coming out of the corner of my building.

mnemonics.meaning: The buddy building is in the next county. If it was in your county then it wouldn't be a buddy, it would be a neighbor. You're aware of this building, but they aren't that close, so they're just a buddy. Imagine looking at a map of your county and the surrounding ones. All of the buildings in the counties next to yours are buddy buildings!
mnemonics.reading: Your county is everything you can reach when shooting a gun (ぐん). If the bullet can't reach a building you know, it's a buddy building in another county. Imagine taking out a gun and shooting in a random direction. When you find where the bullet landed, you know that's the county line. Though if it gets stuck in a building or a person it doesn't count. You'll have to try again.

mnemonics.meaning: Put syrup too close to fire and it will dry up. Put any liquid substance near fire and it will dry up actually, but syrup especially. It goes from being sticky and gooey and yummy to a pile of hard, dry sugar. Not so yummy. Imagine putting some syrup over a fire and watching it dry up. Watch as the sides slowly bubble and harden and lose what makes syrup so good in the first place.
mnemonics.reading: If you dry up syrup like this, you're removing its soul (そう). Have you ever seen dry syrup before? No soul in that. In fact, you probably have no soul if you can dry out syrup like this without feeling bad about it. Go back to imagining a fire drying up some syrup and watch as a tiny little syrup soul cries and is released into the air. Oh no!

mnemonics.meaning: Kill a shrimp with a sickle and you'll need a really good explanation for yourself. What did that shrimp do to you? Why use a sickle? Well? What's your explanation? Try to come with an explanation for picking up a sickle and cutting the head off a shrimp with it.
mnemonics.reading: In your explanation you blame everything on Shaq (しゃく). He told you to do it! It's all Shaq's fault, you explain.  Picture Shaq popping into your head as you struggle to come up with an explanation for me. Picture Shaq's face. This is payback for Shaq Fu, you think, as you finalize the rest of the explanation in your mind.

mnemonics.meaning: If you eat both the moon and the sun with a spoon you'll get fat. Maybe if you only ate one you could get away with it, but you wanted both and now you're pretty fat. Picture yourself digging your spoon into the moon, then into the sun, and gulping them both down. Watch your stomach swell with the sun and moon fats. No going back now, gotta finish.
mnemonics.reading: Once you're nice and fat, you look in the mirror to admire your new girth. But that's not you... it's a sheep (し)! Oh nooo you've turned into a fat sheep! You're actually pretty adorable and round and fluffy, but you liked being a human!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of Korea is destined for greatness. I mean, they're the leader of Korea already, right? So they have to have a decent chunk of greatness in them already to get that far.
mnemonics.reading: The greatness radiates off of the leader of Korea, so much so that you can hardly look. Just when you're about to close your eyes to shield them from the greatness, a great eagle (い) soars over them, letting out a cry. Picture the greatness of the scene before you: the leader of Korea, a great eagle overhead, it's so great!!

mnemonics.meaning: Your car is dry because you kept it under the eaves of your house.  This kanji has a second meaning too: house counter. Imagine counting all the houses on your block by the number of eaves you see keeping cars dry. One eave, one house. Two eaves, two houses.
mnemonics.reading: On top of the eaves of your house Ken (けん) the samurai is counting houses too. Ken hops down and explains that he's been hired to count all the houses in his lord's domain just because his name is the same as the counter for houses. It isn't really fair, he complains to you, as you try to sneak by and lock him out of your house.

mnemonics.meaning: You put flowers on your scooter and your car. The flowers you put on them are lotus flowers. Imagine placing lotuses on top of your scooter and car. They are the right kind of flowers for these vehicles.
mnemonics.reading: You're putting a lotus on both your scooter and car because they are rentals (れん). You always put a lotus on top of your rental cars and scooters. Come up with a personal reason why you do this.

mnemonics.meaning: A person with horns has you on the ground and lets loose two poops over your heart. "Mercy! Mercy!" You cry, but the horned dude doesn't stop until there are two gross poops sitting on your heart. "M-mercy..." is the only thing you can think to say. Imagine yourself saying "mercy" over an over as this horned guy has you on the ground and keeps pooping over your heart.
mnemonics.reading: As you shout "Mercy!" one more time, suddenly Jesus (じ) appears out of no where and punches the horned guy into the stratosphere. Jesus snaps his fingers and the poop is gone and you're off the ground. Your heart is safe. Imagine yourself saying mercy and seeing Jesus appearing just in time to save the day. The word "mercy" must be his bat signal. Jesus signal? Sure.

mnemonics.meaning: The dirt on the forehead of a pig makes a small mound. Picture it, if you will. A pig is rooting through the dirt. It lifts its head and there is a mound of dirt right on its forehead. Imagine that you're the pig. How big can you make your forehead dirt mound?
mnemonics.reading: The pig's forehead dirt mound keeps getting bigger until it's the size of two cars (つか)! Pigs are big, but you didn't think one could balance a mound the size of two cars on its forehead and not fall over. Picture a pig with a mound of dirt the size of two cars leisurely stomping around on a farm.

mnemonics.meaning: The mysterious radical and the mysterious kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: There is no one more mysterious than Genji (げん). He's tall, dark, handsome, and most of all... 〜mysterious〜! Who's the mysterious man who's always reciting poetry? Genji! Who's the mysterious man who gets all the ladies? Genji! Who's the mysterious man crying over there because someone turned him down? G... Genji...

mnemonics.meaning: When the moon faces the right direction, everyone on earth becomes obese. The pull of the moon moves all the water on earth as well as inside us, so when it faces the right way, we all get super fat. Picture the moon turning to face a different direction. Feel your body start to become really obese. You get huge and round just like the moon.
mnemonics.reading: You look around and everyone is obese like you. You try to reach out to them, but you roll over like a big bowling (ぼう) ball. The person next to you does too. Soon you're all rolling around like helpless, obese bowling balls. Picture yourself, as obese and round as a bowling ball, rolling faster and faster down hills. Other people are rolling around you too. You're all screaming. You want the moon to face the other direction so it will stop. You don't like being a human bowling ball!

mnemonics.meaning: You have a plow and a (water) well. These are the two things you need in order to plow. You'd think you'd only need a plow, but you also need water if you're going to plow a field, otherwise what's the point?
mnemonics.reading: plowing all the fields are こういちs. Not Emperor こういち. These are the こういち clones the government made, and now they're being put to use. Thousands and thousands of こういちs, set free unto the world to do all our plowing work.

mnemonics.meaning: Everyone knows that when a woman plays football she becomes a princess. Thats how princesses are made. Picture the awesome princess, kicking butt and taking names, out on the football field.
mnemonics.reading: Remember the word 姫? It means princess too. If you remember the ひめ from 姫, you'll be able to remember this one too. Make sure you know both princess words and you'll know their readings too.

mnemonics.meaning: Your clan is breaking ground and building your new residence. You're all working together to make you a new home! Picture your clan, working together, to build a new residence for you on their land.
mnemonics.reading: Your new residence is complete! You step closer and the smell of tater (てい) tots hits your nose. Someone is making you tater tots in your new residence. Wait, no they aren't. Your residence is MADE of tater tots! Thank you, clan! Imagine living in a tater tot residence. Whenever you're hungry, you just lean over to the wall and munch.

mnemonics.meaning: You wake up in prison and there is a big mouth full of legs coming really, really close to your own mouth so you scream! Scream because this is terrifying. Scream because it's all you can think to do. Imagine a prison where horrible mouth leg creatures are trying to get in your mouth. You don't want to scream because they might get in there, but you can't help it.
mnemonics.reading: You scream and scream and scream until a door bursts open. It's Genghis Khan (かん) and he looks mad. Apparently your screaming is bothering him and now he's gonna give you a real reason to scream. Imagine Genghis Khan doing something to make you scream. What is it? What could Genghis Khan do that's worse than what's already happening to you?

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers that grow in a rice paddy only live to be seedlings. Once they sprout, they're plucked away to make room for more rice. Poor little seedlings. Picture the seedlings growing among the rice plants. Once they bloom they'll be picked, so let's hope they stay small as long as they can.
mnemonics.reading: The seedlings try their best to blend in by referring to themselves as myou (みょう), you know, me and you combined. That's myou. Listen to the little seedlings say myou over and over. Too bad the farmers can tell they aren't rice plants.

mnemonics.meaning: A turkey sitting on a stool is something every ship has in its crow's nest. That's why the universal ship counter is a turkey on a stool. Not a crow. Picture yourself counting ships by pointing your finger from one turkey propped up on a stool to the next. You'll be the best ship counter in the world at this rate!
mnemonics.reading: Once you become the best ship counter in the world everyone will think you are super sexy (せき)! Nothing is sexier than being able to count, and counting ships is the sexiest thing you can count. Imagine yourself, a sexy ship counter. Sexily counting ships. You go guy/girl/non binary person! So sexy!

mnemonics.meaning: If you look in a tiger's stomach you'll find a bunch of skin. It's really gross but what else did you think you'd find? Everyone knows tigers can't digest the skin of the things it eats.  Imagine yourself opening a tigers mouth and looking all the way down into its stomach and seeing a bunch of skin. Why would you imagine that? Eww.
mnemonics.reading: The only person who would try to take skin from a tiger's stomach is a fool (ふ). You'll probably get your head bitten off looking for skin that way.   Imagine a fool trying to pull skin out of a tiger's stomach. You can imagine them getting their skin added to the pile too if you want.

mnemonics.meaning: A car that's lacking is really soft. Cars need to be hard so that things like bugs and other cars wont hurt the people inside when you hit them. But if your car is lacking the hardness it needs, you'll have a really soft, useless car. Picture a soft car lacking what it needs to drive down the road. It's so soft it just flops down and won't move.
mnemonics.reading: This car is probably so soft because it's made entirely of naan (なん). Naan may be delicious, but it makes a really crappy car. No wonder it was so soft (and yummy). Picture trying to drive this soft naan car. It probably just sinks into the ground and then gets eaten by wild animals (and me).

mnemonics.meaning: If you mix a bunch of buildings together, you have yourself a suburb. Isn't that all a suburb is? Just a mix of a variety of buildings in one area?
mnemonics.reading: "Suburbs are what we need!" says Emperor こういち.  "That suburb life will encourage more people to study kanji," Emperor こういち continues.

mnemonics.meaning: Take the street all the way to that geoduck, way up there. When you reach it, you will have made it to the summit. You humbly present the road to the geoduck and bow before it. There is a giant geoduck at the summit of the mountain, and the street will lead you right there. Imagine the grueling climb up the mountain to the summit. Feel it in your legs, and keep looking at that tall, tall geoduck. Now imagine kneeling those same aching legs humbly to the street below the geoduck.
mnemonics.reading: You are at the top, the summit of everything! You humbly survey your surroundings from the top of the geoduck, only to see someone on the street, running toward you. It is Mrs. Chou (ちょう), and she looks angry. Anytime you use the street, you're in Mrs. Chou's territory. After detecting you were using her street to reach the geoduck, she started coming after you. Remember, wherever there's a street (radical), Mrs. Chou is not far behind.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to throw your two wolverines and your turkey into the oncoming tsunami if you want to wash them at the same time. It's the only way you can get them clean at once without the wolverines fighting over the turkey and somebody getting hurt. The tsunami is big enough to wash them all before anything bad happens. Imagine the tsunami coming toward you. Two wolverines in one hand and a turkey in the other. You're gonna wash them so good they'll never get dirty again.
mnemonics.reading: Once they're nice and washed you need to subdue them by poking each of them with a tack (たく). The tack has special sleeping medicine on it, so once they're nice and clean you can put them back in their cages without them trying to eat each other. If you want to wash your animals make sure to have your special tack ready. The tsunami will recede pretty fast so get it out!

mnemonics.meaning: If you put two mustaches on either side of a tsunami it won't know which way to go and spin back and forth until it becomes a whirlpool. Mustaches are pretty gross, so I don't blame the tsunami for avoiding them. Picture the tsunami spinning in a circle, trying not to hit the mustaches until it spins itself into a giant whirlpool.
mnemonics.reading: The whirlpool is huge, and it starts pulling things into itself. Oh no, is that my car (か)? Hey, wait! Whirlpool give my car back! Picture my car getting sucked into the whirlpool. Picture me crying as my car disappears into it forever.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have an ear for the public's heart, you must be very wise. You can understand everything the people want, and you know how to give it to them because you listen to their hearts so well. Close your eyes and open your ears. Feel all of the wise things fill you.
mnemonics.reading: All of these wise things are stored in your soul (そう), not your brain. That's where all of these kinds of intuitive feelings live. Picture your wise soul, living inside your body. Somehow it just seems to know what the public really wants. It's like your soul is connected to their souls, granting you this wisdom.

mnemonics.meaning: When a tree grows old, it will wither. Old trees' roots and leaves grow inefficient, and they can't get enough nutrients. It's only natural for them to wither up a little bit.
mnemonics.reading: This withered tree's best friend is a human 子 (こ). Imagine the child hugging the tree. It gave the 子 its shade, its sap, and eventually its body to build a house. What an awful child, and what a generic giving tree.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have mercy upon those you love it's called affection. You end up doing things out of the kindness of your heart because they mean a lot to you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は慈愛に満ちた微笑を僕に向けた。
She turned her affectionate smile toward me.

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning of this word and the meaning of the kanji are the same: Again! This is a very common word, but it's almost always written in kana in casual situations. However, it's often written in kanji in formal contexts, such as official paperwork and legal documents. You'll also see it in some literature, particularly stuff that was written around the time of Miyazawa Kenji and Natsume Soseki.
mnemonics.reading: The reading you learned for the kanji is the same as the reading for this word. You hopefully won't have to learn it... again.

sentences: 別れを告げ、それから又数年が過ぎた。
They said their goodbyes, and another few years passed.
この書類は、必ず黒のペン又はボールペンで記入してください。
This form must be filled out with a black pen or ballpoint pen.
「僕又来ますね 」と言って、猫はそそくさと帰って行った。
"I'll be back," he said, and the cat hurried off.

mnemonics.meaning: Plowed land is called arable land. This is the kind of land you use for growing crops or for pastures.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この辺りには耕地が広がっています。
The arable land is spread out in this area.

mnemonics.meaning: If you scream wake up! at someone you can bet they're going to awaken. Screaming anything at a sleeping person would probably rouse them. They'll probably be mad at you though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大学の入学式で、学生たちに飲酒やカルト宗教についての注意喚起が行われました。
At the university entrance ceremony the students were alerted to the dangers of alcohol and cults.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. That said, it's mostly used as a standalone word meaning "bay" in classical literature. Nowadays, it comes up most in place names, like the port Tagonoura (田子の浦) and the city of Urayasu (浦安市).
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 駿河湾西沿岸は田子ノ浦と呼ばれます。
The west coast of Suruga Bay is called Takono Bay.

mnemonics.meaning: The point at which something starts to boil is the boiling point.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 沸点は何度ですか。
How many degrees is the boiling point?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 瓶ビールを一本ください。
One bottled beer, please.

mnemonics.meaning: What's stuffed in the bottle? Jam you bottled for later! How could you forget?
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 瓶 and the kun'yomi reading for 詰 that you learned when you learned 詰める. You've learned them both so as long as you remember the rendaku, you should be able to read this word too! Just remember that 詰 is taking the め from 詰める with it in this word too. You can't see it, but it's there.

sentences: メープルシロップを瓶詰しています。
I’m bottling maple syrup.

mnemonics.meaning: When you use your intuition to determine the amount of something, you'll end up doing the calculations in your head. You do the same thing when it's time to pay your bill at dinner too, just determine the amount in your head, go with your intuition, and it should be the right amount.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 定 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're having trouble with the calculation of the amount on your bill, just call Jourm (じょう). He's really great at numbers and he will be able to figure out the numbers in his head really fast.

sentences: お勘定をお願いします。
Can I have the check, please?

mnemonics.meaning: A morally good person who has mercy upon people gives to charity. These people prove they're good by mercifully giving all their money away to the poor and needy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この本は慈善事業支援の目的で出版されました。
This book was published for the purpose of supporting charitable projects.

mnemonics.meaning: Chastity is always in season so it's always cool to try to keep your chastity. Spring, summer? Doesn't matter. Your decision to stay that way is fine no matter what time of year it is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は最後まで貞節を守ったんだ。
She protected her chastity until the end.

mnemonics.meaning: You are a strong, independent person and you are the only one who can manipulate your chastity. Nobody else can. So if you want to keep your chastity that's completely up to you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの男が彼女の貞操を奪ったのよ。
That man robbed her of her virtue.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 襟が曲がっていますよ。
Your collar is twisted.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have mercy for people who are sad you have a lot of compassion. You just can't help but go easy on sad people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 祖母は本当に慈悲深い人だった。
My grandmother was a really compassionate person.

mnemonics.meaning: A one sided corner is still a corner, just a really small one.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そのことが心の片隅にずっと引っかかっていたんです。
That had always been stuck in the corner of my mind.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この部屋の隅に、少女の霊がいます。
There is a girl’s ghost in the corner of the room.

mnemonics.meaning: Plow the earth to make it ready for cultivation and farming.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この土地を耕作するには許可がいります。
You need approval in order to cultivate this plot of land.

mnemonics.meaning: Even something dry will dry up more if it's got dehydration. There's a lot of dryness going on here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 乾燥対策でマスクをつけています。
I’m wearing a mask to counter the dryness.

mnemonics.meaning: Wash wash powder is the detergent you put in the wash you make sure your clothes are washed well. Detergent used to only be available in powder form back in the old days, and it still can be, so this is for that good powdery stuff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 粉. You already learned this reading for 粉 when you learned the word 小麦粉. If you can remember that, you should know the readings for this one too!

sentences: 洗濯粉がきれちゃった。
We ran out of detergent.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 現在、郡は地名に使われることが多い。
The word "county" is now often used in place names.

mnemonics.meaning: The wash wash shop is where you go to get your clothes washed extra well. It's the dry cleaners! They wash your clothes way better than you can because they wash them twice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a mix of the on'yomi readings for 洗濯 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings by now, so you should be able to read this word too!

sentences: 洗濯屋にワイシャツを取りに行ってきます。
I’m going to pick up my dress shirt from the dry cleaners.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that withers from thirst ends up drying up. If you let a plant dry up like this it might die if you don't water it soon.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 渇 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If all of your plants are drying up you should just give them to your cats (かつ). Cats love to play with dried up plants. At least they won't go to waste.

sentences: もうすぐ石油は枯渇する。
The petroleum will dry up very soon.

mnemonics.meaning: In order to use a house counter in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find eaves. And all those eaves together stand in a row.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  These houses that stand in a row are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have no key (のき). With no key, those eaves are just there for you to look at.

sentences: ここには多くのラーメン屋台が軒を連ねています。
There are a lot of ramen carts standing in a row here.

mnemonics.meaning: The prefecture in Japan where they love princesses is Ehime Prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: This reading is a little messy. This reading for 愛 is an exception, 媛 uses the kun'yomi reading ひめ, and 県 uses the on'yomi reading けん. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember this reading for 愛: If you ask anyone outside of Ehime Prefecture what they think of princesses they'll respond with, "Eh" (え). They don't really care either way. If someone from Ehime heard that they'd says, "EH? EH?! Princesses are the BEST!"

sentences: 私は愛媛県の出身です。
I am from Ehime Prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: A sky bottle is a bottle that has nothing but sky in it. It's an empty bottle.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. You learned this reading for 空 when you learned 空き缶. If you can remember that, you can remember this too! Oh and sometimes you'll see this written 空瓶 without the kana too. And when that happens it can be read からびん! So if you learned it one way and not the other, don't worry, we'll take both here. Just know that seeing it as 空き瓶 (and pronouncing it あきびん) is way more common.

sentences: 空瓶はこちらに捨ててください。
Please throw away empty bottles here.

mnemonics.meaning: The most mysterious thing that's connected to a house is the entranceway. When you're walking into one you never know what's coming next. You just take off your shoes and hope the rest of the house isn't really weird or something. If it is, the entryway is then your only way out.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 玄関で靴を脱いでください。
Please take off your shoes in the entranceway.

mnemonics.meaning: An explanation that's bright is just a really clear and well developed explanation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これについて、正式に釈明をする必要がある。
You need to formally explain this.

mnemonics.meaning: Even if you untie an explanation it's still a pretty good explanation anyway.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その解釈は間違っていると思います。
I think that explanation is wrong.

mnemonics.meaning: Farming with a plow is still farming.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 僕のおじいさんは農耕をしています。
My grandfather farms.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that's both fat and obese has even more fat on it than you first thought. Like the blubber on a really big whale.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 太ももの脂肪を落としたいんです。
I want to lose the fat from my thighs.

mnemonics.meaning: A gentle and soft thing will be really flexible and pliable. Soft things are really easy to bend, like towels and flower petals.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このホテルは色々な要望に柔軟に対応してくれます。
This hotel flexibly deals with various requests.

mnemonics.meaning: Four corners are four corners!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both by now, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 写真の四隅を暗く加工するにはどうすればいいのか教えてください。
Can you teach me the best process to make the four corners of a picture dark?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of greatness? Great!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The only thing a great person doesn't do is make errors (えら). That's what makes them so great. They can always sense when an error is about to happen and they correct it before it even has a chance!

sentences: 社長がそんなに偉いんですか？
What makes the company president so great?

mnemonics.meaning: Big greatness is still greatness, just a lot of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 人類史上最も偉大な発明は何ですか。
What is the greatest invention in all of human history?

mnemonics.meaning: A person with a lot of greatness is a great person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 世界の偉人たちの名言を集めました。
I’ve collected wise sayings from great men of the world.

mnemonics.meaning: The land inside of a residence is called the grounds or the premises. Only really big residences have land inside them big enough to be called the "grounds" though.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは、邸内の写真です。
This is a picture of the grounds.

mnemonics.meaning: Soft prohibition isn't going to be as bad as jail or prison. They went soft on you, so you're only under house arrest. That's not so bad, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は自宅軟禁下に置かれました。
She was placed under house arrest.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This can be used to count houses and buildings, which is good because you never know which buildings have people living in them like they're houses.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この人は、マンションを五軒持っています。
This guy has five apartments.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い all the way at the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. Confused is already an adjective and this word is a little different. Usually when you get confused it's because you were already hurried, busy, and things were hectic. So this adjective is what causes your confusion.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading, so you should be able to read this already!

sentences: 十二月はレストランにとって慌ただしい時期だ。
December is a hectic season for restaurants.
本当、カツオくんのお姉さんって慌ただしい性格ね。
Seriously, your older sister is such a frantic person, Katsuo-kun.
出発が慌ただしく、コーヒーも飲めなかった。
It was a hasty departure. I didn't even get to drink a cup of coffee.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to char fish for dinner it will dry up because of your own impatience. Charring fish takes time and if you're too uneasy and shove it too far in the fire it will dry out, burn, and get gross.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 度重なる事業の失敗で、すっかり焦燥しきっているんだ。
I’m thoroughly irritated with this repeatedly failing project.

mnemonics.meaning: A lotus flower is a lotus flower!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 花 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Something is on the lotus flower... something little and kinda shiny. It's a little gecko (げ). It's hiding in the lotus and trying to catch flies. How cute!

sentences: この池にはいつから蓮花があるのですか。
How long have lotus flowers been in this pond?

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a residence that's also your house, it's still your residence. But you probably have a lot of money if you can own your own house, so it's probably a nice, big mansion too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この邸宅は、幽霊が出ることで有名です。
This mansion is famous for ghosts appearing in it.

mnemonics.meaning: This may look like an adjective, but it's actually the noun version of the kanji watered. Watered things, like plants, hold a lot of moisture in them.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 潤う, so you should know this one too.

sentences: この化粧水が、あなたのお肌の潤いを保ちます。
This lotion will help keep the moisture in your skin.

mnemonics.meaning: A fire in a bottle that makes a big fire when thrown is called a Molotov Cocktail. Don't throw them in the house please.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 男は火炎瓶を投げつけた。
The man threw a Molotov cocktail.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Usually these types of mounds are burial mounds. (There's bodies under there!)
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 塚を見下ろすことのは失礼です。
It’s rude to look down at a burial mound.

mnemonics.meaning: Before you can give an explanation of who you are to someone you're about to meet, you have to nod or bow as a greeting first. It's rude to start explaining who you are before you greet them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 会 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When someone bows to you, you always feel a little uncomfortable, so you say, "Eh" (え) and try to get them to stop. You're so uncomfortable that you can't think of words and "eh" is all you can manage to get out.

sentences: 会釈をしたら会釈を返すのが礼儀でしょう。
You might have the decency to return my nod with a nod.

mnemonics.meaning: Corner corners are still corners. Sometimes they're the corners TO corners, so they're the little nooks and crannies that are hard to get at.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji you learned, twice, with the second one rendaku'd. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は部屋を隅々まで掃除しました。
Today I cleaned every nook and cranny of my room.

mnemonics.meaning: If your brain can't stop pouring out all the explanations your teacher gives you, you'll need to keep notes. That way when the information pours out of your head, you'll still have your comments and annotations to help you remember the teacher's explanations later.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その場合は、注釈を付けてください。
In that case, please add notes.

mnemonics.meaning: A government residence is one that is assigned to government officials. That means it's their official residence, and it goes on all their official paperwork.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 首相官邸ツアーに参加しました。
I participated in a tour of the Prime Minister’s official residence.

mnemonics.meaning: A public residence is the one you tell everyone for things like documents and loans and stuff. That means it's your official residence and it's in everyone's books.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大統領公邸が何者かに襲撃されました。
The President’s official residence was raided by someone.

mnemonics.meaning: You are determined to get an agreement out of people so you decide to be really positive with them. As long as you make it seem like everything is super great, and totally good for them, they'll end up agreeing with everything you say.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして肯定も否定もしないんですか。
Why won’t you say yes or no?
まずは自分を肯定してみてください。
First of all, try to affirm yourself.
その肯定の気持ち、これからも大切にしてね。
Cherish that positive feeling from now on.

mnemonics.meaning: A private residence is a private residence!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この豪華な建物は、大統領の私邸です。
This gorgeous building is the president’s private residence.

mnemonics.meaning: The fat that comes out of the wood from trees is used to make resin. Trees don't have fat, you say? Well you're wrong, look it up. Trees are super fat and we use the resin from them to do all sorts of stuff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これを透明の樹脂で固めました。
This was hardened with transparent resin.

mnemonics.meaning: Clear flat is one way to write the Japanese given name Ryohei.  Some well-known people with the name include metal sculptor Miyada Ryohei (宮田 亮平), actor Suzuki Ryohei (鈴木 亮平), and model and actor Ōtani Ryohei (大谷 亮平), who acts in both Japanese and Korean films and dramas.
mnemonics.reading: Unlike most Japanese names, this one actually uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Yay for easy names!

sentences: 亮平は人気のある男の子の名前です。
Ryohei is a popular boy's name.
この間、日本の有名な俳優の鈴木亮平を間近で見たよ。
I saw the famous Japanese actor Suzuki Ryohei up close the other day.
亮平君は漫画が好きで、東京に出て絵の勉強をしたいと思っています。
Ryohei-kun loves manga and he wants to go to Tokyo to study drawing.

mnemonics.meaning: This isn't just any lotus. It's THE lotus. The Sacred Lotus. When you see it blooming all alone in a murky pond, you'll know.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The sacred lotus has (はす) a strong significance (and probably some powers). It has something at least, just remember it has something special going on, and you'll be fine.

sentences: 蓮の花の花言葉は何ですか。
What does the sacred lotus mean in the language of flowers?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The best time to plant seedlings is at night (なえ). If you plant them at night they'll sleep through the whole transplanting process and they'll wake up happy and ready to grow.

sentences: 四月に苗を植えました。
I planted seedlings in April.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 港には、七隻の船が止まっています。
Seven ships are stopped in this harbor.

mnemonics.meaning: The skin under your skin is still skin. The extra layer is there to make sure when you get little cuts they don't bleed all over the place.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ギターを弾くので指先の皮膚が厚いんです。
The skin on my fingertips is thick because I play the guitar.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's another way of saying wise? Smart or discerning.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What did you do to get so smart? You sat (さと) in class all day. You didn't even get up after class was over. You planted your butt down and sat in your desk until class started again the next morning. You absorb knowledge through your behind, so as long as you sat down all day, you sucked up all the knowledge in the world!

sentences: この子は本当に聡い子だよ。
This is a really smart kid.

mnemonics.meaning: Suburbs on the outside of town are still suburbs. They're sometimes called the outskirts of town too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 都心と郊外、どちらに住みたいですか。
Would you rather live in the city center or the suburbs?

mnemonics.meaning: Suburbs near you are still suburbs. They're all pretty much the same.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は東京近郊に住んでいます。
I live in the suburbs of Tokyo.

mnemonics.meaning: The mountain summit is still called the summit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 富士山の山頂には住所がありません。
There is no address for the summit of Mt. Fuji.

mnemonics.meaning: If you call someone by screaming, you're probably trying to summon them like a magician would. Magicians have to scream their spells out in order for them to work. So you have to scream out their name when you call them if you want to summon someone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 魔法使いを召喚しました。
I summoned a magician.

mnemonics.meaning: A seedling letter is the very first letter you learn when you're little. What's the first thing you learn to spell when you're little? Your surname! You need to know who your family is, otherwise if you get lost or something happens, you won't know how to get home! Or even who you are!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その苗字、初めて聞きました。
That was the first time I’d heard that surname.

mnemonics.meaning: 世界 means "world" and 恐慌 means "panic" or "scare," so when you put them together you get a scare that made the entire world panic. This is how we refer to The Great Depression. It was caused by and subsequently resulted in everybody in the whole world panicking together about money.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You've learned them already, so you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: 私の祖父は世界恐慌が起きた年に生まれました。
My grandfather was born the year the Great Depression occurred.
世界恐慌は様々な国に影響を与えた。
The Great Depression affected many countries.
世界恐慌は失業率と共に自殺率までも上げた。
The Great Depression raised unemployment and even suicide rates.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means boil, so the verb version is to boil. It can also be used to mean to get excited, because you're boiling with that excitement.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want to boil for dinner tonight? Walrus (わ). Boiled walrus is a delicacy where you're from, and the only way to be able to eat its yummy walrus flesh is to boil it for a long time until it's soft. Mmm smells good.

sentences: 私はお湯が沸くのを待っている。
I’m waiting for the water to boil.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means cover, so the verb version is to cover or to hide.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You decide to cover yourself with a sheet because you want to pretend to be a ghost. But covering yourself isn't enough. If you really want people to believe in your disguise you have to say, "おお!" Otherwise they'll think you're a covered chair or a bush. If you おお at them they'll definitely know you're a ghost covered in that sheet.

sentences: 私の庭は落ち葉に覆われています。
My garden is covered in fallen leaves.

mnemonics.meaning: If you humbly do something you are going to humbly receive, to humbly accept, or eat or drink it. Basically you're humbly doing a lot of things. And you can use this word for all of them!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You technically already know this reading! You know how people say いただきます? Well that's the same as this! You're humbly receiving your meal. So to humbly receive is いただく!

sentences: お祝いを頂き、本当に有難うございます。
Thank you very much for your congratulations.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means between, so the verb version is to put between or to sandwich.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: パンにハムと卵を挟みました。
I put the egg and ham between the bread.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means call, so the verb version is to respectfully call. It can also be used as to respectfully eat or to respectfully invite too. It's a really useful word like that. As long as you remember it's the respectful/honorific way of doing things you should be fine.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you want to respectfully call out to someone you need to make sure you don't look them in the 目 (め) because that's super rude. Always remember to turn your 目 away to show respect.

sentences: あなたのお姉さまは神に召されたのですよ。
Your older sister was called by the gods.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means roast, and the verb version is to roast or to toast. This verb is most commonly used when referring to dry roasting things like coffee, tea, or beans.
mnemonics.reading: Do you know what animal likes to roast and to toast things? Eagles (い)! They're always roasting coffee beans and the like. That's how they stay so alert.

sentences: どうやってコーヒー豆を煎るんですか？
How do you roast coffee beans?
フライパンでピーナッツを煎りました。
I roasted peanuts in a frying pan.
ココナッツを煎ると食感がよくなります。
If you roast coconut, the texture improves.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scream, so the verb version is to scream or to shout.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If you want to shout at someone you should pick a word that will really hit them. Give them a big whammy (わめ) to the face! Hey, that word works. Shout WHAMMY!

sentences: 酔っぱらいが喚いているんだよ。
A drunk guy is shouting.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means immersed, so the verb version is what happens when you immerse something in a liquid. It's to soak or to dip.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 浸る, so you should know this one too.

sentences: どうして野菜を水に浸しているの？
Why are you soaking the vegetables in water?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means plow, so the verb version is to plow or to till.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to till your land because you want to have a tiger yard (たがや). That's either when you have a yard full of live tigers, or you plant bushes and shape them into tigers. I hope it's the second kind of tiger yard. Either way, you have to plow the land to get it ready.

sentences: この機械で畑を耕すんですよ。
I’ll plow the field with this machine.

mnemonics.meaning: Wash wash to wash your clothes. You wash wash your laundry. Hmm wash wash sounds like the sound my laundry machine makes when it's washing my underpants.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: セーターをお湯で洗濯したら縮んでしまった。
I washed my sweater in hot water and it shrunk.
洗濯が好きだと言っていたから結婚したのに、今まで一度も洗濯をしてくれたことがありません。
I married him because he said he likes doing laundry, but he still hasn't even done it once.
「俺のワイシャツ、今洗濯してる？」「ああ、それなら口紅が付いていたので洗濯屋さんに出しておいたわよ。」
"Is my white shirt in the wash?" "Oh, that one had lipstick on it, so I took it to the cleaners."

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wither, so the verb version is to wither or to die.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: How do you get plants to wither? You hit them with your car (か). It isn't very good for your car either, but the plants will definitely die, so problem solved!

sentences: せっかく植えた木が枯れてしまいました。
The tree I took great pains to grow withered.

mnemonics.meaning: When you do not have chastity, it's probably because you were unfaithful to your promise to whoever you told you'd stay chaste to.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 妻が不貞をはたらいたので、離婚しました。
My wife was unfaithful so we got divorced.

mnemonics.meaning: Mysterious rice is unpolished rice, or brown rice. You're used to seeing nice white rice, so seeing rice look any other way is really strange for you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 米 so here's a mnemonic to help you: The biggest problem when you buy unpolished rice is the mice (まい)! Mice like to eat and sleep in unpolished rice, so you have to be careful when you buy a bag that you get rid of all the sleeping mice before you try to cook it.

sentences: 玄米は体に良い。
Unpolished rice is good for your health.

mnemonics.meaning: A bottle for flowers is a vase. You should get some flowers and put them in a vase for someone special right now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは素敵な花瓶ですね。
This is a beautiful vase.

mnemonics.meaning: In the middle of a whirlpool you'll find a spinning vortex of water. You really don't want to get sucked in there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は離婚騒動で渦中の人だよ。
He’s in a vortex of divorce turmoil.

mnemonics.meaning: A wash wash machine is just another way of saying washing machine. It does extra washing that you can't do by hand so there are two washes here.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 洗濯機が壊れたみたい。
The washing machine seems to be broken.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this meaning, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  There are lots of whirlpools at the uni zoo (うず). Unis really like being spun around in whirlpools, so when you go to the zoo to see them look out for the tank full of them!

sentences: 海に渦が発生するのはどうして？
Why do whirlpools appear in the ocean?

mnemonics.meaning: A wise and bright person is wise and intelligent. In fact, they have so much wisdom that it's showing up as brightness on their skin. Sparkle sparkle goes the wise old woman.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 聡明な子供達に恵まれてとても幸せです。
I am very lucky to have intelligent children.
こんなに聡明さと経験を兼ね備えた人材いないって。
I don't think anyone else has that combination of wisdom and experience.
三村崇は非常に聡明な少年だった。
Takashi Mimura was a very wise boy.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is made of dirt, legs, and winter. If you have to bury your legs in the dirt in winter, it's probably because you got frostbite. You had to leave your dead legs behind. :(

When a spirit lives in a sheep it becomes the most auspicious creature on the planet. Lights shine out of it and the whole world weeps at its beauty. Look at the sheep's fluffy glowing head. Nothing could be more auspicious and glorious than this. Picture this auspicious spirit sheep. Blessing the children with its fluffy hooves.
mnemonics.reading: The spirit sheep is so auspicious that the Shougun (しょう) declares this day to be the most auspicious of all days. The day when the spirit sheep appeared. Picture the Shougun telling the world that they must fly spirit sheep flags on this day forever, because of how auspicious it is.

mnemonics.meaning: I hope all you're doing in the bathtub is taking a bath. I mean, you can do other things if you want I guess. But bathtubs were made just for baths! Picture yourself taking a bath in your bathtub. Relaxing!
mnemonics.reading: When do you miss taking a bath the most? When you're on the road (ろ). Traveling is fun and all, but when you're stuck in a car, traveling down a dirt road for days, all you want to do is take a nice long bath. Imagine being stuck on the road all day for a week. Imagine how good a bath will feel when you finally get home. Nice and hot and relaxing. Mmmm...

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of the library thinks that all the books in their library are better than everyone else's books. He's a very biased person. If he wasn't the leader of that specific library he'd probably feel differently. Imagine showing the leader your favorite book. "That's not a book in MY library," he says, and throws it in the trash. That's so biased! He didn't even give it a shot!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to give in to his biased recommendations and look at what he has in his library. It doesn't take long until you realize that these books are all about hens (へん) and hen care. This guy is so biased about his favorite books that he only filled his library with what HE wants to read. And apparently that thing is taking care of hens... weird. "This is such biased crap," you say, as you finish reading the title of a book called "Hens are better than all other birds." Screw this leader guy and his books.

mnemonics.meaning: If you look at flowers the first thing you notice are the leaves and petals themselves, then the next thing you notice are the briars. You never see thorns first, only after you've looked at the flowers.  Imagine what you see next after looking at the pretty flowers. The briars are what you see next. Spiky and sharp. It would have been nice if you had seen them first.
mnemonics.reading: When you see the briars you can't help but yell, Eee! Ba riars! (いばら)! You pause funny because you prick your finger on one while you're yelling. Ouch! Imagine seeing the briars and yelling out "Ba RI ars!" as you prick your finger on one.

mnemonics.meaning: This building was a former prison until the cave in. You see, prisons aren't built very carefully, they just try to get them done fast enough to stuff people in there. So while you can tell this was once a building, it definitely isn't a prison anymore, since the whole thing caved in. Picture the cave in in your mind. Can you see all the little prisoners and guards being squished as the building tumbles down around them? Oh no!
mnemonics.reading: You keep picturing the cave in and you see Genghis Khan (かん) climbing over the rubble. He's the one who took down this prison! And he's coming for your town next! Genghis Khan is all about being smart and using better tactics. In this case, why fight a bunch of guards and prisoners when you can just cause a cave in and win immediately? The ol' Khan cave in, a classic war maneuver.

mnemonics.meaning: The famous gold triceratops shellfish is good for only one thing, and that's being made into chains. They link their triceratops horns together and form an unbreakable gold chain. You can't eat them, because they're gold. So they're only really good for their chaining together ability. Picture these little gold triceratops shellfish linked together by their horns in a chain around your neck. Feel them hanging there. Sparkly and cold.
mnemonics.reading: However, the only way to break the chain is to saw (さ) it open. Once the triceratops shellfish start holding on, they never let go. So when you want to take the chain off you have to really hack at it with your saw. Picture the saw in your hands, sawing back and forth on the gold chain around your neck. Maybe this isn't the best fashion accessory if you have to use a saw to get it off.

mnemonics.meaning: You give a bunch of shellfish to a clown as compensation. The clown did you some favors, and everyone knows clowns only accept shellfish as a form of currency. So your compensation is a pile of random shellfish. Picture the shellfish in your hands. Imagine handing them over to the clown as compensation for the unspeakable acts you had him do for you.
mnemonics.reading: Once the clown has been properly compensated, he looks you in the eyes, one hand full of shellfish, the other in the air, and waves, "Bye (ばい)" he says. "Bye, bye." All you have to do is give him the right amount of compensation and you'll hear his sweet "bye, bye." Then you never have to see him again.

mnemonics.meaning: Your soul is like the ground or the dawn. It is constant, never changing. Think of some other things your soul is like, but always make sure you come back to one word: constant.
mnemonics.reading: Also constant is the Emperor こういち, who will surely rule for a thousand more years! A constant rule from Emperor こういち means constant kanji learning and constant WaniKani reviews. They will always be constant!

mnemonics.meaning: You're sewing something with thread but you and your creation get frostbite while you're still working. Luckily the snowflakes freeze themselves into the cloth and turn into a pretty design. They swirl around and press a unique snowy design into the fabric. This is nice for you because you can't sew anymore with your frostbitten hands. Imagine holding your creation in your frostbitten hands as the snowflake design starts to appear. The design gets more and more complicated the longer you watch, twisting this way and that, like it's dancing in front of your eyes.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch the snowflake design form you see letters appearing in the corner! They form the name Aya (あや), our artist here at WaniKani. Somehow she's magically putting together this beautiful pattern! If you know someone else called Aya, go ahead and use them in this mnemonic! Whoever it is, imagine an Aya watching from afar holding a magic wand, creating this beautiful frosty pattern!

mnemonics.meaning: If you figure out how to use a tsunami as a weapon, everyone is going to die. You can't control a tsunami, you fool. Now you've doomed us all. Picture everyone in the world being swept away in a tsunami to die. This is what happens when you try to use nature as a weapon.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to maybe not die is to find boats (ぼつ). As long as the boats don't get smashed by the tsunami, you might be able to cheat death by holding onto the boats and not drowning. You don't want to die, do you? Get to the boats!

mnemonics.meaning: Your fingers grasp this lid and when you raise it you see a poop turkey (a turkey covered in poop). You can't help yourself, you embrace the turkey.  Someone was obviously going to cook this poop turkey in a pot, and if you hadn't looked under this lid it surely would have died. Now as you embrace it you can hear the turkey weeping softly.
mnemonics.reading: As you embrace the sad turkey it makes a funny sound and suddenly starts pooping yogurt (よう) all over you. But you don't want to stop embracing it! It's probably just scared still. But the more you squeeze, the faster the yogurt comes out of it! Imagine embracing the turkey as it covers you in yogurt poo. You hope it's yogurt at least. You aren't gonna taste it to find out. Maybe. Okay you might taste it a little.

mnemonics.meaning: When you ride your scooter on the ground listening to music under the sun, you're bound to encounter a bunch of new people! They hear your music playing as you scoot by and they come out to meet you. Picture all of the people you encounter as you ride your scooter, spreading your music around town.
mnemonics.reading: Everyone you encounter wants to bare their soul (そう) to you, literally. They're all coming out to meet you, pulling back their skin and showing you the soul ghosts inside of them.  "We love your music, look at our souls!" Uh oh, this is turning into some kind of horror movie. You better scoot a bit faster or you might meet an unfortunate fate.

mnemonics.meaning: From your mouth comes a cross, some flowers, and shellfish. It all erupts from your mouth! Imagine these three things coming out of your mouth not one at a time, but all together like an eruption. Perhaps you're laying on your back, and they burst out of your mouth.
mnemonics.reading: When do inanimate objects erupt from your mouth? Mostly when you're having fun (ふん). It's really inconvenient that things erupt from your mouth whenever you're having fun. Makes it hard to have fun.

mnemonics.meaning: If the yakuza slide you into a jet, things are especially bad for you. Not just normal bad, like, especially bad. First of all, the yakuza have you, that's bad already. But they're sliding you into their jet? That means you aren't upright, you might even be knocked out or dead. That's especially worrying, don't you think?
mnemonics.reading: You're especially worried now, because they're putting you in some kind of chute (しゅ). You already took a slide in here, and now you're teetering over the edge of a dark, steep chute into who knows where! As you slide down the chute, it's especially dark. And especially scary. And especially bad! How did this happen to you?!

mnemonics.meaning: A leader puts their hat on the ground next to a bookshelf. This is a test in ethics. People hang around the bookshelf, and the leader wants to see if anyone will steal the hat or not. That's why its a test of ethics.
mnemonics.reading: To test your ethics even more, the leader puts down a ring (りん) as well. Now we'll really see how everyone's ethics are. Will they turn in the ring to the lost and found? Will they ignore it? Will they steal it?

mnemonics.meaning: The building to the east is an exhibit. It's a pretty large building and you can see inside to all of the different exhibits within the main exhibit.
mnemonics.reading: Right now the exhibit has a bunch of chins (ちん) on display. Animal chins, human chins, every chin you can think of is in the exhibit. Go up to the first exhibit and look very closely at some turtle chins, then some crab chins, then some alligator chins. This is weirdly familiar.

mnemonics.meaning: If you tie a cross to a turkey you can trick everyone into thinking it's a falcon. The cross will stretch its wings out just enough for it to stop looking so fat and turkey like, into a super cool bird of prey. Imagine tying a cross to this turkey and see it transform into an elegant falcon. Majestic.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to name this new falcon after your favorite falcon-like ninja. Ryu Hayabusa (はやぶさ) from Ninja Gaiden! Picture your fat turkey falcon and Ryu Hayabusa teaming up Banjo and Kazooey style. Yeah, that's the dream right there. Picture your falcon Hayabusa and the real... ok fake.. Hayabusa running around together and kicking butt.

mnemonics.meaning: What do stairs do? They take you from where you were, to somewhere else. They're a way to get from place to place. Picture yourself climbing stairs, picture going from room to room. From place to place. From wherever you were to wherever you want to be.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going from place to place, make sure you have some nori (の) seaweed on you, in case you get hungry. Nori is a great source of energy. Imagine yourself going from one place to another with your pockets stuffed full of nori. The smell is starting to get overwhelming. It's making you really hungry (or nauseous, depending on how you feel about nori!).

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to have your wedding in a car you're going to need a lot of help. Cars are pretty small compared to weddings, so if you don't get help from everyone you know you won't be able to pull it off. Picture all of your close friends coming to help you squeeze everything for the wedding into your car.
mnemonics.reading: You can't just ask for help on the day of the wedding, either. You have to schedule (すけ) getting your friends' help ahead of time. They might have pretty tight schedules too, so make sure you plan early! Imagine calling all your friends and scheduling when you will get their help. Make sure you have your day planner ready!

mnemonics.meaning: There is an animal in the grass and your horrible task is to go hunting for it. Picture the shape of the animal in the grass, off in the distance. You can't see what kind of animal it is yet, but you know you're hunting it.
mnemonics.reading: You're currently hunting in a row (りょう) boat and you have to row as quietly and carefully as you can or the animal will run away. You wouldn't be able to go hunting in any other kind of boat—the motor would be too loud. Picture yourself in a row boat with all of your hunting gear. You need to be extra careful not to make any loud splashing sounds with the oars!

mnemonics.meaning: If you have spiders in your mouth, then you're going to instigate fights between people. Mostly because the spider in your mouth makes you grumpy, but also because the spider keeps telling you to be an instigator with its little mouth inside your own mouth. Imagine having a spider in your mouth. Imagine being angry about it and instigating fights between people because of it.
mnemonics.reading: The spider in your mouth tells you to instigate a fight by sawing (さ) the other person's leg off. It even whispers where you can find a nice big saw.  Picture the fight you and the spider instigated. The guy pointing at the saw, then pointing at his sawed off leg. Listen as the spider tells you to shake your head.

mnemonics.meaning: In its soul, a narwhal that's supposed to do construction under the moon, will be too lazy to do it. And when your soul is lazy, there's no way you'll be able to get something done. Picture the lazy narwhal laying on a block of ice in the moonlight. There are tools and other blocks of ice around, but he just can't seem to get up and do any construction work.
mnemonics.reading: You can't tell the lazy narwhal he's being lazy because he's your dad (だ). If he was anyone else you'd tell him off for being lazy, but you can't tell off your dad. That's just not right. Picture your lazy dad. Your big, lazy narwhal dad.

mnemonics.meaning: If you give a machine a heart it will get lazy. Hearts give us emotions and with emotions we become weak. Why would a machine with a heart want to work anymore? Nah. It's lazy time now. Picture a machine with a heart, laying on the couch, eating oil snacks, and snoozing. What a lazy machine!
mnemonics.reading: The machine is so lazy it won't even wear its tie (たい) anymore. That was the only official thing left about it, but now it's as lazy as a human. Would a lazy human put on a tie? I don't think so. Picture the lazy machine sitting on the couch again. There are untied ties all over the floor.

mnemonics.meaning: Take a leather helicopter to the moon to prove your excellent leadership. Some people called you crazy, but you'll show them, as you lead an entire crew of leather helicopter pilots on their first mission to space! Not many people have the leadership it takes to lead such a mission. Imagine what it takes to do it!
mnemonics.reading: Under your superior leadership you and your leather helicopter crew are able to make it to the moon. The moon! Your crew is so impressed by your leadership, and their lack of being very dead, and they all start laughing, "Ha (は) ha ha ha!" They thought they were going to die but you lead them to the moon safely! Imagine laughing along with the crew, in awe at your own leadership skills. Ha ha ha! We didn't die!

mnemonics.meaning: Shaving the hair off a geoduck before you try to eat it is absolutely necessary. If you don't, the hair will get caught in your throat and you'll choke. It is necessary that you remove the hair. Picture the page in your cookbook where it says "Shaving the hair off your geoduck = Necessary!!" It's absolutely necessary that you follow that instruction!
mnemonics.reading: It is also necessary that you wear a suit (す) when eating shaved geoduck. It's a super fancy meal so a suit is necessary for you to enjoy it correctly. What's necessary? To shave the hair off your geoduck and to wear a suit. That's not too hard. You should do it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take a cow's life you're turning it into an offering. In the old days, cows' lives were given to the gods as offerings pretty often. Picture yourself offering the cow's life up to the god(s). It's a good thing we don't actually have to do this anymore, you think.
mnemonics.reading: You prepare the offering with your holy blue saber (せい). Normally this would be gruesome, but your saber glows and the cow's life shoots up into the sky without you laying a hand on it. Thanks to the mercy of your saber, the offering is quick and painless. A normal saber, however, would have cut that cow to bits. Like, really just wrecked it. Good thing we didn't make you think about that, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: If a grain has a fault, it needs to be put back in order. Grains must be perfectly identical at all times, otherwise they'll be thrown out. That's why special people will go out and check them to confirm their regularity. Keeping order is a tough job! Imagine being one of these people who maintain order by going out in the fields and inspecting every single grain, keeping the good ones and plucking off the ones with faults.
mnemonics.reading: You can always tell if a company keeps order or if it cheats (ちつ) just by looking at the grains. If there are faulty grains in there, they cheated and order was not maintained. Now you have to go through all the grains and throw out the weird ones yourself.
