mnemonics.meaning: There was once a melon child, that is, a child with the body of a melon. When he was born, his parents didn't want him, so he became an orphan. The "melon boy orphan," is what they called him. Imagine a melon (your favorite kind) with a face and arms and legs sticking out. He walks up to you and says "hello kind person, could you help an orphan?"
mnemonics.reading: The orphan melon boy is but a 子 (こ). That's the sad thing about the melon orphan boy... he's just a child. "Hello gov, I'm just a child," he says to you.

mnemonics.meaning: If you point flowers in the same direction you'll be able to smell their wonderful perfume. The best way to get perfume out of flowers is to make them face the same way. Then the smell will go the same direction, making you smell great. Imagine aiming a bunch of flowers in the same direction towards you. The perfume coats your body. You smell great now!
mnemonics.reading: You decide to perfume your entire home (ほう) by planting flowers all the way around it, all facing in toward it. Now when you're in your home the overwhelming smell of perfume assaults your nostrils. It's actually... really strong. Oh... oh no it's too strong, you can't breathe. And you live alone. Help! Someone!

mnemonics.meaning: Under the window, you place a shellfish, then slam the window shut to pierce its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise. This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them sushi counters! Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
mnemonics.reading: Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them. Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.

mnemonics.meaning: The rice that's prepared at dawn by the village are provisions for the army. The army is scheduled to arrive right after dawn, so all of the village's provisions for them have to be ready by then. Picture everyone in the village getting all of their rice together as provisions for the army. Even the kids and old people are helping out.
mnemonics.reading: Once all of the provisions are ready, the soldiers show up in their row (りょう) boats and load it all up. But they aren't done there. "Rice isn't enough, we need roe (ろう) so we will have the strength to row our row boats back." And so the village brings them all of their roe too. Picture the soldiers gobbling down their provisions of rice and roe in their row boats as they row away.

mnemonics.meaning: If you stand in the wind it will be really quick to knock you over. So quick that you probably won't even know the wind did it. You'll end up standing up again just to be knocked over again, just as quick. Imagine how quick the wind knocks you over when you stand up. So quick, you don't even remember being up. Try again and try to count how many seconds it takes for it to knock you down. Less than one. Now that's quick.
mnemonics.reading: The wind was so quick to knock you down that you sat (さつ) down instead. The wind may be quick, but it can't knock you down if you've already sat yourself. Picture how quick you sat down. Even faster than the quick wind. Nice job!

mnemonics.meaning: If your soul is acting like the sun trapped in a net sitting on a stool, then people will ridicule you for your laziness. You're just sitting there, trapped and not moving. Your soul just doesn't want to move or do anything though... and that may look like laziness, but you can't help it. You wish your friends and family wouldn't ridicule you. You're going through enough, internally.
mnemonics.reading: When people ridicule you, when you can't stop the laziness, you read manga (まん). Manga helps you feel better about the mean things people say. Manga helps you feel like you're doing something, and that you aren't just a lazy person. Picture yourself reading manga and watch as the people who ridicule you and call you lazy fade away into the background. You're going to be okay.

mnemonics.meaning: Play your drum under the moon and your hair will swell! The more you play and the longer it's under the moon, the larger your hair will swell. Have you been suffering from flat, boring hair? Well do I have the swelling treatment you've been looking for!
mnemonics.reading: Using this method, your hair swells so much it looks like a giant bowling (ぼう) ball is sitting on top of your head. It's all round, and well... swollen is probably the only word that fits. Imagine watching your hair swell to the size of a large bowling ball. Imagine never being able to go bowling again because the comparison is too easy for people to make.

mnemonics.meaning: Your scooter gave you a splinter, so you had to go in for treatment. Imagine how bad a scooter splinter would be! You would need special treatment for that.
mnemonics.reading: After you get treatment, you feel really good (ぐう). Not just "good," but "goooooood." Emphasize the long vowel for the long vowel in ぐう. You feel this way because when you went in for treatment, they gave you the good, good drugs. You know the ones.

mnemonics.meaning: When you win especially well everyone will find you admirable. So get out there and win!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつは殊勝な女だったよ。
That’s an admirable woman.

mnemonics.meaning: If you do not have any ethics you'll probably do something crappy, like commit adultery. Usually only unethical people would cheat on their spouse, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうやら妻が不倫をしているようなんです。
It seems that my wife is committing adultery.

mnemonics.meaning: All the art, music, or books that come out after a person dies are considered to be released after death or posthumously.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 没後50年を記念した展覧会を予定しています。
A commemoration exhibition is planned 50 years after their death.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have the leadership spirit it means you have a lot of ambition to go after the things you want. And you'll be able to lead others because of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの息子は、若いのに覇気が無い。
Despite his youth, my son lacks ambition.

mnemonics.meaning: Animals exit the mountains into your land and never seem to die! They end up appearing frequently in your garden, eating all your yummy carrots and watermelons, and then make their exit back into the hills. They're infesting your home now and you don't know what to do!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本各地でクマが大量出没している。
Bears appear frequently in large quantities all over Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a design from Ayano. Do you know an Ayano who's good at designing things? A couple creative Ayanos include traditional Okinawan folk singer and sanshin player Uema Ayano (上間 綾乃), and author Takeda Ayano (武田 綾乃) who won the Yoshikawa Eiji Literary Newcomer Award in 2021.
mnemonics.reading: This name uses the readings that you learned with the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 子供の頃、綾乃というとても無邪気な女の子と友達だった。
When I was a child, I was friends with a very innocent girl called Ayano.
先日、綾乃さんから電話があったんですが、留守電にメッセージが入っていなかったんです。
Ayano called the other day but she didn't leave a voicemail message.
綾乃ちゃんと亮平君が殴り合いをしているけど、どうしよう。
Ayano-chan and Ryohei-kun are having a fistfight, but what should I do?

mnemonics.meaning: Stand behind someone and embrace them. That's how you show them you're backing and supporting them. Do this to your local politicians.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうせ出馬者を擁立しようとしているだけだろう。
I’m sure that they are just trying to support the candidate.

mnemonics.meaning: Let the wind in from the window above your bath so the water is cool enough for you to take a bath! If the water is too hot, you'll get all dizzy and that's dangerous!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. This isn't the same on'yomi reading you learned for 風, though. It's a little different: ふ. If you're taking a bath you'd be a fool (ふ) to bring food in there. Drop the う or you'll end up as soup!

sentences: ゆっくりお風呂に浸かりたいなあ。
I want to slowly soak in the bath.

mnemonics.meaning: A sealed chain won't break or open so it gets in the way of everyone, forming a blockade. This can happen at banks too and it will result in them freezing your account!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 銀行が潰れて、預金が封鎖されてしまったんです。
The bank was bankrupted and my account was frozen.

mnemonics.meaning: One design that you can take anywhere with you is cat's cradle, the game where you loop string around your hands and fingers to create patterns.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi for both kanji.

sentences: 子供の時、綾取りをしていたのを覚えています。
I remember playing cat's cradle when I was a child.
この間、綾取りに挑戦した。
The other day, I tried my hand at cat's cradle.
マミさんには折り紙や綾取りなどいろいろな遊びを教えてもらいました。
Mami taught us various games such as origami and cat's cradle.

mnemonics.meaning: A cave in where everyone dies is still a cave in, just a really sad one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 地震であそこの道路が陥没したそうです。
It looks like that highway over there collapsed from the earthquake.

mnemonics.meaning: If you take along a chain with you it's still a chain, it's just moving somewhere new.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: まずはこの負の連鎖を断ち切る必要があります。
First, you must sever ties with this negative chain.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The best way to break out of the chains life puts on you is to put on a cool sari (くさり). A cool sari will remind you where you come from. Who your family is. And how beautiful you look. Cast off those chains and put on a cool sari!

sentences: 逃げないように鎖で繋いでいます。
They were tied with chains so they wouldn’t escape.

mnemonics.meaning: Pierce someone when you stab them with a mighty charge with your sword. Better yet, hit them with your lightning attack!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 突貫工事で犬小屋を建てました。
We built the doghouse by constructing it at top speed.

mnemonics.meaning: If it's in your nature to ridicule people, it will become a chronic problem. You can't change something that's so embedded in who you are, which is a shame, since you're a jerk.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は慢性胃腸炎を患っているんです。
I suffer from chronic gastroenteritis.

mnemonics.meaning: If you keep exhibiting the same actions and emotions and phrases eventually they're going to rot and sound cliched to everyone. You have to mix things up once in a while. You don't want to get stale, do you?!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out for ふ becoming ぷ.

sentences: 陳腐な台詞しか思い浮かびません。
I can’t think of anything but cliched lines.

mnemonics.meaning: A closed chain lets everyone know that a building or store is closing for good. It's got to lockout everyone so they won't try to get in anymore.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このプールは今月で閉鎖されます。
The pool is closed this month.

mnemonics.meaning: When you are given cool treatment it's called a cold reception or inhospitality. This sucks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は実力があるのにどうしてこんなに冷遇されているんですか。
If he’s so great then why did he get such a cold reception?

mnemonics.meaning: Those with leadership who want control will set out on missions of conquest and strive for world domination!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: わが校の野球部が、秋のリーグ戦を制覇しました。
Our school’s baseball club dominated the autumn league match.

mnemonics.meaning: The constant normal things in your life are also constant. If you normally always do them, then they're also probably a part of your everyday routine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このシステムで部屋の温度を恒常に保っています。
With this system we can consistently keep it at room temperature.

mnemonics.meaning: Who's a big help? That'll be Daisuke! Famous Daisukes include film director and screenwriter Itō Daisuke (伊藤 大輔), figure skater Takahashi Daisuke (髙橋 大輔), and actor and singer Namikawa Daisuke (浪川 大輔).
mnemonics.reading: This name uses the on'yomi for 大 and the nanori for 輔. You learned both of these with the kanji, so that should be a big help. Note: Historically, this name can be read たいふ or おおすけ, as is the case for Heian period poet 伊勢大輔, whose name can be read either いせのたいふ or いせのおおすけ. In modern contexts, you'll only need to know だいすけ though, not to worry!

sentences: その方の配偶者は大輔さんという方だと思います。
I believe that person's spouse is called Daisuke.
大輔はとても感銘を受けた。
Daisuke was deeply impressed.
大輔君の苗字は何か知ってる？
Do you know what Daisuke-kun's family name is?

mnemonics.meaning: If there is a cave in because it was lacking something that means there was a defect or a fault in there somewhere.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 消費者からこの商品の安全性の欠陥が指摘されています。
The safety defect in this product was identified by consumers.

mnemonics.meaning: If you encounter something difficult it's going to result in disaster. Especially if you're in a boat. Encountering really difficult water will result in a shipwreck! Ick!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 危うく遭難するところでした。
We narrowly missed having a disaster.

mnemonics.meaning: When a plant or an animal dies you have to discard it. You can't just keep it sitting around the house after death, that's weird.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: こないだの原稿は没になってしまった。
The manuscript was rejected the other day.
申し訳ありませんが、この案は一旦没にしてください。
I'm sorry, but I'm afraid you're going to have to discard this idea for now.
その歌手は、2015年12月1日没、とされているが、真相は定かではない。
The singer is said to have died on December 1, 2015, but the facts are not clear.

mnemonics.meaning: An embrace and a hug are pretty much the same thing. So you're still going to embrace and hug people!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 抱 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who gives the best hugs in the world? Harry Houdini (ほう)! He knows what it's like to be hugged too tightly because he's always in straight jackets. So his hugs are nice and gentle. Just the way you like them!

sentences: その映画の、主役の二人が甘い抱擁を交わすシーンがとても美しかったよ。
The scene in that movie where the two leading actors exchanged a sweet embrace was so beautiful.

mnemonics.meaning: It doesn't matter what kind of treatment you get on your encounter with new people because it's the encounter itself that's scary! Don't worry, people are just people. They shouldn't make you nervous.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 悲惨な交通事故に遭遇しました。
I encountered a tragic traffic accident.

mnemonics.meaning: I get ridiculed a lot, but it makes me have really strong endurance. If you get picked on a lot, just say, "I have patience and self control, and I can make it through this."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: おしっこを我慢するのは体に悪い。
Holding your pee is bad for your health.

mnemonics.meaning: The treatment of your boundary of your neighborhood is something you should be concerned about, because it's your environment and if you don't take care of it, who will?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自分の不幸を境遇のせいにするんじゃない。
You can’t blame your environment for your own unhappiness.

mnemonics.meaning: When a volcano erupts with fire it makes a really big eruption. You should probably start running.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 富士山が噴火したらどうなると思いますか。
What do you think would happen if Mt. Fuji erupted?

mnemonics.meaning: Constant examples that you use all the time end up becoming part of an established practice. You constantly use them so it just stays that way after a while.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うちの会社では、毎年恒例のクリスマス会があるんだよ。
It is an established practice at my company to have a Christmas party every year.

mnemonics.meaning: Ethics and reason together in a person make them have very strong ethics and morals.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ちゃんと職業倫理を守ってください。
Please abide by business ethics properly.

mnemonics.meaning: An exhibit of things in a row only happens at an exhibition. Everything will be neatly lined up on display for you there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたは、パン屋のむき出しの陳列についてどう思いますか。
What did you think of the bakery’s exposed exhibition?

mnemonics.meaning: You need to swell and stretch if you want to see any kind of expansion of your company. Growth can't happen without a little wiggle room.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 宇宙は膨張しています。
The universe is expanding.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 俺の一番好きなバイクは、スズキの隼です。
My favorite motorcycle is the Suzuki Falcon.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means tall.

If you try to say something to the Death Star, it would only admonish you. It was made to destroy planets, after all, so I don't know why you'd expect it to have anything nice to say. It just admonishes you about everything you've ever done wrong until you can't stop crying. Imagine being admonished by the Death Star. It's hovering above you, giant and round, just yelling at you about everything you've ever messed up. It's really awful being yelled at. But the Death Star doing it is particularly scary and embarrassing.
mnemonics.reading: Right now you're being admonished about living in a yurt (ゆ). The Death Star bellows, "What, am I too big and safe for you? I'm easy to move too, you know. You're a disgrace! You should be ashamed!" Imagine sitting in your yurt, the home you love, but you can still hear the admonishments from the Death Star in your ears. You feel... bad.

mnemonics.meaning: How many buildings have scooters? All of them! All buildings have at least one scooter. It could be out front, on the roof, in the basement. But all of them have scooters and someone who likes to ride them instead of using a car or a bike.
mnemonics.reading: All of these scooters have a specific sound they make as they burst out of the buildings: zuwee (ずい). Imagine the sound of the scooter's tiny engine: zuwee zuwee zu zu zuwee. All of them do this, which is why you hate them.

mnemonics.meaning: The old moon (the moon we had before the current moon) was actually just a huge barbarian floating in the sky. Just imagine a huge barbarian (whatever that means to you) floating in the sky, looking down. Some ancient people look up and wave at the old moon barbarian.
mnemonics.reading: At least, this is the kind of story you told your 子 (こ) when they asked you where the moon came from. "You see, my child, the old moon was not like the current moon. It was a giant barbarian in the sky, who would eat children that asked too many questions."

mnemonics.meaning: In your fingers are flowers which really suit you. But you throw them to the people waving to you from below, as you board your ship. The flowers fall, unneeded. You're embarking on a new life, a new journey. There will be more flowers where you're going. Picture yourself boarding the ship and letting the flowers slip from your fingers, into the crowd of people waving goodbye.
mnemonics.reading: You board a ship to とうきょう, bound for your new life, of course! Where else would you go at this point? I mean, come on. You've made it 53 levels since you embarked on your kanji journey with us. We know you by now. You want to be in とうきょう.

mnemonics.meaning: You weave gold and white patterns into this towel, turning it into brocade. It's beautiful, elegant, and worth way more than when it was just a plain towel. Imagine weaving this beautiful brocade fabric out of one of your old towels. Try to actually picture the gold and white patterns you want on there. If you're a crafter, actually do it!
mnemonics.reading: You want to keep your brocade fabrics safe, so you lock them away and seal them in with a niche key (にしき). It's niche because brocade is a very niche kind of thing. Imagine using your niche key to open this hidden brocade storage room. The key is gold and white and looks like brocade too!

mnemonics.meaning: If you're in Japan, the fish in your village are carp. You may know them as koi, too. Picture your village in Japan. There's a big, still pond full of bright and beautiful giant carp. You hear the village kids giggle as they feed them and their big round mouths pop out of the water.
mnemonics.reading: A carp is called a koi (こい) in Japanese. We've used that word before so I hope you know it by now. A koi is a koi, you know? Carp are koi and koi are carp. Blub blub.

mnemonics.meaning: Take the moon and wrap it in a bag and it will look just like a cell. It's a circle in a bigger circle. The moon is the nucleus. Yes! Science is happening! Picture the moon with a big bag circling it. Now look down at your biology homework on cells. They're identical!
mnemonics.reading: As you learn about cells you realize they're all over your home (ほう). Without ever noticing it, your home has been slowly filling with dead skin cells. And now that you know what they look like (the moon with a plastic wrap bag around it) you can see them everywhere. AHHH CLEAN ALL OF THESE CELLS OUT OF YOUR HOME!

mnemonics.meaning: Tsunami of conflict will cleanse and purify the lands of people, homes, and culture. Anything less than a tsunami of conflict would leave something behind. But this much conflict will cleanse the area of everything.
mnemonics.reading: The cleanse of your lands was caused by Jourm (じょう). Why did the slow farmhand bring an army to the village, and why is he yelling about, "The cleanse," while destroying everything? Jourm?! Weren't we friends? You thought Jourm was an ordinary, clumsy, ten foot tall farmhand. But he brought down a tsunami upon your village. And, he brought armed conflict too. This thing he calls "The cleanse" was actually something he had been planning for years. His use of a totally ordinary Viking mouth towel... his table made of foreheads... That tatami mat altar with the forehead wearing a top hat... Was he really a Viking pretending to be a simple farmhand just so he could bring his men inland to cleanse and purify your village? It's too late now. Jourm stands over your body. You are about to receive "The cleanse" too.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a drop of bear on this towel. A true commander can notice little things like this. Imagine a commander carefully looking over everything. They not only notice a drop of something on a towel, but they're able to identify that the drop is a small piece of liquid bear.
mnemonics.reading: You watch the commander in all his glory... going back and forth on a swing (すい). "Weeee!" says the commander.

mnemonics.meaning: If you say something the same way they say it in the capital, everyone in the whole country will be able to comprehend what you're trying to say. If you try to speak in your hometown's dialect no one will. But everyone can comprehend what you want if you use the capital's dialect to say it. Imagine the confused faces of the people in the countryside as you try to talk to them. Decide to say it the way it's said in the capital and see their faces light up as they comprehend what you're trying to say.
mnemonics.reading: Now that the townspeople finally comprehend what you were trying to say, they sell you the row (りょう) boat you were trying to buy. You were using the wrong word, but りょう is what they needed to hear to understand you, and now you can row your way back home. Picture yourself rowing away in your new row boat as the townspeople wave goodbye. They were much nicer once they comprehended what you were asking for. Maybe you'll row your way back here someday.

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers are growing out of the ground and over your pet pig's forehead and it's causing the poor thing to live in total darkness. The flowers are hanging down over its eyes and won't let any light in at all. And some of the flowers seem to be growing directly out of the pig's forehead too. The pig has just been wandering and bumping into things all day because of it. Imagine being a pig with flowers hanging down off your forehead and into your eyes so that darkness was all you knew. It's very sad, actually.
mnemonics.reading: To end the darkness you mow (もう) the flowers. You have to drive your lawnmower over its head too, because they're growing out of its forehead too. They'll grow back soon though and cover your pig's world in darkness once again and you'll have to do it all over again. Imagine mowing the darkness away. Be careful! If you mow the pig's eyes, the darkness will last forever!

mnemonics.meaning: The sun is rising and there is a net covering someone, who's being forced to watch as dawn appears. They've never seen dawn before, and they didn't want to, but you're making them. Picture someone tied down in a net as dawn breaks.
mnemonics.reading: The someone who saw dawn for the first time goes on to become sumo wrestling champ Akebono Taro (あけぼの). He always gazes at the sunrise at dawn before he wrestles and it fills him with strength. Look at Akebono looking at you as you look at dawn breaking.

mnemonics.meaning: If you get a big hair stuck in your private soul it will be a disaster! Have you ever gotten a hair in your eye or your mouth that you just couldn't get out? You cough, your eyes water, it's awful! You can't focus on anything until it's gone. Now imagine if a big 'ol hair got stuck in your own private soul!!! Disaster!!! This disaster is ruining your life. You can't eat, sleep, all you can do is panic trying to get the hair out.
mnemonics.reading: This disaster is so huge that even Santa-san (さん) left his vacation in Zanzibar (ざん) to come tell you you're on the naughty list for being such a disaster person. WHAT?! Even you Santa-san? Santa-san has forsaken you. Your life is a wreck. This is a total disaster just because of one big hair.

mnemonics.meaning: When what you're writing is as tall as the grains growing outside, you know you're done with your first draft. Some teachers want papers to be a certain number of words or pages, but that's silly. You should measure your draft in grains! Imagine holding your draft up outside in a field of grains. You're a couple leaves short. Time to get back to the drawing board.
mnemonics.reading: Who asked you to write such a tall draft in the first place? Emperor こういち, who wants you to draft up the world's largest book about how great of an emperor he is. Now こういち is out there measuring your draft against the tall grain plants. You better hope it's long enough, because if it isn't, Emperor こういち's probably going to execute you.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can find the door in winter shaped like a mouth it will enlighten you. Imagine searching for this special door in the cold wind and snow of winter. The search for enlightenment always has something to do with suffering and searching on your own like this.
mnemonics.reading: The door enlightened you by opening up and revealing the cake (けい) in its door-mouth. "Cake is the key to enlightenment, my child. Now eat it from my mouth." All you need to do to attain enlightenment is to eat this cake... out of this mouth. Eh. Maybe enlightenment isn't worth it.

mnemonics.meaning: Press your fingers in someone's skin to expose what's underneath. This is pretty gross, but sometimes it's more important that you expose the cause of the problem, than avoiding something uncomfortable. Close your eyes. Picture someone's arm. Now touch their skin with your fingers and peel it back to expose the muscles and bones underneath.
mnemonics.reading: You expose a small hole under their skin and heat (ひ) comes pouring out. Aha! You knew there was something wrong under here. Apparently there's something under this person's skin that's exuding way too much heat. Imagine the heat steaming out, like it's coming out of a teapot, not out of somebody's arm skin.

mnemonics.meaning: A drunkard crosses thread across special spikes to separate the fibers. The best way to separate the fibers of thread is to get a drunkard to do it. If you're too precise it will just snap. You gotta be loose with it! Just flop them onto the spikes and the fibers will come apart by themselves! Imagine a drunkard crossing threads onto spikes and pulling the tiny fibers free. You don't think you could do that. Maybe if you got drunk too...
mnemonics.reading: You stare at the fibers easily coming apart when you realize that this drunkard seems to have a few extra legs... and hair and a tail? This isn't just a drunk guy, it's a centaur (せん). Maybe separating fibers is really a centaur trick, and that's why normal people can't do it... Watch the centaur cross the fibers and separate them with his spikes. How strange.

mnemonics.meaning: If you loiter around a surplus of anything, you need to be gentle and touch everything gently.  Unfortunately it's not specific as to what kind of surplus you're loitering around, so you'll need to imagine a surplus of something memorable to you. Then, just imagine loitering around there, being really gentle with everything.
mnemonics.reading: You have to be gentle and handle these things gently because they belong to Jo-Anne (じょ). You're loitering around her surplus of (whatever you decided to imagine). Imagine Jo-Anne coming back to her surplus, then asking you if you were gentle with the goods. You were, you treated everything very gently.

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers that are thought to be little tents sent from heaven are hollyhocks. They're shaped almost like little teepees and would make the perfect tent for a faerie or a little yokai!  Picture a tiny yokai using a hollyhock as a tent. Aww cute!
mnemonics.reading: Hollyhocks are mostly あおい (blue) because they copy the color of the heavens, where they came from. Imagine yourself in a field of hollyhocks and the あおい of them match the あおい of the heavens! It's like you're standing on a giant flower filled mirror of the sky.

mnemonics.meaning: While the moon is out, a gladiator is riding a horse, yelling about inflation. No one would listen to him during the day, so he waited for the moon to rise so he could complain about prices doing the same. Picture the gladiator riding his horse in the light of the moon yelling, "Do you have any idea how important it is to increase the average pay rate to account for inflation? All of us gladiators are going to be unable to pay the bills soon because inflation isn't being taken into account! You'll suffer too! Listen to me!"
mnemonics.reading: Inflation rises the most in とうきょう, and the gladiator knows that because that's where most of them live and fight (and die). Imagine if you were in this gladiator's place. In five years, you wouldn't be able to afford to eat thanks to the bosses in とうきょう refusing to adjust for inflation. Back in my day, onigiri only cost FIFteen yen!

mnemonics.meaning: You use your fingers to take down the old flag and install a new one. Flags get old, just like computers and furniture and people. So when one gets too old, you have to get on up there and install a new one in its place. Imagine reaching out and grabbing onto the old flag with your fingers. Feel the dirty grime and little holes it's gotten. Now install something new!
mnemonics.reading: You've decided to install a suit (す) where the old flag used to be. I mean, a suit is probably more durable than a flag, am I right? This way you won't have to install flags as often. Picture a newly installed suit flying in the air on a pole.

mnemonics.meaning: You cut the flowers off the grain with your knife. The flowers that fall off are jasmine flowers. It's weird that jasmine flowers are growing out of your grain, but that's why you're cutting them off.
mnemonics.reading: The jasmine is growing out of everything, not just grain! It's also growing out of the reeds (り)! You have a farm that grows grain and reeds. Jasmine flowers are growing out of both of those things, ruining your crops! Perhaps you should become a jasmine tea farmer instead...

mnemonics.meaning: The thread that goes through Korea is the latitude line splitting up North and South Korea. Why thread? Back in the old days globes were sewn together with cloth and thread, so there was a literal thread dividing the Koreas! Or you can just picture an actual, super long piece of thread going around the entire globe. That works too.
mnemonics.reading: The only way you can see this latitude line is to ride an eagle (い) over it. The line isn't visible from a car, you're too close, and a plane is too high. You have to see it from an eagle's point of view. Imagine being an eagle yourself, flying around the entire globe, following the latitude line that splits Korea down the middle.

mnemonics.meaning: The melon radical and the melon kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo! Make sure you remember this radical means melon and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
mnemonics.reading: What's the best use for a melon? Not eating it, but running over it in your car (か)! Melons make a nice big splat sound when you drive over them, and that's what you plan to do to every melon you see. Imagine hitting the gas pedal in your car as you head for a big melon. Watch it burst into a million pieces as your car makes contact, hurling melon bits all over your windshield. It's a melon firework!

mnemonics.meaning: Tigers and wolverines have one big thing in common and it's that the government likes to oppress them. It doesn't matter if you're the animal or a mutant X-Men hybrid. The government will go out of its way to oppress you if you are one.  Imagine being a tiger or a wolverine or a tiger-wolverine and being oppressed by the government just because you're different. Imagine being stuck in a cage. Not being allowed to vote. It's awful!
mnemonics.reading: Tiger and wolverine people are so oppressed that the only thing they're allowed to amuse themselves with is Gak (ぎゃく). You know, that weird goo they made us play with when we were kids? Well that's not so fun when it's all you have. Imagine being a tiger/wolverine girl and being so oppressed that you can only sit in a cage, playing with goopy Gak all day. This blows...

mnemonics.meaning: A cross carrying drunkard wants you to go to a rice paddy together so you can receive something from them. You really don't want to receive whatever it is this drunkard wants to give you, and it's even sketchier that they want you to go to a rice paddy together to do it.
mnemonics.reading: Against your better judgement, you decided to go and receive the thing. You close your eyes, hold out your hands, and feel a silky, light tie (たい) being placed in them. The tie looks harmless enough, but you still receive it skeptically. The drunkard is just holding up his cross and smiling at you. Hmm.

mnemonics.meaning: A boat owned by a Yoga King needs to be able to let him keep doing his exercises while he's on it. That's why his boat is a rowboat, so he can work on his yoga arms as he gets around. Picture the Yoga King rowing a rowboat. Maybe he's using his legs. Maybe he's using his butt? You don't know. Yoga people are super flexible, he could be using anything to move this rowboat.
mnemonics.reading: As he rows the rowboat with his butt, you see the Yoga King eating something with his toes. They're tater tots (てい). Tater tots are the perfect snack for a rowboat. They're small, delicious, and they float if you drop them in the water. Go rent a rowboat and try eating tater tots in it. For fun, throw a bunch of them in the water and watch them float. Maybe you'll catch a fish!

mnemonics.meaning: This is a boat, but it's missing some pieces. That's because it's really rusty, so parts are falling off of it and it looks rust colored. In ancient Chinese literature, this rusty red color represented sincerity, and you'll often see this kanji take that meaning in jukugo words.  Picture this broken, rust colored boat. It's a reddish-brown color and it's definitely missing some important pieces.
mnemonics.reading: The rust colored boat has inspired you, so you sit down next to it in the sun and tan (たん). You want to be the exact same rust color as the boat, and in a few hours you're sure you'll match. Watch your skin slowly change as you tan to match the rust colored boat. Feel your skin in the sun. This may not be good for your health, but it's great for fashion!

mnemonics.meaning: The threads a criminal wears will always be scarlet. Scarlet is the color of freshly spilt blood, which is why bad guys wear it so much. Picture a person wearing all scarlet all the time. Don't they give you a criminal-y vibe?
mnemonics.reading: This scarlet color holds a lot of heat (ひ). Scarlet is the color of fire, and it has the heat of fire too. Picture a criminal, covered in this scarlet thread, heat radiating off of him.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a turkey on ice and it will only get semi frozen. You add more ice, and it stays the same. Only some of it will freeze. What the heck! Imagine covering a turkey in ice and every time you check it, it's only semi frozen. It doesn't matter what you do, it just refuses to freeze all the way through.
mnemonics.reading: Finally you realize it will only semi freeze because it's June (じゅん)! It's too hot out for your turkey to freeze all the way. The ice keeps melting off the top and semi thawing it! The lesson is to never try to freeze something in June. If you do it will only semi freeze.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to have a quaint cottage wedding, so you have to go to the cottage wedding shop to get everything you need. This shop is the only place you can buy everything you need. It's not like you can make a cottage from scratch! Picture yourself walking into the cottage wedding shop. Look at all the different cottages you get to choose from. And there's wedding cake too?! This shop has everything!
mnemonics.reading: You're browsing everything in the shop when a garden hoe (ほ) catches your eye. Yes. This will make your cottage wedding the absolute best one. The hoe will give you away at your wedding. Imagine walking around the shop and then falling in love with a hoe with pretty tassels and flowers attached to it. Yes, it's only for decoration, but you're going to buy and use it during your cottage wedding.

mnemonics.meaning: A dirt nurse is someone who nurses dirt. When nursed, dirt becomes soil. Soil generally has more nutrients in it. It makes sense for dirt that's been nursed to become soil.
mnemonics.reading: Soil is a thing Jourm (じょう) the huge farmhand works on improving. If he makes the soil better, the farm will yield more crops. Imagine Jourm working with soil (not dirt!). Improving it by mixing in various ingredients. The soil this year is particularly lush, for some reason...

mnemonics.meaning: When a horse sees a spider it will start running at a speed no one ever thought a horse could go! Horses are super afraid of spiders, you see, so if they see one, they'll bolt and reach top speed! That's actually the only way to get a horse to run that fast.  Imagine the eyes of a horse seeing a spider and then running at top speed to get the heck away from it.
mnemonics.reading: Once people realize that they can increase the speed of their horses, soon (しゅん) everyone will be taking spiders with them to scare their horses into running faster. I say soon because it hasn't quite caught on yet. But if you help to spread the word it can happen even sooner. Soon the world will be filled with horses running at full speed all thanks to the spider increase of the 2000s! Soon we will be in the future of top speeds!

mnemonics.meaning: There's so much grain in your mouth you need to use a knife to remove it. Only when there is a surplus can you put that much grain in your mouth. Imagine seeing so much grain that you can stuff your mouth so full you can't swallow or spit it out. You have to use a knife to remove it. After you get all the grain out, comment on the surplus of grain.
mnemonics.reading: The surplus is thanks to the hard work of folks like Jourm (じょう) the big farmhand. He worked hard to make sure there was a surplus of grain this year. Remember how Jourm made the soil better? Perhaps this is some of that work paying off. Thanks to that and everything else, there is a great surplus.

mnemonics.meaning: The roof flowers see everything. But, they only see. That is because they learned the art of tolerance. These roof flowers only see because they do not judge. They accept everything. We humans can learn a thing or two about tolerance from these roof flowers.
mnemonics.reading: Tolerance is one thing that Genghis Khan (かん) had a surprising amount of. You wouldn't expect it, but he actually allowed many types of cultures, religions, and peoples to exist under his reign. The Mongols had an exceptional amount of tolerance for the time.

mnemonics.meaning: If you can't wait to oppress people when you grow up, you're the kind of person who's prone to inflicting abuse on other people. You should try to correct that right away.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 虐待を受けた子供は、自己評価が非常に低くなることが多い。
Many children who were abused have extremely lowered self esteem.

mnemonics.meaning: Line up house counters and you'll see that all the houses you've counted are the same across the board. It also turns them into a row of houses.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 軒 and 並 that you've already learned, so you should be able to read this word too.

sentences: IT関連の株価が軒並み下落しました。
IT-related stock prices fell across the board.

mnemonics.meaning: The fee you charge to produce your draft is called an advance for manuscript. Also known as copy money.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: わずかですが、稿料をもらいました。
It wasn’t much, but I got an advance for the manuscript.

mnemonics.meaning: Expose what you want to expose by making an announcement. Then show the world!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 露 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You're making the announcement from a row (ろう) boat. People will pay more attention when you're in a row boat because it's kind of weird. Especially since you're in a row boat on a stage.

sentences: 誕生日会で、手品を披露しました。
Sleight of hand was performed at the birthday party.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have all the time in the world you can do whatever you want at any time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 新しい情報が入れば、随時ご連絡致します。
If new information comes in, I'll contact you at any time.

mnemonics.meaning: To oppress people and then kill them is an atrocity. It's also called a massive killing because that's what you're actually doing. And you're awful, why would you ever do that?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 南京大虐殺が捏造だったというなら、その証拠を説明してください。
If you say the Nanking Massacre is a fabrication, please explain the evidence.

mnemonics.meaning: In reality, carp are usually black carp. The colored ones aren't as common, people just wish they were.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 真鯉の刺青を背中に彫りました。
I got a black carp tattoo done on my back.

mnemonics.meaning: When you board a plane or a car to take a ride it's called boarding or embarkation. You have to get on the right way or you can't ride.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but since that was quite a few levels ago, here's a mnemonic just in case: You know one person who always has a hard time boarding a plane, and it's Jourm (じょう), the farmhand. Jourm is what you'd call a very big boy. He doesn't fit in the tube thing you normally walk through when boarding a plane, so he has to climb up the side. It's a whole thing.

sentences: ご搭乗の際は、足元にお気をつけください。
Please watch your feet while boarding.

mnemonics.meaning: To compete in a rowboat is to take part in a boat race, also known as a regatta. Who are you gonna bet on?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 競艇で大儲けしました。
I made a killing in the boat race.

mnemonics.meaning: The inflation of boiling water means that bubbles are being inflated in there and bubbling to the top. This is called boiling, or if it's happening in a person it's called seething.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: スープが沸騰してグツグツいってますよ。
The soup was boiling and simmering.

mnemonics.meaning: People who have the same cells as you are your brethren, they're your brothers!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お前は同胞を裏切るつもりか。
Do you intend to betray your brethren?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 高級錦織で作られた着物を買いました。
I bought a kimono made from luxury brocade.

mnemonics.meaning: You nail a board to the wall of a house you're selling and publish in the listing that it was built in with the house! No one will know you just put it there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今度の機種には、どんな新機能が搭載されるんでしょうか。
What kinds of features are built in to this model?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 鯉に餌をあげないでください。
Please do not feed the carp.

mnemonics.meaning: Thin cells are what make up our bodies. They're still cells but they can also be called biological cells.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は、人工多能性幹細胞(iPS細胞)の研究をしています。
I study induced pluripotent stem cells (iPS cells).

mnemonics.meaning: When you cleanse water it becomes clean water that you can drink.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 三十万円の浄水器を売りつけられそうになりました。
I almost had a three hundred thousand yen water filter sold to me.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin of your collar is your collar! And the nape of the neck because that's where collars go.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 襟元にファンデーションがついていますよ。
There’s foundation on your collar.

mnemonics.meaning: A brocade carp is a fancy way of saying it's a carp that has a lot of pretty colors on it. It's a colored carp or a colored koi.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 庭の池に錦鯉を放ちました。
I released the colored carp into the garden pond.

mnemonics.meaning: The commander of the whole army is just called " the commander." No one knows his real name and everyone is too afraid to ask.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それは、ヒトラー総帥の指令だったのです。
That was Fuhrer Hitler’s order.

mnemonics.meaning: The remainder of oppression is cruelty. Even when you're done oppressing people the brutality you caused will linger in their minds and hearts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは非常に残虐な犯行です。
This is an extremely brutal crime.

mnemonics.meaning: Failure that causes disaster is a crushing failure and you were utterly beaten by your opponent.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本はワールドカップで惨敗してしまった。
Japan suffered a crushing failure at the World Cup.

mnemonics.meaning: Barbarians have melons too, but they're long and funny looking. Wait, those aren't melons, they're cucumbers! Barbarians must have mixed them up.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Cucumbers have cute ribs (きゅうり)! I mean just look at them. Cute little green ribs. Adorable!

sentences: たまに胡瓜の糠漬けが無性に食べたくなるんだ。
Occasionally, I’ll want to eat pickled cucumbers so badly.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 春の曙の空はいくら見ても見飽きません。
No matter how many times I see dawn in the spring sky, I don’t get tired of it.

mnemonics.meaning: A withered tree is a dead tree and it's got really dry wood. Perfect for a campfire!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes you'll see it spelled 枯木 without the kana too. Keep your eyes open for it!

sentences: 枯れ木に花を咲かせましょう。
Let’s make the dead tree bloom.

mnemonics.meaning: Slender and thin things are very delicate and dainty. They're easily broken, so you have to be careful.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 上品で繊細な味の日本食が好きです。
I like the elegant and subtle flavors of Japanese food.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well the science of skin is dermatology!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は皮膚科に通院しています。
I’m going to a dermatologist.

mnemonics.meaning: If you are trying to manage latitudes you're really trying to manage the details of something. Managing latitudes is just a fancy way of saying it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は、これまでの経緯を静かに語りだした。
He quietly told us about how it all started.

mnemonics.meaning: If you don't want your thoughts to turn rust colored, you need to be diligent and studying, learning, and experiencing new things. Without diligence your brain and all your thoughts will get old, and stale, turning a rusty, gross color.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 熟練の染師が、一つ一つ丹念に染め上げました。
The skilled dyeing master diligently finished dyeing each one.

mnemonics.meaning: Disaster in action means the disaster is still happening. Get outta there!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 惨事を招くことは避けたい。
I want to avoid causing a disaster.

mnemonics.meaning: A sad disaster is one that's especially disastrous and tragic. It's the worst kind you can imagine.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 残された加害者の家族の末路は、悲惨なものだった。
The assailant’s remaining family member’s last days were tragic.

mnemonics.meaning: Disastrous conditions in the weather lead to you seeing a disastrous scene. Just don't look outside and you won't see the horrible stuff out your window right now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 東北大震災の惨状を忘れることができません。
I can’t forget the disastrous scene of the Great Tohoku Earthquake.

mnemonics.meaning: When you are enlightened enough you'll need to make your departure from this world into enlightenment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最近は、自己啓発本ばかり読んでいます。
Lately I’ve only been reading self-improvement books.

mnemonics.meaning: Enlighten the darkness of people's minds with instruction and they'll reach enlightenment like you did!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我々が大衆を啓蒙するのです。
We enlighten the general public.

mnemonics.meaning: All that comes out of a writing brush is essays. You can't paint or doodle, you have to write with it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 随筆の書き方を教えてください。
Please teach me how to write essays.

mnemonics.meaning: All places are everywhere.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この寿司屋には、店の随所に、日本の美を感じさせるインテリアが飾られています。
You can feel the beauty of Japan everywhere in this sushi restaurant from the way the interior is decorated.

mnemonics.meaning: If you surpass your surplus then you have lots of excess stuff.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 過剰包装は紙の無駄です。
Over wrapping is a waste of paper.

meanings: woman of the red light district

mnemonics.meaning: A mysterious person is really really good at what they do. So good that they aren't exactly sure what is it they do, but you know they're definitely an expert at whatever it is.
mnemonics.reading: This reading for this word is mysteriously an exception (sorry). So here's a mnemonic to help: If you're such an expert you should be able to tell what anything is if someone asks you. Even this crow toe (くろうと). Crow toes are pretty hard to recognize, unless you're a professional crow guy. But I guess you are, huh?

sentences: 水商売の玄人と素人を見分けるのが趣味です。
My hobby is to try to differentiate between professionals and amateurs in the "water trade."

mnemonics.meaning: A speed horse is a fast horse, and a fine horse. This word isn't very common, but it does come up in horse racing contexts, and creative writing.
mnemonics.reading: You learned the reading for 駿 with the kanji, but 馬 has two possible readings in this word, and you only learned ば. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember め: This fast horse is so fast that all you can see as it speeds past are the whites of its 目 (め). Of the two readings, しゅんめ is the more common.

sentences: 王は、自慢の駿馬に乗って姿を現した。
The king showed up riding his prized fast horse.
その大名には、数々の駿馬が献じられた。
The daimyo was presented with a number of fine horses.
とても良い毛並みの駿馬を一億円で落札した。
She made a successful bid of 100 million yen for a fine horse with a very good coat.

mnemonics.meaning: The fat on an animal's body is called fatty meat. Some people really like to eat it and others really like to hate it.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 脂 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Mmm, all that fatty meat. Think about fatty meat on your own body. If you have a lot of fatty meat, then you need a way to support said fatty meat. To do that, you would use a bra (あぶら).

sentences: お肉の脂身って苦手なんですよね。
I don’t like the fatty meat.

mnemonics.meaning: The fiber you use to maintain your own health is the fiber you eat!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎日サラダを食べて、ちゃんと食物繊維を摂るようにしています。
I eat a salad everyday and consume the perfect amount of dietary fiber.

mnemonics.meaning: Even if you follow all the people you've ever met, you're still following them. Once a follower, always a follower.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 追 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: They get you to follow them by yelling TWEET (つい)! Birds tend to follow each other, and something about hearing them tweeting at you makes you feel like you have to follow them.

sentences: この会社は、圧倒的な強さで、他社の追随を許しませんでした。
This company is unrivaled by other companies with its overwhelming strength.

mnemonics.meaning: The commander's origin was as the general of the army. He stepped down, but that's where he started. Maybe he's working the system backwards...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これが、あの有名な最高司令官のマッカ—サ—元帥です。
That’s famous supreme commander, General MacArthur.

mnemonics.meaning: If you go gently you're actually going slowly. You can't be gentle if you don't move slowly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 住宅地や学校の近くでは、徐行で運転してください。
Please drive slowly near residential districts and schools.

mnemonics.meaning: If you do it gently gently then you're only doing it gradually. You have to go slowly if you want to be as gentle as possible.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

sentences: 二学期に入って、徐々に成績が上がり始めました。
Second semester came and my grade slowly started to rise.

mnemonics.meaning: The main shop is the main shop or the head office.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ベビー用品は、いつも赤ちゃん本舗で買います。
I always buy baby things at the main baby shop.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 徳川氏の家紋といえば、「三つ葉葵」が一番有名だ。
Speaking of the Tokugawa family crest, the "three hollyhock leaves" is the most famous.

mnemonics.meaning: Humbly receive something and you'll be humbly receiving it. Or humbly eating it if they gave you food and not a puppy or something inedible. It can also mean humbly having. The theme here is humility! This is usually formal when written in kanji and used together with a verb like する. It can also be used alone to make very casual requests. In casual requests, it's still written in kanji in novels and other creative writing, but is generally written in hiragana anywhere else.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just watch out because たい becomes だい here.

sentences: 先ほど、先方からお電話を頂戴しました。
We received a call from the client a little while ago.
では、遠慮なく頂戴します。
Well then, I shall eat it gratefully, without hesitation.
ママのこの指輪、大きくなったら私に頂戴ね。
Mom, let me have this ring when I grow up, won't you?

mnemonics.meaning: Degrees of latitude are still called latitude.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: GPSで経度や緯度が検索できます。
I can look up the latitude and longitude on my GPS.

mnemonics.meaning: Lotus root is lotus root.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 蓮根と人参のキンピラを作りました。
I made kinpira with lotus root and carrot.

mnemonics.meaning: Your original draft is called a manuscript.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 原稿に珈琲を零してしまいました。
I spilled coffee on the manuscript.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Bite into a melon and what do you taste? Uni reese's pieces (うり)! Did you know that? The next time you eat a melon see if you can taste the difference!

sentences: これは瓜の漬物です。
This is pickled melon.

mnemonics.meaning: What do a warship and a rowboat have in common? In wartime they're both considered military vessels.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 海軍の艦艇の乗組員が不足しています。
The crew of the navy’s war fleet is lacking.

mnemonics.meaning: If you face a lot of disasters in your life you're going to be really miserable. It's a shame, but it's hard to be anything but sad when your life is full of disastrous stuff.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You'll be really miserable if you find out you're going to have a really 短い (みじ) life.

sentences: そんなことを言われて、人がどれだけ惨めな気持ちになるのか分かる？
You say something like that, but do you understand how miserable people feel?

mnemonics.meaning: In the old times Japan thought one country was full of nothing but darkness. That country was Mongolia. It was mostly because when the Mongolians invaded it was always night time. So everyone just started thinking they were used to the darkness because they lived in it all the time back home.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この絵には、蒙古襲来の時の様子が描かれています。
This picture depicts the state at the time of the Mongolian invasion.

mnemonics.meaning: North latitude is north latitude or northern latitude.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 江ノ島とギリシャのクレタ島の北緯は同じです。
Enoshima and Greece’s Crete island are on the same northern latitude.

mnemonics.meaning: You end up writing your rough draft on some grass leaves because you forgot your notes. This grass will serve as your notes now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: スピーチの草稿を作成しています。
I’m writing up a draft of the speech.

mnemonics.meaning: A bed just for seedlings is called a nursery. It's where all the little seedling grow before they're sold or replanted outside.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は夫と苗床を作りました。
I made a nursery with my husband today.

mnemonics.meaning: A latitude line can also be called a parallel.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 緯度0度の緯線のことを、赤道と呼びます。
The 0 degree parallel is called the equator.

mnemonics.meaning: A shop's attire is what's around it. A good shop wears pavement around its bottom so that people can get into it easily from the road or the sidewalk.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この道路はまだ舗装されていない。
This highway still hasn’t been paved.

mnemonics.meaning: Pure cleansed things are pure and clean.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 真に清浄な心を持った人間などいるのでしょうか。
Do you think there are people with absolutely pure hearts?

mnemonics.meaning: Land where all the people have been cleansed and purified is the Pure Land of Buddhism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そこはまさに極楽浄土のような所だった。
That place is exactly like Amitabha’s Pure Land.

mnemonics.meaning: Purify water to change it from being dirty. This is called purification. It's important to purify water before you drink it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は、放射能汚染水を浄化する施設を設計しています。
I’m designing a facility to purify radioactive water.

mnemonics.meaning: What's the city of flat soil? Pyongyang in North Korea. Which is pretty misleading, it's got more than a bunch of flat dirt, but back in the old days before the illustrious Kim Jong line built it up, that's all that was there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It can also be pronounced the way we say it in English sometimes too. That's ピョンヤン, if you're wondering, and these kanji are used for it too.

sentences: 平壌で英語を教えていたことがあります。
I taught English in Pyongyang.

mnemonics.meaning: If there is only semi criticism on a law ratification is still possible. It's only if everyone criticizes it that it won't be ratified.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 新戦略兵器削減条約の批准を最優先課題としています。
The ratification of New START is a maximum priority issue.

mnemonics.meaning: A scarlet colored carp is called a red carp and sometimes a golden carp because sometimes people don't understand colors.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a combination of on'yomi and kun'yomi. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.

sentences: ニシキゴイは緋鯉をもとに改良されたものです。
The colored carp was an improvement on the red and golden carp.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have a surplus surplus it's a little redundant and you end up having a surplus of surpluses!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 余剰資金で株を買いました。
I bought stock with surplus funds.

mnemonics.meaning: What indicates that you've been enlightened enough to reach enlightenment? A revelation! That's the only way you can know you've been enlightened enough.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それはまるで神の啓示のようだった。
That’s just like divine revelation.

mnemonics.meaning: Jasmine child is one way to write the girl's name Riko. Imagine fashioning a child out of jasmine, and calling her Riko. Examples of people named Riko include pop star and singer Fukumoto Riko (福本 莉子) and idol and actress Nakayama Riko (中山 莉子).
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading for 莉 with the kanji, and I bet you're very familiar with this reading for 子 by now. A lot of Japanese girls' names that end in 子, too.

sentences: 今度、莉子ちゃんと韓国旅行に行く予定なんだよね。
I'm planning to go on a trip to Korea with Riko-chan.
莉子って、ちょっとぶりっ子じゃない？
Riko puts on a bit of a good girl act, doesn't she?
うちの莉子が、ご迷惑をおかけしました。
I'm sorry for the trouble our Riko has caused you.

mnemonics.meaning: If you only comprehend one guy, make that guy Ryoichiro.
mnemonics.reading: You learned all the readings in this name with the kanji. What could be easier to comprehend?

sentences: 諒一郎って、あだ名とかあるの？
Ryoichiro, do you have a nickname?
諒一郎君と付き合うことになったんだ。
I've started going out with Ryoichiro-kun.
諒一郎は今、外出中です。
Ryoichiro is out right now.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 巻く means "to roll?" Well the thing you roll up around your collar is a scarf!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ピンクの襟巻きを巻いているのが私の妹です。
The girl wrapped in the pink scarf is my little sister.

mnemonics.meaning: A seedling tree is still a seedling.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この盆栽は苗木から育てたんです。
I raised this bonsai from a seedling.

mnemonics.meaning: If you purify your self you are performing self purification.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この事件が業界の自浄を促すだろう。
This incident will promote the self-purification of the industry.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: おかげ様で自分の舗を構えることができました。
Thanks to you I was able to set up my own shop.

mnemonics.meaning: A shop shop is still a shop.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 空港の近くにレンタカーの店舗はありますか？
Is there a rental car shop near the airport?

mnemonics.meaning: When barbarians sit they only sit cross legged. Sitting on your feet hurts and they don't care how they look, so they're going to be comfortable and cross their legs.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: If you're sitting cross legged lots of people will think you're a grouch (あぐら). Back in the day sitting like this was thought to be really manly, and if you were a woman who did it they'd call you a grouch too.

sentences: こんなところで胡座をかいてないで、さっさと仕事にとりかかりなさい。
Don’t sit cross legged here, start your work quickly.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 皮膚 is "skin?" Well when your skin is sick, you have a skin disease. You should probably go to a dermatologist right away.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 息子は皮膚病を患っています。
My son suffers from a skin disease.

mnemonics.meaning: Soil soil is still soil.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 土壌が悪い時は育てられない。
You can’t make a tree grow in bad soil.

mnemonics.meaning: South latitude is south latitude or southern latitude.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 理論上は、南緯45度が南極点から赤道までの距離の中間地点であるとされる。
Theoretically, 45 degrees south is considered to be middle point between the South Pole and the equator.

mnemonics.meaning: The child of a cell is a spore. They're just as tiny and they're floating all around you right now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: キノコの胞子はとても小さいので、肉眼で形は分かりません。
Because mushroom spores are so small, their appearance can’t be understood with the naked eye.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw your draft at people to post it on their Facebook wall! Wait, that's not how it works? Hush, yes it does, just throw it harder.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: フェイスブックに犬の写真を投稿しました。
I posted pictures of my dog to Facebook.

mnemonics.meaning: Tall inflation of prices means that there was a sudden price jump and it's waaaay more expensive than it used to be.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして株価がこんなに高騰しているんだ。
Why do stock prices suddenly jump like this?

mnemonics.meaning: Sudden inflation results in a sudden rise of prices. They all jump up together.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ドルが再び急騰しています。
The dollar suddenly rose again.

mnemonics.meaning: Violent inflation causes a sudden rise in prices. It sucks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 住宅価格が暴騰している。
House prices are skyrocketing.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means summit and this word means summit, peak, top and crown, most often in reference to mountains.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You should already know this reading from when you learned 頂く. If you can remember that, you can remember this too!

sentences: 日曜日の早朝、アキラは富士山の頂を目指して、出発した。
Early Sunday morning, Akira set off for the summit of Mt. Fuji.
ピンク色のネコの一族は、山奥や山の頂に住んでいる。
The pink cat clan lives deep in the mountains and on mountain tops.
目を覚ますと、眼前には険しい頂きがそびえ立ち、その頂きの上には仙人が立っていた。
When I woke up, I saw a rugged peak in front of me, and a hermit standing on top of it.

mnemonics.meaning: The commander that unites the world is one with supreme command. He's better than all the other commanders who couldn't bring everyone together and now he rules over everyone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日は学校で、天皇の統帥権について学びました。
Today at school we learned about the supreme command authority of the Emperor of Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: Surplus of surplus money is still a surplus. There's just too much money everywhere!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 会社の利益剰余金を資本金に振替えるつもりです。
We intend to transfer the company’s earned surplus into capital.

mnemonics.meaning: Fibers you join together to make more, stronger fibers, they turn into synthetic fibers. Note that this is an abbreviation of the specialist term 合成繊維, and it mostly comes up in industrial contexts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 原油安やナフサ安を受けて、合繊の価格も下落しています。
We receive cheap crude oil and cheap naphtha and the price of synthetic fibers is also falling.

mnemonics.meaning: Fibers that have been changed from other materials are synthetic fibers. They aren't natural because they were something else once. Like plastic, or kittens. Note that this is an abbreviation of the specialist term 化学繊維, and it mostly comes up in industrial contexts.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 掃除には、化繊箒を使っています。
I use a synthetic fiber broom for sweeping.

mnemonics.meaning: Who admonishes and teaches you? A Teacher. Probably not the nicest one though...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの教諭、昔の教え子と結婚したらしいよ。
Apparently that teacher married a former student they had a while ago.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means admonish, so the verb version is to admonish or to warn.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Your mom started to admonish you so you instantly sat (さと) down. Maybe if she sees you sat down right in front of her, looking guilty and feeling remorseful, she won't yell as hard.

sentences: うちの父は俺のことを叱るけど、本当は諭すのが正解だと思う。
Even though he scolds me, my father thinks admonishing is the solution.
