mnemonics.meaning: You already learned the word 沸く which means "to boil" or "to grow hot" but this is when you are the one heating the water. It still means to boil or to heat. But remember that you're the one who is doing the heating.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 沸く, so you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: お風呂を沸かしておきましたよ。
I ran the bath for you.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned the word 挟む which means "to put between." Well this is when something is between two things and you're not putting it there. It's just kinda doing it by itself. It means to get between or to be caught in.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 挟む, so you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: アスパラガスが歯に挟まっています。
You have asparagus caught in your teeth.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means install, so the verb version is to install or to fix.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 今度、この機械を工場に据えようと思っているんだ。
I think I’m going to have the machine fixed by the factory this time.

mnemonics.meaning: It doesn't matter how big your tolerance is because it's still tolerance.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それは寛大な処置だったと思います。
I think they were tolerant measures.

mnemonics.meaning: All forms of tolerance are still tolerance. Usually people like this are really open minded and generous too.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 自分には厳しいけど、他人には寛容です。
I’m strict with myself but tolerant of others.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned the word 枯れる which means "to wither," but this is when you are the one making a plant wither. It means to let dry or to kill your plants. They didn't just die on their own, you did it.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 枯れる, so you should be able to read this word as well.

sentences: 水をやりすぎて、サボテンを枯らしてしまいました。
I gave the cactus too much water and I killed it.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to show your agreement with someone you need to nod at them so they know.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: You seem to nod your head a lot when you're at the unagi zoo (うなず). Unagi zoos are really rare and hard to get into. So while you're there, keep nodding to everyone because you're so honored to be there!

sentences: 母は話を聞きながら、ウンウンと肯きました。
While I listened to my mother talk, I nodded, "Uh huh."

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means oppress, so the verb version is to oppress or to persecute.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The best way to oppress someone is to make it so they can't use the sh*tter (しいた). Just imagine any kind of oppressive monarch from history. They know your weakness. They know you need to poop at some point. What would it be like 48 hours from now if you didn't have a place to poop. If you didn't have your "sh*tter." To help you to remember that there's an い in there, think about an eagle, as we often do for い. This eagle represents "American Freedom." If you had this freedom you'd be pooping all you want and nobody would take your sh*tter away from you.

sentences: あの男は、妻と子供をずっと虐げてきたのよ。
That man always oppressed his wife and children.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tolerance, so the verb version is what happens when you're a really tolerant person. You're able to relax and to feel at home because nothing really gets to you.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You want to relax so you go down to old coots road (くつろ). It's a road with a bunch of old coots who don't bother nobody. They just kinda sit around and complain. That's where you like to relax. Something about being surrounded by a bunch of old coots on old coots road makes you feel at home.

sentences: まるで自分の家のように寛いでいました。
I relaxed like it was my own home.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen that 召す can mean "to respectfully eat," so adding 上がる, "to rise," means you're lifting the other person up. In polite language you use this when you're talking to someone higher up than you so you have to raise the humbly eating up. So it still means to respectfully eat, but raising it makes it a higher politeness level.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 召す and 上がる that you learned already. 召す becomes 召し and then you add that to 上がる. Pretty straightforward, right?

sentences: もしよければお召し上がり下さい。
Please eat if you’d like.

mnemonics.meaning: Violence and oppression are all signs of tyranny and that someone is being really cruel.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつらは暴虐の限りを尽くしたんだ。
They committed all kinds of tyrannical acts.

mnemonics.meaning: If you have not cleansed yourself you're going to be covered in uncleanliness and dirtiness. Eww.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: インドでは、左手を不浄の手として、右手でご飯を食べる。
In India the left hand is considered to be unclean and the right hand is used to eat.

mnemonics.meaning: If you manage to make all parts of something work together you worked very, extremely, considerably hard to do it. Doing all of anything is hard so lots of work had to happen.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 随分大胆なことをしたんですね。
You did a very bold thing.

mnemonics.meaning: You wash something to cleanse it by doing the washing and cleaning. You have to do the washing if you really want to get all the dirt out and make your things clean.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 電気ポットはどうやって洗浄してますか？
How do you do the wash with a hot water dispenser?

mnemonics.meaning: Melons that grow in the west are round and striped and green and wait a second. That's a watermelon. I guess they come from the western part of Japan.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 西 here is an exception. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Watermelons taste best after you swing (すい) them around. Whether you tie a rope to them or swing them on an actual swing, it mixes up the yummy watermelon insides and they end up tasting the best this way. So always remember to swing your watermelon before you crack it open.

sentences: 夏といえば西瓜ですよね。
When it comes to summer, watermelon's the first thing that comes to mind.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the word 渦 meaning "whirlpool" and 巻く meaning "to roll." A rolling whirlpool is still a whirlpool, just a really violent one.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of the words 渦 and 巻く. 巻く becomes 巻き and you just add 渦 to it. So reading this should be pretty simple.

sentences: 蚊取り線香はどうして渦巻き状になっているんですか。
Why are mosquito coils in a whirlpool shape?

mnemonics.meaning: A miner works with such sincerity that her arms and legs start turning rust colored from working earnestly. All the clay and rocks she's putting her effort into digging are turning her the same color. That color is how you know someone works with serious diligence.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お婆ちゃんが丹誠込めて育てたトマトだよ。
These are the tomatoes that Grandma worked earnestly to raise.

mnemonics.meaning: Who goes into their yurt to boil things? All the people you've ever known. You don't boil things outside, are you crazy? Wait, you're telling me all people don't do the same things? Excuse me?
mnemonics.reading: Here, all the people I know do this, so just let me show (しょ) you how. First you go into your yurt, hey! Pay attention and watch what I'm showing you. Okay, now that I've shown you what to do, you're just like all of us.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to wear a top hat you also have to wear a suit to go with it. You can't just wear a top hat, that just doesn't look right. When you think top hat, think about what you also need with it. Picture all the things you also need. A suit, a tie, a monocle, some shiny shoes. There's also ... something... else. What is it?
mnemonics.reading: You have a top hat and all the clothes that go with it but you also need a nice car (か) too! You can't just get all dressed up and then have no way to get anywhere to show it off. Think about all the things you also need when you wear a top hat. The car is probably the most important addition. Otherwise no one can see the top hat in the first place!

mnemonics.meaning: When the sun comes up the spikes of geoducks appear. The spikes don't just come out of the geoduck, they literally appear out of thin air. They didn't even exist before the sun touched them.
mnemonics.reading: You watch these spikes appear and suddenly Ken (けん)the samurai also appears next to you. "I DID IT!" he shouts, "I've learned how to appear out of thin air!" "Thank you sweet geoduck, you have taught me the way of appearing with your spikes."

mnemonics.meaning: What does a tree make that you'd want to put in your mouth? An apricot! Apricots are also about the size of an open mouth, so they kind of look like mouths hanging down under the trees. You can bite them right off the tree with your own mouth! Picture the mouth sized apricots hanging down off the tree. Imagine using your own mouth to bite them down. Just don't swallow the pit!
mnemonics.reading: After you put the apricot in your mouth you realize that this tastes really familiar, but not pleasant. It tastes just like the anchovies (あん) from the zoo (ず) smell. How did that happen? You don't like apricots anymore. Imagine trying to eat the bite sized apricot and spitting it out after the taste of anchovies from the zoo fill you up.

mnemonics.meaning: Dry an already dry tree to create a bookmark. The more you dry the tree, the flatter it becomes, making it the perfect way to mark your spot in a book without needing to fold a page or write on it. To be fair, books are just dry trees in a way, but bookmarks are actually dry, dry trees that have flattened out and turned into chunks.
mnemonics.reading: What are you bookmarking anyway? Look down and see yourself putting one of the tree bookmarks on a page in your notebook that says "She owes me reeds (しおり)." Oh yeah, you had to make this bookmark in the first place because your friend took your reed bookmarks and didn't give them back. What does she owe you? Open the page to your bookmark and see she owes reeds!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a bunch of trees lined up outside of the gate to the east and realize they look like perfect columns. It seems like a building or a castle should be resting above them. Picture these column trees outside the gate to the east. You end up drawing them in the columns of your graph paper because they fit so well.
mnemonics.reading: Out of the tree columns bursts professional wrestler Randy (らん) Savage! "Oooh I'm talking about columns that I like mmmm oh yeaah. The Macho Man loves columns MMm OOHH YEAAH~!" Now draw Randy Savage in the columns on your graph paper. He just seems to fit there now.

mnemonics.meaning: Your forehead is the origin for the measurement for your crown! If you measure somewhere else on your head for a crown it won't fit. Imagine someone putting a tape measure around your forehead and taking careful measurements for your crown. They better not mess up, or you'll have them put to death!
mnemonics.reading: You want your crown to be just like Genghis Khan's (かん), which was more of a cap. He's your hero though, because he ruled over the most people, so you want yours to match his measurements. Why don't you go look up what Genghis Khan's crown/cap looked like. Then try to imagine how it would look atop your head.

mnemonics.meaning: If you announce that alcohol is illegal you're just being cruel. Honestly, saying no one can have any alcohol at all is totally unjust. They tried that in the 1920s and it didn't work then either, so cut it out! Let people drink what they want to drink! Imagine if your country's leader announced that there would be no more alcohol. People would be in the streets in seconds calling them cruel and unjust!
mnemonics.reading: After this cruel announcement is made everyone will turn to the next best thing after alcohol. Coke (こく)! It's not a replacement, but if this unjust law won't change, then coke sales are going to go through the roof. Imagine drinking coke while complaining how unjust it is that you can't add rum to it.

mnemonics.meaning: The surplus stool, please describe it. You have a surplus (extra) stool, and someone wants it. But, they need to know more about it, so you describe it in great detail. Imagine yourself doing just that. Every screw and nubbin is described.
mnemonics.reading: You describe the features of the stool to Jo-Anne (じょ).  Jo-Anne is really excited about this stool. It's the perfect height for her (remember, she's on the shorter side to distinguish じょ from じょう). She pays attention to you describing the stool while sitting on it and spinning around. Have her ask for you to describe it more.

mnemonics.meaning: Jump on a scooter to excuse yourself from answering a question and you've successfully deviated from that nosey person's plan! You've also been able to elude them pretty well. Imagine excusing yourself by scooting away on a scooter. If they want to get your answer, they'll have to chase you.
mnemonics.reading: You deviate from the plan a little too well, and as you're scooting, what you've done eats (いつ) away at you. You feel guilty for eluding them...  Welp, it's too late to turn back now. You've already deviated pretty far, and you're not even sure where you are now. You were too busy trying to elude that person that you didn't look where your scooter was taking you.

mnemonics.meaning: You use thread and writing to sew our family crest. You've been sewing your family crest since you were a kid, you could do it today with your eyes closed. Imagine the thread slowly forming the writing that makes up your family crest. You're making a scarf with your crest on it. It's like a wizarding school house symbol.
mnemonics.reading: Your family crest is of a monster! And the writing says "Our Family Monster." What kind of monster is on your family crest? Picture it in your mind right now. Now tweet to us @wanikaniapp because I really want to know what you came up with!!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a building with a lip ring and it's just so cute you have to flatter it. "That lip ring looks wonderful on you, Buildingさん," you say. Flattering buildings is just as nice as flattering people, as long as they're okay with it.
mnemonics.reading: The building is flattered and you hear it shout, "Ah (あ)!" and blush. The entire building turns red. The "ah" the building made was actually quite loud, and since you've never heard a building speak before, it scared you pretty bad. But at least you know the building was flattered by your compliment (I think.)

mnemonics.meaning: If you give Splinter your heart you'll feel pretty foolish afterwards. His heart belongs to the art of ninjutsu!  You were foolish to give your heart away to Splinter. He didn't want it. Also he's a rat, what's wrong with you?
mnemonics.reading: Splinter tells you to your face how foolish you are and you feel your heart turn to goo (ぐ). Now you can't even give it to someone else. No one wants goo. What will you do with your foolish goo heart now?

mnemonics.meaning: A triceratops with a mustache will go on talking forever. Every time you think he's done he says, "Furthermore..." and keeps going. Something about a mustache on a dinosaur makes him kind of a jerk, but he's held in such high esteem that no one ever interrupts him. Imagine this mustachioed triceratops. He probably has a monocle and a fedora too. Every time you think you can talk or leave he says, "Furthermore" again. Come on guy, how much do you have to say?
mnemonics.reading: Why don't you just interrupt this mustache triceratops while he's saying furthermore? Because he's the Shougun's (しょう) pet. If you interrupt him you'll probably be put to death or something. Just let him keep going and hope he runs out of furthermores to talk about. "Furthermore!" the mustachioed triceratops points at the Shougun, "He is the best Shougun we'll ever have. And he'll let me talk forever OH OH OH!"

mnemonics.meaning: A mouth with a sword is threatening to cut off your fingers because they've kidnapped you! You can't see anything about them, since they're all covered up. All you see is their angry mouth and the sword they keep putting near your fingers.  Imagine you've been kidnapped. And the person who kidnapped you is going to cut off some of your fingers and mail them to your parents if they don't pay the ransom soon enough. You don't want your fingers to be cut off with a sword! Help!
mnemonics.reading: You've been kidnapped and your kidnapper has asked for one thing in exchange for your safe return: a kayak (かい). Kayaks are expensive. And it's way easier for this dude to kidnap you and demand your family buy one and give it to them than for them to work for one. If your parents don't send in the kayak to your kidnapper soon, you're gonna lose some fingers. Come on guys, just get the kayak already!!!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader who usually hits you with a stick in winter finds it in his heart to give you some leisure time. You fall to your knees, "Oh thank you for not hitting me with your stick and letting me relax!" You haven't had a moment of leisure in ages!
mnemonics.reading: You're just about to start your leisure time when a group of youths (ゆう) appears with their own sticks. You look back for the leader, and he's wearing a bathrobe, sunglasses, and is drinking some hot cocoa. Wait... this is leisure time for... HIM?! OH NO! As the leader leisurely watches, the youths smack you with their sticks. What a cruel world! "Enjoy your leisure time," the leader yells over, "the youths hit much softer than I do. Have fun!"

mnemonics.meaning: You're in a really important position, heavy with power, but you can't carry all of that around with you, so you boil it all down to just a few merits. Most people in places heavy with power, like the scouts, boil down all of their responsibilities and accomplishments this way into merit badges.
mnemonics.reading: The only problem with consolidating your merits like this is that raccoons (くん) are always trying to steal them. Raccoons really like shiny, small things. Like, say, the physical representation of all your personal and professional merits. This is why you never see a military officer or a girl scout leaving their merit badges out in the open. They pin them right onto their clothes. Otherwise the raccoons would come.

mnemonics.meaning: A coat rack will turn into a bundle of sticks if you neglect it. When you neglect a coat rack, the weight from the coats will pull all of the arms off, leaving it as a sparse stick. Picture this sparse, neglected coat rack. All of its arms and the coats that were on it have fallen off and are in a big pile on the ground.
mnemonics.reading: You go up to the neglected coat rack and try to make things right by cleaning it with soap (そ). But no matter how much you scrub, it won't get clean, the arms won't go back on. If you neglect something for too long, not even a good soap scrub will bring it back. That goes for humans too. Take care of yourselves. Use soap.

mnemonics.meaning: Whatever you say through a satellite turns into Noh chanting. It gets all drawn out and distorted from going through the satellite, which makes it SOUND like Noh chanting at least. Say whatever you want and send it up to the satellite. Now imagine listening to it when it comes back and hearing beautiful, deep Noh chanting back!
mnemonics.reading: While you're fake Noh chanting you have to pause every few minutes to take a bite of yogurt (よう). Yogurt is good for the throat! At least you think it is. It's not like you're actually chanting, the satellite is doing all the real work. Watch closely the next time you go to a Noh play. See the man Noh chanting? Watch close enough and you'll see him eat a scoop of yogurt every once in a while.

mnemonics.meaning: After your wedding you have a baby and it uses its mouth to nurse from your post-marriage boobs. Yes, babies nurse from breasts. Get over it, kids. You waited until your wedding to have your baby and all it seems to do with its mouth is want to nurse. It doesn't cry, which is nice, but it doesn't laugh or talk either.
mnemonics.reading: The baby wants to nurse all day and the only thing you can seem to do at the same time is hoe (ほ) your garden. You hold the baby to your breast with one arm and hoe little rows with the other. It's actually a great workout and a nice way to spend time! This hoe has really helped you get through nursing. You think you'll keep this up even after your baby is weened off! Hoeing the garden is your new favorite hobby!

mnemonics.meaning: A drunkard gets his hands on a plow and starts planting right away. Drunk people are surprisingly good at planting, especially when they have machines to help them do it. Picture a drunk guy laughing and plowing a field and planting seeds. He wouldn't do this if he was sober, but drunk people can't help themselves.
mnemonics.reading: He keeps planting and planting... a little too much. You walk over and realize this drunkard isn't just any guy... he's YOUR CYBORG (さい)! Oh my sweet cyborg child! Is this what they've done with you? You're just a drunkard who's only good for planting? Nooooooo!!

mnemonics.meaning: You put your foot on the bar at the gymnasium at your very first practice. That's a big accomplishment since you're here learning how to walk on that long bar like all the cool gymnasts. But you can't just start right away, you need lots of practice so that's why you're here in this class. But so far you got your foot on the bar already, good for you! Picture your foot touching the bar. This is it. This is exactly what you're at this gym to practice.
mnemonics.reading: This type of practice is especially hard for you because you're a centaur (せん). You only have hooves for feet, and balancing on a bar is going to be a huge hurdle. But your teacher promised if you practiced enough you could make it, and here you are! With your hoofed foot on the bar! Picture your centaur foot on the bar as you practice to become a gymnast. It's going to take years and years of this kind of practice, but you're sure you'll make it all the way up there some day! Never give up!

mnemonics.meaning: The Mouth King, who is just one big mouth, has one skill, and that is to present. That big mouth is always presenting something. Imagine the Mouth King giving a presentation about the importance of mouths. His subjects all flatter him by saying, "Please, please, present to us about mouths again! We truuuuuuly love it!"
mnemonics.reading: "I will present to you a presentation about mouths, but I require energy. Please fill my giant mouth body with delicious tater (てい) tots. You pour a bucket of tater tots into his mouth body and he continues his presentation about mouths. "You see, mouths are just orifices..."

mnemonics.meaning: Your leader managed to find the right direction home using marks in the dirt in the middle of winter. This makes you so proud! You're proud because this resourceful leader is YOUR resourceful leader. Imagine how proud you and your whole country feel as your leader comes trudging in through the snow. He made it home. You're (sniff) so (sob) proud!
mnemonics.reading: This leader you're so proud of is old man ごういち. He's been getting a bit slow over the years, and you really didn't think he'd make it back. But, by gum, he did it. Let's be honest here, ごういち isn't getting any younger. You really should be proud of him for surviving this long at all.

mnemonics.meaning: A sickness that hits you like an arrow will do its gross work rapidly. It's not a good thing, you're gonna get really sick really fast. Picture this rapid sickness spreading through your body like a cartoon arrow ricocheting through your body. Yuck!
mnemonics.reading: This rapid sickness makes your head pound like there's a shih tzu (しつ) yapping and barking nonstop. And it's making you sh*t a lot. Imagine getting sick this rapidly. All of a sudden, there's a shih tzu barking in your head, it hurts! And... oh no, where's the toilet?!

mnemonics.meaning: Flowers that grow in the west are colored by the sun setting so they turn bright red. That's why red flowers that grow in the west are used to make red dye. They're the closest to the actual color of the red sun, so they're prized by painters and other artists for their perfect color for dye. Picture yourself sitting in the west as the red sun sets, smashing those pretty red flowers into a paste to make red dye. Your fingers get dyed red too and you crush the petals into a paste.
mnemonics.reading: As you're smashing the flowers into red dye, a little girl comes up to you and points at the paste. She says, "赤ね (あかね)?" (That's red, right?) You look down at the red dye on your fingers and nod. She's right, it is red. Hear the little girl say あかね while pointing to the red dye. She's right. And the way she says it is so darn cute.

mnemonics.meaning: You took someone's alcohol and drop drop drop'd it all into the river. Now you have to repay them. Alcohol costs a lot of money, you know. Picture yourself dropping the alcohol, drop by drop, into the river. Uh oh, the person just caught up to you, so you better repay them.
mnemonics.reading: In order to repay them for the alcohol you wasted, you offer to give them your shoes (しゅう). They don't want your shoes though, so you have to bring them to a store and watch them try on a bunch of different pairs so you can repay them that way. Imagine waiting as this person tries on like twenty different pairs of shoes. They're getting them for free! Why do they have to be picky?! Just let me repay you already!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a mouth coming out of the top of a tree so you go into shock. Your brain just can't comprehend what's in front of you. A tree... with... a... mouth? No, it can't be... I... a-. Your face warps into a permanent state of shock.
mnemonics.reading: The shock you've suffered results in you needing to stay home (ほう) from now on. You don't get to travel, explore, or even get groceries. You're homebound from now on, buddy. I'd be shocked if you ever left your home again, honestly. But hey, there's always anime.

mnemonics.meaning: You cast the Mona Lisa in gold and attach it to a stick to turn it into a sickle! It's really big and bulky, but when you swing it fast enough your new sickle cuts lots of wheat! Just don't tell anyone what you did with the famous Mona Lisa painting and you should be able to get away with this! Imagine wielding your gold Mona Lisa sickle. It's sooo heavy, but it's really shiny and it cuts grass and wheat pretty well!
mnemonics.reading: Now that you've turned the Mona Lisa into a sickle, you have to change the little description under its name in the Louvre. You draw a giant comma (かま) next to "Mona Lisa" and write "THE SICKLE." Then you shove it back on the wall as best you can. Hear all the guests say, "Mona Lisa... comma the sickle? WHAT'S HAPPENED HERE?!" As panic ensues. You like your addition and you're very proud.

mnemonics.meaning: A wolverine that sticks its legs in rice will become very solemn, very fast. This is weird to you because wolverines always seem so happy. Well his dad died from his legs getting stuck in rice, so just leave the poor solemn creature alone. Imagine if your dad died from getting his legs stuck in some rice, now feel solemn too.
mnemonics.reading: Remember how solemn wolverine looked when his dad died? You hated seeing him like this so you ran up and shook (しゅく) him. You shook the solemn sadness right out of him! You should do that again now! Imagine seeing how violently you shook him. You shook him so hard his solemn mood disappeared!

mnemonics.meaning: When you leave flowers on a tombstone they look good at first, but after a few days or some harsh weather, there's nothing left but stems. That's why you have to replace flowers on tombstones all the time. If you don't it will look like you only left the stems there, and that's pretty disrespectful. Imagine being in a graveyard looking at all the tombstones and seeing nothing but stems on all of them. All the pretty flowery parts have died and blown away.
mnemonics.reading: You have an idea that can make these tombstones look better than just having leftover stems all over them. You brought cookies (くき)! Cookies don't fall apart in the wind, and everyone loves cookies, alive or dead. You replace the stems with the cookies and everything looks a lot nicer. Look at all the cookie covered tombstones. Now your bag is full of stems, but you can use them to make more cookies to bring back next time. Don't worry, nobody eats them. Stem cookies are probably poisonous.

mnemonics.meaning: You're sick because you put an arrow in your mouth and tried to eat it. To be honest, that's just really stupid. You have to be stupid to try to eat an arrow. You deserve to be sick. How stupid do you have to be to put arrows into your mouth until it makes you sick? Pretty darn stupid, it seems.
mnemonics.reading: The only way to cure this serious case of stupid is to make you eat cheese (ち). Not only will it fix your sick stomach by cushioning all the arrows that you shoved in your stupid mouth, but it should send smart cheese waves to your brain and cure you of that stupid all together. Imagine if everyone knew that cheese cures the stupid out of people. Then maybe we would have more cheese and less stupid in the world!

mnemonics.meaning: Clearing his flowers of icicles, the samurai returns home to his villa. Picture the samurai's villa. It's in the countryside and covered in flowers and icicles. Even though it's spring, it's still cold, so all the new flowers are very cold.
mnemonics.reading: Once the samurai enters the villa, he lets his soul (そう) go. He's been fighting for long enough and this villa was always where he wanted to go. Picture the samurai sitting in a chair in his beautiful villa and breathing his last breath. His soul slowly floats up and out of his still body and dances around the villa, free.

mnemonics.meaning: If you travel to the fish capital, you'll find the leader of all fish, the mighty whale! Okay, so a whale isn't technically a fish, but that's why it makes such a good leader. You can usually only find whales hanging around near the capital because they really enjoy ruling over all the other fish. They are the biggest, after all. Picture the underwater fish capital. Statues of whales line the fishy streets, and all of the fish bow down to the whale ruler's giant body.
mnemonics.reading: The whale who resides over the capital just happens to be gay (げい). You only know this because his husband is a man whale too. Actually, now that you think about it, all the whales you've ever met have been gay. Picture the gay whale ruler holding whale hands... fins? with his whale husband. They're so cute.

mnemonics.meaning: You should stop to buy stamps at noon because that's the only time they're being sold at wholesale price. Everyone's so busy eating and working and being at school, that they miss this awesome deal, but not you. Everyday at noon you stock up on wholesale stamps. Do you send a lot of mail? No, you probably just collect them. But they were cheap, so who cares! Imagine yourself stopping at the empty bank at noon, grabbing a handful of wholesale stamps. So many stamps. So few extra charges.
mnemonics.reading: Oh, one more thing. Going at noon isn't enough, you have to say the password to get them at wholesale price too. The password is "Oh Roshi" (おろし). Okay, so maybe that's just the name of the guy there, but it always works when I want to get stamps wholesale so you should do it too! "Oh Roshi" you say carefully as you hand your stamps over at noon. The guy raises an eyebrow at you, but gives you them wholesale! It worked!

mnemonics.meaning: If it appears to exist, then it's probably an actual thing... you know, existing and stuff. That should be pretty obvious.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この絵は、人間の顕在意識と潜在意識を象徴しています。
This picture symbolizes humanity’s conscious and subconscious.

mnemonics.meaning: How do you deviate from a normal talk? With lots of anecdotes. If you add enough of them into your conversations no one will ever be able to keep track of what you were talking about to begin with.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この学校には面白い逸話があってね。
This school has an interesting anecdote.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading with the kanji! Yay!

sentences: 干し杏のジャムを作りました。
I made dried apricot jam.

mnemonics.meaning: Provisions that are only for soldiers are army provisions.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned the reading for the second kanji but not the first one yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you: The army said it would provide you with some army provisions. That's great! You go to the drop site where the provisions are, and you see the provisions. "Heyo! It's roe!" (ひょうろう) you say out loud. You're pretty happy that your provisions consist of tons and tons of roe!

sentences: 兵糧攻めをするつもりなんだ。
They plan to use starvation tactics.

mnemonics.meaning: Tell everyone how you describe yourself in your autobiography. It's the only way they'll be able to understand the real you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 電子書籍で自叙伝を販売しようと思っています。
I’m thinking of selling my autobiography as an e-book.

mnemonics.meaning: A milk bottle that babies use to nurse is called a baby bottle.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 哺乳瓶を熱湯消毒しています。
You disinfect the baby bottle in boiling water.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the place you take a bath in is the bathroom!
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 場. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!

sentences: 風呂場で滑ってお尻の骨を折りました。
I broke my butt bone slipping in the bathroom.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You already learned this reading when you learned 偏る, so you should be able to read this one too!

sentences: あなたって、考え方にすごく偏りがあるよね。
Your way of thinking is really biased, isn't it?

mnemonics.meaning: A space as empty as the sky is a blank space. You're probably supposed to fill that in with something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 空欄に答えを書き込んでください。
Please fill out your response in the blank space.

mnemonics.meaning: Tray planting is bonsai. It makes sense because that is exactly what you're doing: planting a tree in a tray!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アメリカでも盆栽が買えるんですか？
Can you buy bonsai in America too?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 本を読む時に栞は使いますか。
When you read books do you use a bookmark?

mnemonics.meaning: Who works for peace and is held in high esteem? A Buddhist high priest. They work harder than anyone else to reach world peace so they're held in very high esteem.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 和 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The only thing you ever hear the Buddhist High Priest say is "Oooooo" (お). It must be some kind of Buddhist humming or chanting. Every time you think about him you hear that o sound in your head.

sentences: 昔々あるところに、水飴が大好きな和尚がおりました。
Once upon a time there was a high priest who loved starch syrup.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: この欄は空けておいてください。
Please leave this column blank.

mnemonics.meaning: Describe someone's merit at a ceremony for the conferring of decorations. That's when medals are given out to people who deserve them. Usually in the military or something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎年、春と秋に春秋叙勲が実施されます。
Every year, in spring and fall, the spring and fall conferring of decorations is carried out.

mnemonics.meaning: Look at a chapter on family crests in that book and you'll see every crest in your area.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: これは、王家の紋章です。
This is the royal family’s crest.

mnemonics.meaning: Red dye color is crimson, or dark red. This word is used most often to describe the color of the sky at sunset.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the same as the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 空が夕焼けで茜色に染まっていて、とても綺麗でした。
The sky was crimson in the sunset, and it was very beautiful.
茜色の空を見ながら、シャンパンを飲んだ。
We drank champagne while looking at the crimson sky.
見て、空が燃えるような茜色になってきてるよ。
Look, the sky is turning a fiery dark red color!

mnemonics.meaning: A king's cap is his crown. It's a hat only he can wear.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は恋をして王冠を捨てたんだ。
He was in love and abandoned the crown.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of cruel? Cruel or awful.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Think of a man who is cruel. Doesn't matter who, but pick one that you know of that is actually cruel. He can be a real person or someone in a movie or on TV. What does this man do? He do (ひど) cruel things.

sentences: 彼女の作った料理は、どれも酷い味だった。
All of the food she made tasted awful.
自分の彼女によくもそんな酷い事が言えるね。
How can you say such a cruel thing to your own girlfriend?
こんなに暑さが酷くなるって分かっていたら、この国に引っ越していなかったよ。
If I had known the heat would be this severe, I wouldn't have moved to this country.

mnemonics.meaning: A cruel cool person is more cruel and coldhearted than just a normal cruel person. It's probably because they're cold all the time and it makes them mad. You should stay away from people like that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あなたのこと、ずっと冷酷な人だと思っていました。
I always thought you were a cruel person.

mnemonics.meaning: The remainder of cruelness is cruelty. There always seems to be plenty to go around, and it kind of sucks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は、ひどく残酷な決断を迫られました。
I was pressed for an awfully cruel decision.

mnemonics.meaning: Planting seeds in land to cultivate crops is called cultivation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 庭でトマトを栽培しているんです。
I’m growing tomatoes in my garden.

mnemonics.meaning: To show that you had merit for a chapter of your life you will be given a decoration or a medal. Especially if you're a soldier or an athlete.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして勲章の受賞を辞退したんですか。
Why did you decline the winning medal?

mnemonics.meaning: If you seem stupid and shocked all the time you might have dementia. It makes it so everything is unfamiliar and confusing, so you can't help looking silly and confused all the time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 祖母の痴呆が始まったんです。
My grandmother is starting to get dementia.

mnemonics.meaning: If the neglect of an area surpasses what was expected, then the result will be depopulation. No one wants to live in a neglected town, especially one that's worse than what they were told.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本には、過疎に悩む地域がたくさんあります。
There are a lot of areas troubled with depopulation in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: Describe your surroundings by mentioning everything you see. What you just said was a description.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この授業では、挿し絵や写真と叙述を結び付けることを学びます。
In this lesson we’re going to learn to link together illustrations, photographs, and descriptions.

mnemonics.meaning: If you deviate from the plan and undress yourself, that's a serious deviation and could ruin everything! You need to wear pants, you know!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 任務を逸脱する行為は慎み給え。
Please refrain from tasks that deviate from the mission.

mnemonics.meaning: You expose something new and it appears in front of the whole world as your discovery.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして我々の陰謀が露顕したのだ。

mnemonics.meaning: Something that you are afflicted with rapidly is a disease. You should go to the doctor's right away to treat this fast-acting ailment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の妹は、精神疾患を抱えています。
My little sister has a mental disorder.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 秩序 means "order?" Well if you have nothing like that then it falls into disorder and chaos!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 戸棚の中には、何千本というマニキュアが無秩序に並べられていた。
Thousands of bottles of nail polish are disorderly lined up in the closet.

mnemonics.meaning: A poem that describes things is an epic poem. This is for those super long, really descriptive poems that you're forced to read in English class.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 『ギルガメシュ叙事詩』は、古代メソポタミアの文学作品です。
"The Epic of Gilgamesh" is a literary work from ancient Mesopotamia.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is the kanji followed by the particle に, so it uses the kun'yomi reading like a kanji does if it's alone. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you wear when it's especially cold out? Your favorite coat (こと). You only wear it when it's unusually cold though, never any other time.

sentences: 殊に、来年はコウイチ様生誕100周年を記念するメモリアル・イヤーとなります。
Additionally, next year will be the memorial year commemorating the one hundredth year anniversary of Koichi-sama’s birth.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 必須 can mean "essential" and that 条件 means "condition," so put them together and you get essential condition! That basically means that it's a must.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お肌の張りと艶は、モテる女の必須条件です。
Shiny, toned skin is a must for popular women.

mnemonics.meaning: Neglect someone so much that you remove yourself from their inner circle and live outside of their life and it's called estrangement. You might never see them again. But that's okay with you, your relationship is too weird to fix now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 学校ではずっと疎外感を感じていました。

mnemonics.meaning: If your neglect of family members goes too far you'll end up with estrangement in your relationships with them. And they'll probably neglect you as much as you neglect them.

sentences: それっきり、姉とは疎遠になっているんです。

mnemonics.meaning: Leisure that last for a long time ends up going on for all eternity. It never ends, and why should it? You're soooo relaaaaaxed, you can't possibly ever stop.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 悠久な大自然で、人生について色々なことを考えてみました。
I thought about various things about human life within the eternity of mother nature.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are ethic al are ethical.

sentences: うちの会社は、世界で最も倫理的な企業の一つに選ばれました。

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 倫理 means "ethics" so when you add study it means the ethics you study in school.

sentences: 医学倫理学の講座を受けています。

mnemonics.meaning: If a place has been neglected for too long you'll have to open the doors for evacuation of the building. Places can't stay nice forever and sometimes the safest thing is to get the heck out of there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 空襲を避けるために田舎へ疎開していました。

mnemonics.meaning: Do you excel when you deviate from the norm? Well, then you're made for excellence, my friend!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この広告は非常に秀逸だと評判です。

mnemonics.meaning: Repay what someone lent you in response to them already lending YOU money, and the two of you will have exchanged money.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 両チームのファンからやじの応酬が続いた。

mnemonics.meaning: If you use something in a cruel way it's called exploitation. You're probably going to overuse it, at that rate too. Cut it out, dude.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 労働者を酷使するブラック企業をこのまま野放しにしていてもいいんですか。

mnemonics.meaning: Present and expose wrongdoing to get proper exposure. The world needs disclosure and so do you!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつがしていたインチキが全部露呈したんだよ。

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 新郎が紋付袴を着ている写真はありますか。

mnemonics.meaning: The family crest on your finger? That's just your fingerprint. It can be used to identify you, so it's pretty much the same as your own personal family crest.

sentences: ドアノブの指紋を綺麗に拭き取った。

mnemonics.meaning: The peoples Noh chanting is folk songs. They're the songs for the common people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最近は毎日ロシア民謡を聞いています。

mnemonics.meaning: Shock someone by flattering them and they'll end up looking like a fool. Taking compliments always turns people into silly idiots. It's okay, they're just embarrassed.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 学生の頃は、いつも阿呆なことばかりしてたな。
When I was a student I only did stupid things.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Since this word is both a noun and a na-adjective, it can also mean things like folly and foolishness.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 先ほどは愚なことを申し上げてしまいまして、誠に申し訳ございませんでした。

親友と、愚にもつかない話をして夜を過ごした。

まさに愚の骨頂だね。
This is certainly the height of folly.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When do people tend to use the word furthermore? Right now (なお)!

sentences: 温めて食べたら、尚、おいしくなりますよ。
If I warm it up and eat it, it becomes even more delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: A rapid wind is a gale or a strong wind.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 真っ黒な犬が、疾風のように河原を駆け抜けていった。

mnemonics.meaning: Deviate from normal, everyday products and buy lots of gems and treasures! Especially if you're buying presents. Normal stuff just isn't going to cut it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この黒毛和牛のステーキは、シェフのこだわりの逸品です。
This Japanese Black steak is a gem chefs obsess over.

mnemonics.meaning: All tasks are a part of the general affairs of the people. That's why they're general, they're the ones everyone is involved in.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こんど、庶務課に配属されることになりました。
It will be assigned to the general affairs department this time.

mnemonics.meaning: Silver apricots are called ginkgo nuts. Okay, they aren't really apricots, but they are silver and they sure look the same.
mnemonics.reading: This word is an exception. You'd think it would be the same in Japanese as it is in English, but it's not. And it has two different readings and meanings. Yikes, sorry. Here's a mnemonic to help you out: Before you read this PLEASE PLEASE REMEMBER this is NOT a jukugo word. It's weird. You're gonna want to type ぎんこう but that's wrong. Stop that now. When you think of a ginkgo tree think about this: Ginkgos are a favorite nesting place for eagles but evil Mrs. Chou likes to eat eagles AND whole ginkgo trees. She prefers eating eagles WHILE THEY'RE IN THE GINKGO TREES AND ARE STILL ALIVE. So いちょう. Eagles and Mrs. Chou. And ginkgo trees. It's horrible to think about. Just like this reading not being jukugo. The other meaning is the ginkgo nuts themselves. They taste like 銀 (ぎん) naan (なん). Mm mm soft and metallic, but still not the jukugo word though. How sad for you and all Japanese learners everywhere.

sentences: 銀杏を食べ過ぎると中毒症状が出ます。
Poisoning symptoms develop when I eat too much ginkgo.

mnemonics.meaning: If everyone is acting solemn and strict then you should probably pay special attention to the gravity of the situation you're in. Don't start playing the trumpet when you're supposed to be bowing your head!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 結果を厳粛に受け止め、次回に臨みたい。
I want to solemnly react to the results and face it next time.

mnemonics.meaning: A column made of dry wood is turned into a guardrail to help people walk up and down stairs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その欄干は古いからもたれないほうがいい。
This guardrail is old so you shouldn’t lean on it.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that's cruel tends to be harsh, severe, and terrible. And of course, it's still cruel to boot.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: それをあいつに頼むのは、ちょっと酷すぎやしないか。
Asking that guy for it is a bit too harsh.
あれは、みんな酷な実践方法だったと言っていた。
Everyone was saying it was a severe way to practice.

mnemonics.meaning: You only hold someone in high esteem if they are really high, noble people. They have to be refined to be held so highly by you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 高尚な趣味をお持ちなんですね。
You have such refined tastes.

mnemonics.meaning: A villa separate from your normal house is a holiday house. You go there when you're sick of your normal house to relax.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この春に別荘を売ってしまうつもりです。
I plan on selling the villa in spring.

mnemonics.meaning: Sometimes someone will appear before you and it's clear they're worth honoring. If Koichi appeared before you, for example, it should be pretty clear what you should do.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 先日、献血50回を労る顕彰をいただきました。
The other day, I was honored for having donated blood 50 times.

mnemonics.meaning: The prefecture famous for its ancient thorn castle is Ibaraki prefecture. I may or may not be making this up. Don't fact check me, just look at that cool thorny castle in Ibaraki that I put in your head. Ooooh, how cool!
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the kun'yomi reading for 茨, and exception for 城 and the on'yomi for 県. Phew! You haven't learned this weird reading for 城 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ibaraki prefecture is famous for making keys (き)! It's their biggest export. The key to knowing this reading is in the keys they make! Or, just knowing that it's the same in English and Japanese.

sentences: 茨城県に実家があります。
My parents’ home is in Ibaraki prefecture.

mnemonics.meaning: A foolish and stupid person will make lots of idle complaints. You really don't like being around them because they grumble about how nothing is good enough all the time. But they really just don't get it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 愚痴ばかり言っても、何も変わらないよ。
If you only talk of idle complaints, nothing will change.

mnemonics.meaning: A rapid sickness is an illness or a disease.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 病 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you don't treat an illness right away you'll end up paying (ぺい) with your life. And if you don't die, you'll still have to pay a lot for doctor and hospital fees. Yuck.

sentences: がん、急性心筋梗塞、脳卒中のことを三大疾病といいます。
The three major diseases are cancer, heart attack, and stroke.

mnemonics.meaning: Cruel hot weather is the kind that's too much for anyone to handle. It's intense heat. Stranded in the desert in summer, heat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 暑 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Intense heat will show (しょ) on your face. You'll turn red and get all sweaty. You really can't hide it.

sentences: 今年の夏は、酷暑が続きました。
This summer the intense heat continued.

mnemonics.meaning: Invite someone to kidnap you and you'll have a kidnapping on your hands. That wasn't very smart. You should try to be more careful.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 社長の息子を誘拐するつもりだ。
I’m going to kidnap the manager’s son.

mnemonics.meaning: Long leisure makes everything you do leisurely and slow. You're able to perform tasks at a deliberate rate because nothing's rushing you. And you've been like this for so long, why would anything try?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: そんな悠長なことを言ってる時間はないよ。
This isn’t the time to talk about such leisurely things.

mnemonics.meaning: The best way to describe your feelings is with lyricism. Making a clear description of feelings is difficult, but it will make you feel better.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: うまく叙情できるよう勉強しています。
I’m studying to be able to cleverly describe my feelings.

mnemonics.meaning: If you write outside the columns in your notebook paper you're actually writing in the margins. It's a good space to put doodles.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: サインが欄外にはみ出てしまったんですが、大丈夫でしょうか。
I wonder if it’s okay that my signature is going out of the margins.

mnemonics.meaning: All peoples make up the masses. They are the common people and no society is complete without them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私みたいな庶民には関係のない話です。
The story has nothing to do with a common person like me.

mnemonics.meaning: You do things especially worthy of merit and they're called meritorious deeds.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 攻守ともに殊勲を立てました。
Both offense and defense played with distinction.

mnemonics.meaning: Your body thinks you want to substitute new exhibits inside yourself but it apologizes and replaces them more than you'd like. What it's actually doing is controlling your metabolism. Picture your body using food you eat by setting it up in an exhibit in your stomach. But it gets bored of it and wants to substitute it with a newer one, so it makes you hungry again, digesting the food fast.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. However, you haven't learned this (less common) on'yomi for代 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: As everyone knows, the best way to boost your metabolism is to wear a tie (たい). It just makes your body feel more efficient.

sentences: 新陳代謝がアップするエクササイズをご紹介します。
I’m going to introduce an exercise that improves my metabolism.

mnemonics.meaning: Okay... so before I get into this, you can't get mad at me. I didn't make this word up. I didn't make the Japanese language and I have nothing to do with this. And don't blame Japanese people for it either. So apparently a stupid Chinese person is a molester. Our theory is, that in China "Chinese" just meant "person" so a molester was just a stupid person. But in Japanese we think of 漢 as Chinese, so there you go. Either way, you'll probably never ever forget this one. You're welcome!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今朝、痴漢を逮捕しました。
The molester was arrested this morning.

mnemonics.meaning: The most superior treatment is another way of saying it's the most favorable treatment you've ever received. It's when you get the warmest reception out of everyone around you. Like they think you're the president or something. Either way, it's pretty great!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 最優遇貸出金利はいまどのぐらいですか。
How much is the prime rate right now?

mnemonics.meaning: A mountain villa is a mountain retreat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ある閉ざされた山荘で悲劇は起きた。
A tragedy occurred at a particular closed mountain retreat.

mnemonics.meaning: If you never neglect to pass through your thoughts to another person the two of you will be able to have a special mutual understanding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼とは、意思疎通が全然できないんです。
There is no way I can come to a mutual understanding with him.

mnemonics.meaning: Noh chanting for juveniles are nursery rhymes. Kids won't understand the heavy stuff, so you have to dumb it down for them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 幼稚園で新しい童謡を習ってきました。
I’ve learned new nursery rhymes in kindergarten.

mnemonics.meaning: Nurse and raise your baby by nursing. Milk helps babies grow up big and strong.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 乳児哺育の方法は大きく変化しています。
The method of nursing infants is changing greatly.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that the word 孤児 means "orphan," so when you put a bunch of orphans in an institution it's called an orphanage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は孤児院で幼少期を過ごしました。
I spent my childhood in an orphanage.

mnemonics.meaning: To tell you the truth, practice is practice. You can't just substitute something else for it. You'll only make progress with real practice! You can do it!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 理論は実践に移してこそ意味があるのです。
Theories are meaningful only if put into practice.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that the word 時期 means "time period," so when you add furthermore and early to that, it means that something happened ahead of time. It means premature.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その話を持ち出すのは時期尚早だろう。
I think it’s premature to broach that topic.

mnemonics.meaning: Present your findings in advance during an early presentation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 訪問者の多いブログには、Tポイントが進呈されます。
T-points are presented to those blogs with a lot of visitors.

mnemonics.meaning: Present your presents at the presentation. Presents for everyone!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 主役を演じた友人に花束を贈呈しました。
I presented flowers to a friend who was playing the leading role.

mnemonics.meaning: If you ridicule other people because you're so proud of yourself that everyone seems like crap in comparison, you've got too much pride. You should also work on toning down your arrogance and haughtiness, because people won't like you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あんな傲慢な男は初めてだよ。
This is the first time I’ve met such an arrogant man.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 風呂 means "bath?" Well the store you pay to take a bath in is the public bathhouse!
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the jukugo word 風呂 and the kun'yomi reading for 屋. You've learned all of these readings, so you should be able to read this already too!

sentences: 風呂屋に来るのは初めてです。
This is my first time going to a public bathhouse.

mnemonics.meaning: Leisure with more leisure added on? That's a really quiet and leisurely life you've got going on! Note that you need to add と to the end of this word to make it an adverb, and たる to make it an adjective!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is just the on'yomi readings (which you learned with the kanji) twice in a row.

sentences: 退職後は田舎で悠々と暮らしたいな。
After retirement I want to live a quiet life in the countryside.

mnemonics.meaning: When an author appears in public it's always remarkable. People usually don't remember there's anyone behind those pages, so when the actual author shows up in person it's pretty striking.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我が社の業績は顕著に回復しています。
Our company’s results are making a remarkable recovery.

mnemonics.meaning: Gold you get as compensation for reparations is called reparations.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 賠償金をお支払い頂く可能性があります。
You may be expected to pay reparations.

mnemonics.meaning: If you resemble someone who's cruel, you, well, you resemble them. Maybe you're really mean too. I guess only you can know that. But you do look like that other guy...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 似 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Which cruel guy do you resemble? Jesus (じ), of course. I mean, you look just like him. Look in the mirror if you don't believe me. Look, there he is. Wait, what do you mean he isn't a cruel guy? I guess you're the cruel one then. Sucks to be you.

sentences: 三冊の本は、どれも内容が酷似している。
All the content in the three volumes of the book resemble each other.

mnemonics.meaning: Repay people for the news they tell you by rewarding them! Everyone deserves compensation for the time they take to pass information to you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このプロジェクトが成功すれば、報酬として、クリステンがほっぺにキスをしてくれます。
If this project is a success, Kristen will give me a kiss on the cheek as a reward.

mnemonics.meaning: Throw your family crest into the waves and you'll make lots of ripples. There will probably also be repercussions with your family because those things are important and you really shouldn't be tossing them into the sea's waves.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大臣の不用意な発言が波紋を呼んだ。
The cabinet minister’s careless remark created a huge stir.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're solemn by yourself, you have a lot of self control. You don't need anyone to tell you to be that way, you have your own self discipline.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 役員の不祥事発覚を受け、本日は全社員が営業活動を自粛致します。
With the staff scandal coming to light, all employees are to restrain themselves from doing business activities today.

mnemonics.meaning: Evaluate in a cruel way so you can lay some severe criticism down on your competition! It's not the nicest thing to do, and it's not very constructive for them, but it will make you look better.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: いちいち酷評を気にしてたら、何も書けないよ。
I can’t write anything if I pay an undue amount of attention to each severe criticism.

mnemonics.meaning: Your boss surpasses his normal cruelty and rains severity down on your head. You had other things to do this weekend and now you have to work through it? Harsh...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼らは、不当に過酷な労働を強いられています。
They’re being forced into unreasonably severe manual labor.

mnemonics.meaning: The room where you exhibit things in a row is a showroom. Maybe there are cars lined up, or boats, or tiny porcelain cats! Either way, they need a nice big showroom to show them off.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その陳列室には、いったい何が並べられているのですか。
What the heck is on display in the showroom?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 鎌をすっぽ抜けただけです。
The sickle just slipped out of my hand.

mnemonics.meaning: A solemn quiet person will always be silent. They never ever speak.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 静粛に願います。
Please be silent.

mnemonics.meaning: A villa that's kept under really strict rules will press solemnity on everyone who tries to stay there.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 厳 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To help you understand the solemnity of a moment of silence, usually a gong (ごん) will play a few times. As you listen to the echo and silence that comes after it. The gravity of what you're being silent for really sinks in.

sentences: その儀式は荘厳に行われました。
The ceremony was held solemnly.

mnemonics.meaning: Noh chanting out a song makes it an even longer, more confusing song. But it's still a song nonetheless!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今日のカラオケは、昭和歌謡縛りにしよう。
Let’s tie up today’s karaoke with a Noh song from the Showa era.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When things are sparse, you won't have food or toys or internet. It's hard for everyone. So your mama would baa (まば) to entertain you and get you to stop thinking about how thin you and her were getting. Mama baaing made you calm and happy. Thanks mama.

sentences: 昼間は賑やかですが、夜になると人通りも疎らになります。
It’s bustling during the day, but at night pedestrian traffic is sparse.

mnemonics.meaning: A rapid run is called a sprint or a dash.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 少年は、駅の構内を全力疾走していた。
The boys sprinted around the station.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 薔薇の茎を食べることはできますか？
Can you eat rose stems?

mnemonics.meaning: "To Remove" an eruption it needs to burst out of the earth or volcano it's in.
mnemonics.reading: Remember how you learned the word 吹き出す? Well this is read the exact same way and means almost the exact same thing. If you know one reading, you know both!

sentences: 今までためていた怒りが一気に噴き出した。
The anger that had built up burst out at once.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means swell, so the verb version is to swell or to expand.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  If someone comes up to you and says, "Hey it looks like you've really started to expand around the middle." Go ahead and say a big old, "F@#$ (ふく) you!" If someone is rude to you, dish it right back out. F@#$ that guy!

sentences: 希望は膨らむばかりだった。
My hopes just got bigger.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 貫く meaning "To Go Through" and 通す meaning "To Let Pass." So when you're trying to go through an area and also let someone pass with you, you start to follow them. Not intentionally, but you're both trying to go through at the same time so you decide to stick with them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a combination of two words you already know, so you should already know this too!

sentences: 彼は最後まで自分の信念を貫き通しました。
He stuck to his beliefs until the end.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shock. What happens when you're so old that your brain goes into shock? You start to grow senile. It's sad, but lots of people can't handle being old and they get like this.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  When you start to grow senile you'll make a new friend. It's Bobo (ぼ) the clown! No one else can see him though, but that's okay! He'll become your very best friend. And he won't leave until you finally kick the bucket.

sentences: あの芸人は呆けるのが本当にうまい。
That actor is really good at acting senile.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're stupid when it comes to sounds, then you're tone deaf.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 音痴なので、カラオケは苦手です。
I’m tone-deaf so I’m bad at karaoke.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means neglect and lazy, so the verb version is to neglect or to be idle.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You decide to neglect everything. Your school, your family, even your own name (なま). You've managed to slack for so long that you can't even remember your name? That's pretty impressive, actually.

sentences: 努力する人は希望を語るが、怠ける人は不満を語るのさ。
A person who works hard talks of hope but a person who is idle talks of dissatisfaction.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wholesale, so the verb version is to sell wholesale.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: うちにもその商品を卸してもらえませんか。
Will you sell these goods wholesale?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means deviate, so the verb version is to turn away or to avert.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You want to turn away from this movie because it's not worth watching. I mean, it isn't bad, but it isn't good. It's just so-so (そ). But that's not enough to keep your interest.

sentences: 彼女は颯と目を逸らした。
She quickly averted her eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading, and that is its most common reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In your mind, the only person who can wear a crown is Bill Murray. He asks you, "Can I wear the crown?" and you say "Yes you can, Murray (かんむり)". Murray goes ahead and puts on the crown. He's movie royalty, after all.

sentences: この冠を被れるのは王だけです。
Only the king can wear this crown.

mnemonics.meaning: The sky has an air of neglect about it and makes it seems like everything you're doing is in vain. Why even bother? The sky doesn't even believe in you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: こんな空疎な論争を続けるのは時間の無駄だ。
Continuing such a futile dispute is a waste of time.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 犠牲 means "victim," so when you add someone to that, it still means victim.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: その飛行機事故では、事故で多くの犠牲者がでました。
Many victims appeared from the airplane accident.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  A whale is actually gojira's (godzilla) cool cousin kujira (くじら). Godzilla mutated from a whale, so they're still related. That's where he gets his name from!

sentences: 鯨のベーコンを食べました。
I ate whale bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: Whale meat is whale meat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 美味しい鯨肉の店を知っているよ。
