I know a delicious whale meat shop.

mnemonics.meaning: If you catch a whale you're whaling, and that's illegal now so you should probably put the whale back.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は捕鯨には反対です。
I’m against whaling.

mnemonics.meaning: Sell something at the wholesale price and it's... well it's wholesale.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own. Sometimes it's spelled 卸売り too.

sentences: 卸売市場の見学をしてきました。
I went to observe the wholesale market.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: うちは雑貨の卸をしています。
We sell wholesale goods.

mnemonics.meaning: When you sell something at wholesale value it's being sold at a wholesale price.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: それは卸値で購入することができたんです。
I was able to buy it at wholesale price.

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means doubt.

You start growing thread in your rice paddy to accumulate more. You didn't want to have to buy any, so you're just trying to grow thread with your rice. That seems like a good way to accumulate more to you. Just imagine how much thread you'll accumulate if you can just grow it along with your rice in the rice paddy! So much thread!
mnemonics.reading: Sadly, this is a terrible way to accumulate anything thread related and you ended up ruining (るい) your rice paddy too. I guess if you want to accumulate thread this isn't the way to do it. Your attempts to accumulate more of something by cheating have brought ruin to everything else you were doing. Nice job, dummy.

mnemonics.meaning: When you meet the leader dog you have to bow to show your respect. Dogs are pretty great, so the leader of all dogs must be the greatest! You should bow really deeply to this one. Picture yourself bowing to the leader dog. Leader dog is so cool!
mnemonics.reading: You bow as low as you can, but you lose your balance and fall over. "F**k you (ふく)!" the leader dog barks. Oh no. You messed up and now the leader dog is super mad. Saying f**k you is a little harsh for falling over though, you think. Bow even deeper as the dog leader keeps barking what sounds like f**k you. You're pretty sure that's what he's saying at least... but maybe... maybe it's not.

mnemonics.meaning: When a man meets a tiger he makes the tiger his captive. Men are pretty crappy like that. They see tigers and they want to put them in cages, so the poor tiger becomes a captive of the man. Picture the sad tiger captive and the man laughing as he pokes at it. Tigers shouldn't be captives but when men find them they always seem to do this anyway.
mnemonics.reading: The captive tiger is even sadder because the man put him in a robe (りょ) and is making him act like a human. Tigers look good in robes, but they don't really enjoy being forced into people clothing. Picture the poor captive tiger being stuffed into a bathrobe and paraded around a cage for the man.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to loiter on a cliff with the pope you better be ready to move in perfect circulation with him. The pope is wearing really heavy robes and it's hot up here on this cliff, so you both need to walk in circles to keep cool. Imagine this strange circulation of you and the pope up here on a cliff. It's not even like you two are up here for a reason, you're just loitering. But he doesn't want to be hot so he makes you circulate with him.
mnemonics.reading: This circulation wouldn't have to even be happening if it wasn't June (じゅん). The cliffs are so hot in June, and in any other month the two of you would have just sat down and had a chat. But in June you have to do this weird circulation dance. "This circulation is all June's fault," you mutter, walking in a circle with the pope to stay cool.

mnemonics.meaning: If you find some rice in a top hat it's going to be really coarse and rough. Probably because it's not the kind that's meant to be eaten. Imagine trying to eat the rice you found in a top hat. It's so coarse it feels like it's scratching your teeth. There's probably some dirt in here too. This wasn't the best idea.
mnemonics.reading: You take the coarse rice and try to wash it with soap (そ). If you were trying to make this coarse rice taste like soap, you did it. But if you were trying to make it less coarse, well... sorry, but that's not how anything works.

mnemonics.meaning: If you try to turn something into ice while having doubts, it will just congeal instead. It will freeze, but it will get kinda yucky too. Your doubts will affect the ice-making process, so try not to be so worried and unsure next time you want normal ice. Imagine looking over water in an ice cube tray. You aren't sure if they'll turn out alright, and you doubt whether ice is even a thing. As you think this, the water congeals and freezes into gross shapes.
mnemonics.reading: You always end up congealing your gyoza (ぎょう) this way. You want to freeze your leftover gyoza so you can enjoy it later, but you doubt it will turn out all right and it always congeals in a gross, half-frozen gyoza block. Yuck! Picture frozen, congealed gyoza. Do you want to eat that? I didn't think so.

mnemonics.meaning: The king has a hat that's made from a tree but the more you look at it, the more it looks like it's just a big cork. It's a big, wooden plug that he's just placed on his head. It can hardly be called a hat. Picture how silly the king looks with this cork on his head. He kind of looks like a fat, plugged up bottle of wine when he yells now.
mnemonics.reading: It turned out this cork hat was given to him by a centaur (せん). You look into it and it turned out it IS a really big cork that centaurs use on their big wine casks. But the king didn't understand, and thought it was a hat. The centaurs are probably still laughing. Picture the centaurs drinking and giggling, putting the cork from their wine on their head to imitate the stupid king.

mnemonics.meaning: The king of the flowers in the center (of England, if you remember) has a special crystal. The king crystal. Picture the king holding this crystal aloft, giggling as the sun shines through it and sparkles.
mnemonics.reading: The king thinks everyone wants his crystal so he hides it in the giant acorn (えい) in the center of the flowers in England. There's a tiny hole in the bottom of the acorn, and that's where this crystal stays hidden. Imagine going to England, to the giant acorn in the center of the flowers, and searching for the king's crystal. If you find it, you can probably sell it for a fortune! Or just make a really sweet necklace.

mnemonics.meaning: The dawn radical and the dawn kanji are the same! Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: Dawn is dawn (だん)! It's also a great time to get a tan (たん). The sun is bright at dawn, but not so much that it will send skin cancer rays into you. Imagine getting a tan at dawn. Ahh. Relaxing and warm.

mnemonics.meaning: When spring is dry you need to dedicate your time and effort somewhere else. You can't plant flowers or vegetables, it's too dry. You can't play outside, your skin will flake. So you need to dedicate yourself to something inside. You know how you get. When you can't go outside, you dedicate yourself full force into something else. I mean, you made it to level 55, right? That's some serious dedication. And it probably started because of one particularly dry spring.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to dedicate yourself to your home (ほう). You don't want to be outside in the dry spring air, so you focus on home activities. You can clean the kitchen, build a shelf, or dedicate your time to your home internet system. Dedicate yourself to doing things in your home! Haha, who are we kidding, you already did that. We love you, nerd. ♡

mnemonics.meaning: You got off your scooter to load some charcoal onto it, when it suddenly took off to a distant place! That's some powerful charcoal. Your scooter is charcoal powered, but it looks like you put too much in there and it drove off somewhere distant without you. If you look really carefully, you can just see it, a distant speck on the horizon.
mnemonics.reading: You chase the scooter to that distant place, but then you see it heading for a lake. Oh good, it should be stopped by the water. But wait! In the distance you see your scooter drive onto a row (りょう) boat and... row itself through the water?! No!! You can still make out the distant shape of your scooter, now on a row boat, fading away and completely out of reach.

mnemonics.meaning: Put a sock in a building and it turns into an enclosure. Why? Because that sock is now enclosed in that building!
mnemonics.reading: Now that you have an enclosure, let's go deeper. Put a cock (かく) in the sock and it becomes an enclosure inside an enclosure. Picture this inception enclosure mess in your mind and you'll never forget this kanji, I promise.

mnemonics.meaning: Put your fingers in a jet if you want to erase them from existence. You aren't just chopping or burning them off. There's like, no trace of them at all. Your parents can't even remember if you were born with fingers or not. Jets are that powerful. Imagine your fingers slowly getting closer and closer to the jet's engine. It feels like it's going to suck your whole body in. And you better watch out, because if it does you'll be erased from the planet. And probably from time itself.
mnemonics.reading: You're almost done erasing your fingers when the jet starts sucking all of you in. You would try to grab the closest thing to you, but your fingers don't exist anymore, so you hold onto the mats (まつ) at your feet with your toes. The mats are super strong (they're made for jets, after all) and you manage to save yourself! Now you're so thankful to the mats. If they weren't there you might have erased your whole body! Thank you mats! I'll never walk on you without thanking you for your service again!

mnemonics.meaning: A leader gets double the dirt to build on if he's the most excellent and most skilled of all the leaders. You don't think dirt is so great? Well what if I took the dirt you own away from you? Your house is on that dirt. It's mine now. Get outta here. Imagine being so excellent at leading, that you get double the dirt that everyone else gets.
mnemonics.reading: This excellent leader is going to use all this dirt to store her excellent cars (か)! Excellent people have to have cars in equal or greater than excellent-ness than themselves. Imagine your own car. Is it as excellent as you?

mnemonics.meaning: Your soul long ago was very frugal, which is why you get to have too much in this life! Thank you soul, for being frugal so that I can have so much now.
mnemonics.reading: You know what being frugal is? Sexy (せき). You save money, you use less resources, that's the sexiest thing I can think of. If you want your spouse or S.O. to think you're more sexy, just be more frugal. They'll definitely appreciate it and see you in a different light.

mnemonics.meaning: A hundred foreheads lower themselves to their hearts in winter in grief. There were once many of their kind, the forehead peoples, but now there are only a hundred left after this harsh winter took the rest of them. Their grief is immense. Imagine if winter was so brutal that there were only one hundred human foreheads left. You lost all of your friends and family. Feel that grief.
mnemonics.reading: Their grief intensifies because all of the foreheads they lost belonged to youths (ゆう). Dead youths everywhere. Now there's no one left to repopulate the world. Grief for youths is so painful. No one should have to bury their forehead child.

mnemonics.meaning: The soul in your toe leaves early. You grieve and mourn for your now-dead toe. Look at your toe. It has no soul. It's dark and shriveled, like a mummy's toe. Grieve and watch your tears drip onto it.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to grieve in とうきょう. Your toe always wanted to walk in とうきょう, and now you can at least fulfill its dying wish. Walk through the streets of とうきょう grieving, with your dead toe flopping onto the pavement.

mnemonics.meaning: The sick Death Star needs its heart cured. If it doesn't get healing soon, it will die. Maybe the Death Star wouldn't be sick if it wasn't so mean to you, yelling at you for living in a yurt, when it was a yurt on the inside the whole time. Wait! I know the cure!
mnemonics.reading: You realized that the only way to cure the Death Star is to turn it back into a yurt (ゆ). Then it won't be able to do any more harm, and its outside will reflect its pleasant self on the inside! Hmm, but does this type of yurt healing technology exist?! You'll have to find out to cure it!!

mnemonics.meaning: You see a tree growing on a cliff and it has ten thousand horse chestnuts growing on it. These trees are rare, only grow on cliffs, and they always have exactly ten thousand horse chestnuts on each one.  Picture this tree, weighed down by it's own horse chestnuts, leaning over the edge of the cliff.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to take a bite of a horse chestnut because it looks yummy, and there are ten thousand, so it's not like anyone will notice. You crack it open and take a nice big bite to find out that it tastes like toe cheese (とち)! UHG! It's the worst thing you've ever tasted. Like hot, moldy toe cheese! Ewwww!  Horse chestnuts taste like nasty toe cheese. Imagine what having one in your mouth would be like.

mnemonics.meaning: The imperial radical and the imperial kanji are exactly the same! Wahoo! Make sure you remember this radical means imperial and you'll remember the kanji meaning too!
mnemonics.reading: Who is the coolest imperial you know? Ryu (りゅう) from Street Fighter. Wait what? You mean he FIGHTS imperials? Oh, okay. Looks like Ryu is the coolest imperial FIGHTER you know! Picture Ryu kicking the butts of imperial  scum like Bison and Darth Vader.

mnemonics.meaning: Go from a bow to a small gun and you're increasing in fire power! Even though the gun is small, it's still a step up from a bow. Imagine increasing your power with a new weapon. What would it be?
mnemonics.reading: You keep trading in weapons to get increasingly stronger gear, when you realize that at the top of the list is... a Yankee's (や) baseball bat? Huh. I would have gone for a tank or a bazooka. But I guess if this will increase your power level, you have to go for it. Imagine walking down a line of weapons, each one increasing in power from the one before it. Bow, small gun, bigger gun, tank, Yankee's bat. Yup, that sounds right.

mnemonics.meaning: Your bones have a scooter that moves through the bone marrow inside them. If you think about it, bone marrow is really just a road for tiny blood scooters.
mnemonics.reading: If you put your ear really close to a bone with marrow still in it, you'll hear the scooters going zuwee (ずい) as they move the blood around inside there. That's how doctors can tell if there's something wrong with your bone marrow. If they can't hear the zuuwee of the scooters, you're gonna die soon. I mean, maybe, I'm not a doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: A wing is something you must not do anything with. Wings are fragile (think bird's wings and butterfly's wings) and sometimes dangerous (like the wings of a plane) and you must not touch them, or even go near them! You MUST NOT. You. MUST. NOT. Imagine a pair of wings with a prohibition sign (a red circle with a red line) on them. And next time you see a wing of any kind, think "I MUST NOT"!
mnemonics.reading: Apart from staying away from wings, the other thing you must not do is eat mochi (もち). Okay, they're not fragile or dangerous, but I love mochi and I don't want you eating them. Now imagine some mochi with red prohibition circles on them. You MUST NOT eat those, do you hear me? Those mochi are mine!

mnemonics.meaning: The leader is standing funny, facing a direction nearby. He can't go far because there's obviously something wrong with his feet. He's stuck nearby, very close to your side. Picture the leader very close to your side. He's looking off into the distance, a distance he'll never get to because all he can do is stand there with his messed up feet.
mnemonics.reading: You decide to bring the leader to a nearby bowling (ぼう) alley. It's really close and you can stay right by his side as he throws bowling balls and gets his anger out. Picture the leader bowling nearby. You keep him close by, you never know when he'll fall over and need your help.

mnemonics.meaning: The soul of the Death Star is actually quite pleasant. And if you think about it, it's the people who control the Death Star that are evil and kill. Picture the Death Star in your mind. As you picture it, its pleasant, smiling soul floats up and out of it. "Oh hello, dear," it says happily, "Didn't see you there!"
mnemonics.reading: The pleasant soul within the Death Star actually looks like a yurt (ゆ), not a big angry, metal ball. Yurts are very pleasant structures. They're round and soft and moveable, just like the Death Star's soul.

mnemonics.meaning: You need to run on your toes if you want to proceed down this road. If you can't run on your toes, well then you're out of luck, and you won't be able to move on at all. I didn't make this rule, I just enforce it. Now run! Imagine trying to proceed down the road by running on your toes. No other part of your foot can touch the ground!
mnemonics.reading: If you find that you can't proceed, you're a fool (ふ). Everyone can run on their toes. Don't you know that? No? Then you're an even bigger fool, now get outta here! Imagine being called a fool when you can't proceed along the road because running on your toes ends up being super hard to do.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun is the reason why crops grow and people can get out of bed in the morning. But on planets with two suns, they can get even more done and it makes them way more prosperous than us. They work all day, then as the first sun sets, the second one rises and they get a new burst of energy. The whole planet lives in a state of prosperity because of the two suns. Picture the prosperous planet that has two suns. They get so much work done that no one is ever hungry or tired or without.
mnemonics.reading: The person on this planet with two suns who benefits from the prosperity the most is the Shougun (しょう). Yes, this planet still has a shougun as their leader, but everything is going so well that they didn't see a need to change. The shogun will be in charge of this prosperous world forever. No one ever thinks of revolt when everyone has everything they could ever need. Picture the Shougun looking over the prosperous world, the two suns at his back.

mnemonics.meaning: The only feeling a dead soul will have is remorse. Remorse for the people it left behind. Regrets for the things it did and didn't do. If you died right now and left your soul behind, do you think you'd have regrets?
mnemonics.reading: The soul with the most regrets is Genghis Khan (かん). Everyone knows to stay away from him in the spirit world because he's so sad. Not because of his own actions, but because of the state of his people now. Picture Genghis Khan looking down at the state of his people, the Mongols, in the modern world. See the remorse in his soul's face. They should be leaders of the modern world. Not reduced to a people struggling in the background.

mnemonics.meaning: You decide to carve a tree into a giant replica of your big toe because you think it will be really simple. Once you're done though, it looks like a really crude attempt at a fat, lumpy blob. Maybe carving isn't as simple as you thought. Imagine carving a really simple, crude toe from a tree. It's your first attempt, so I guess you should have known it wouldn't be great.
mnemonics.reading: You're admiring your simple looking toe tree when a lumberjack runs up and asks who created it. ぼく, you say. As in "I" said it, in a manly dude, way. He doesn't seem to believe you, so you say it a few more times. ぼく ぼく ぼく! Who carved this simple toe? ぼく!

mnemonics.meaning: If you put two two pound weights on a person on the moon they'll increase in stature when they come back down. Everything is lighter on the moon so the person won't even feel the weights. Then when they come back to earth they'll have grown a whole two inches taller! Imagine how much height you'd gain if you spent time lifting weights on the moon!
mnemonics.reading: Getting a taller stature will also make you seem super sexy (せき) on the moon and back home on earth. If you stay on the moon long enough, you'll be the tallest person in the galaxy and who wouldn't find that sexy?! Huh? Imagine how sexy the height of a ten foot tall person would be after just coming back from weight training on the moon.

mnemonics.meaning: You want to slice what you say in half so that people focus on the above text first. The above is what you want them to see! So slice what you say! Imagine actually slicing the words you say in the air. The above section is what you want people to pay attention to, so you slice a big gap between the above and the below words.
mnemonics.reading: As you focus on the above words you realize a guy (がい) is trying to push the rest of the things you're saying back up with the rest of them. No! The above text is all that matters! Go away guy! That guy doesn't care if the above is all he's supposed to hear. That guy sucks.

mnemonics.meaning: How do you make a mnemonic for the word this? You don’t. But, we can try. You climb many hills. On top of one of the hills is a little drop of water. You pick it up and say “THIS… THIS IS WHAT I WAS LOOKING FOR!” As you look at the drop of water, you note that you found the right thing. Written on it is the word “this."
mnemonics.reading: This particular drop of water holds the core (これ) of the universe. If you didn't find this very droplet, we all would have died and this universe would be gone. The core of the universe is in this drop of water. Or is it in this mnemonic? Ooohhhhh you'll never knoooowwww!

mnemonics.meaning: The reality of gold is that it has the power to tranquilize anyone who gets their hands on it. Gold may seem cool to have in movies and songs, but in reality, it has the power to mess you up! Imagine being tranquilized by the sweet caress of gold coins. You can't even move. You're in a daze or something.
mnemonics.reading: You've been tranquilized and now drool is running down your chin (ちん). It's actually really gross. But you don't care, look at all this gold! No one will care about your chin when you're rich! If you let gold tranquilize you, you'll drool all over your own chin. Maybe the chins of other people too, who knows?

mnemonics.meaning: When you go to the pool or lake to swim, you'll see a flag stuck somewhere in the water. That flag is there so you know it's okay to pee in that area of the pool. Everyone knows urine dilutes in water, and if everyone just pees in one place, it won't be gross. So go pee over by that flag when you have to go. Don't bother getting out of the water. Imagine swimming over to the flag that's sticking out of the water and peeing there. Yeah, everyone knows what you're doing over there, but it's better than getting out and walking to the bathroom right? Just pee in the water. Just do it.
mnemonics.reading: Right as you start to pee, you hear the life guard start to yell, "NYOOOOOO! (にょう)" and he's pointing at you! You were just peeing by the pee flag! Why is he mad? Imagine your embarrassment when you find out that you aren't supposed to urinate in the water, not even by the pee flag, because a life guard yelled NYOOOOOO and pointed right at you while you did it.

mnemonics.meaning: Between the roof and the ground there are few shellfish. This is because we invited some VIP guests into our home and they ate all our shellfish. The VIPs came into our home (the place between our roof and the ground) where they consumed all our shellfish. Only the best for guests, I guess.
mnemonics.reading: These VIP guests are part of a Hindu (ひん) envoy.  We are treating these VIP guests extra special because they represent the whole Hindu religion. They get shellfish because of course we weren't going to serve them beef!

mnemonics.meaning: You're holding a sword in front two buildings. What will you do? A. Stab the building on the left. B. Stab the building on the right. What do you choose? What? Do you think I'm gonna help you make this decision? No way, you need to dig deep and think about what you want to do.
mnemonics.reading: A. What is, stab the building on the left? You stab the building on the left with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)! B. What is, stab the building on the right? You stab the building on the right with your sword and what comes out is... a plate of delicious nachos (な)! What?! You got nachos either way. You should be happy, don't ask me any other questions.

mnemonics.meaning: Accumulate and accumulate make accumulation!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 日本政府が巨額の国債を累積していることについて、あなたはどのようにお考えですか。
How do you think the Japanese government accumulated such a great amount of national debt?

mnemonics.meaning: What do you wear to heal a really serious injury? An adhesion. Okay, so you don't actually wear these, but your body makes them for your insides to wear so you can heal. Nice job insides!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 手術後の癒着リスクについて、きちんと説明はなされましたか。
Were the risks of adhesion after surgery explained accurately to you?

mnemonics.meaning: Erase one part of your feelings and you'll only feel a little bit of them.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 一抹の不安が胸をよぎった。
For a moment I felt a little anxious.

mnemonics.meaning: A soldier only lays down when she's about to ambush the enemy! If you see some soldiers laying around, it's not that they're lazy, it's because they're getting ready to pounce!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 伏兵に襲われたんだ。
They were attacked by an ambush.

mnemonics.meaning: All you can do is consider your grief and how it's ruining your life. That's called anxiety, and it can be a real problem. You end up being concerned about everything, but don't worry. There are ways to combat it. You'll be okay!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ズバリ、社長が現在抱える憂慮とは何ですか。
What is the company president concerned about now?

mnemonics.meaning: Dedicate yourself to doing the best at school by having perfect attendance! That's how you can show you're really dedicated to learning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今年の夏休みは、老人ホームで奉仕活動をしました。
This summer vacation I volunteered at a senior citizen’s home.

mnemonics.meaning: Dedicate your life to what you believe in and you'll have really strong belief and faith in whatever that thing is. Just try to dedicate yourself to something nice.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私は日本国民全員が神道を信奉すべきだと思います。
I think all Japanese citizens should believe in Shinto.

mnemonics.meaning: Bone marrow is bone marrow!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 骨髄バンクに登録しました。
I registered at the bone marrow bank.

mnemonics.meaning: What do you use to extract a cork? A corkscrew! Or a bottle opener if you're feeling adventurous.
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the on'yomi reading for 栓 and the kun'yomi reading for 抜, which you learned with 抜く. If you can remember that, you'll be able to remember this too!

sentences: 栓抜きはそこの引き出しに入ってます。
The bottle opener is in that drawer.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The worst thing to see as a captive is a 鳥子 (とりこ), a bird child. Imagine seeing a baby bird held captive in a cage. So sad!

sentences: 彼女は、毎日ブログで男を虜にするテクニックについて書いています。
She writes on her blog everyday about techniques to captivate men.

mnemonics.meaning: Circulation in a loop is still circulation. Or rotation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 血液の循環には二種類の経路があります。
There are two types of paths for blood circulation.

mnemonics.meaning: If it's coarse in a bad way it's still coarse but it's also crude or inferior. You don't want a fuzzy sweater to be coarse, do you? Or a carpet? If they are, they're this kind of coarse.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 粗悪なガソリンは、車の寿命を早める。
Crude gasoline will shorten a car’s lifespan.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of coarse? Coarse or rough.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The most coarse thing you can think of is a rock (あら). You rubbed it on your face and it was really rough and kinda painful. You probably shouldn't be rubbing a rock on your face, actually.

sentences: 私はいつも、トウモロコシ、麦、豆などをひき割って粗い粉にしたものをスムージーに入れます。
I always use the coarse flour from corn, wheat, or beans in my smoothies.

mnemonics.meaning: Bow your head to conceal yourself better than you were concealing yourself before. If you want to go into hiding you need to know how to lay low!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 我々はマフィアの潜伏捜査をすることになった。
We conducted an undercover investigation of the mafia.

mnemonics.meaning: Grieve for a pathetic situation by offering your condolences. Showing regret is the best way to handle it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 哀悼の意を表して、黙祷しました。
I expressed my condolences and prayed silently.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 栓抜きが無くても瓶ビールの栓を抜く裏ワザを知っています。
If you don’t have a bottle opener, I know a trick to open a beer bottle.

mnemonics.meaning: If the above is correct then please sign the corresponding line to agree with it. And make sure you correspond in a timely manner.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この商品も、キャンペーンの対象に該当しますか？
Does this merchandise correspond with the target of the campaign?

mnemonics.meaning: Measure how much you've accumulated and you'll have a cumulative total. That total includes all the things you've bought since the beginning of time. Probably.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: このサイトでは、人気アプリの累計ダウンロードランキングを毎日更新しています。
I update the total download rankings for popular apps everyday on this site.

mnemonics.meaning: If you dedicate your entire supply of food to the gods it's called an offering, and it takes real dedication to do something like that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: どうして首相が靖国神社に玉串料を奉納することが批判されるのですか。
Why did the Prime Minister receive criticism for making an offering at Yasukuni Shrine?

mnemonics.meaning: With lots of grief and gloom in your life you'll probably end up in a spiral of depression. Don't worry, you'll be okay. Things get better with time so don't give into the gloom.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 会社へ出勤するのが憂鬱です。
Working at a company is depressing.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that the word 洗浄 means "washing." So when you're washing the laundry you have to use just the right dose of detergent to make sure they wash properly. If you use too little detergent they'll still smell, but if you use too much detergent the washer will explode with bubbles! Just be careful okay, don't end up like me.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 洗浄剤なら、洗い場の下の棚にあります。
There’s detergent under the shelf in the washing area.

mnemonics.meaning: A crystal ladle is the Japanese given name Eito. If you know the singer-songwriter Eito, imagine him holding a crystal ladle. If not, any Eito will do! Other public figures with the name include pro baseball player Tanaka Eito (田中 瑛斗) and Takarazuka actor Namiki Eito (波輝 瑛斗).
mnemonics.reading: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji, and you learned both these readings with the kanji. Get yourself a crystal ladle to celebrate! Note: This name can also sometimes be read あきと, as is the case for pro baseball player Takabe Akito (髙部 瑛斗).

sentences: 頑張れよ、瑛斗。
Do your best, Eito.
あそこに田中瑛斗選手がいるよ！
The pro athlete Eito Tanaka is over there!
シンガーソングライターの瑛斗は、ソーシャルメディアで有名になりました。
Singer-songwriter Eito rose to fame on social media.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to erase and extinguish every lamp and every picture of a lamp in the world, just erase them all. Simple as that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は怪我で一軍登録を抹消されたんだ。
His army registration was deleted due to the injury.

mnemonics.meaning: The marrow of a god contains their essence and spirit. I don't know how you found that out, it was probably really dangerous. You shouldn't mess with gods.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: プロの神髄を見せつけられました。
He was able to show me the true meaning of being a professional.

mnemonics.meaning: The marrow of reality is the true essence of life. If you look deep down into reality you might even find the true meaning of life! Hmm I wonder what that is... it probably has something to do with a certain two digit number. Oh well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 京料理の真髄はハモ料理だと思います。
I think the essence of Kyoto cooking is in eel dishes.

mnemonics.meaning: Make something excellent and everyone will call it a fine work. Or make something that sucks and let everyone down. It's your call.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私の描いた絵が佳作で入選しました。
The picture I drew was chosen as a good piece of work.

mnemonics.meaning: Connect a bunch of things laying in a line. Something's happening here. You can't put your finger on it, but you're pretty sure this is foreshadowing for something else.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 伏線の張り方がすごい。
This method of foreshadowing is amazing.

mnemonics.meaning: A VIP comes to your door. They're your guest! I hope you aren't going to make them sleep in the couch.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 来賓の方々をはじめ、皆様にはお忙しい中、ご臨席を賜り誠にありがとうございます。
We’d like to thank everyone, including the guests, for honoring us with your presence while you’re all busy.

mnemonics.meaning: A VIP guest is a guest of honor. They're even more important than a normal guest.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 海外の賓客を一流の和食でもてなしました。
We welcomed the foreign guest of honor with first class Japanese cuisine.

mnemonics.meaning: A healing cure will be great for healing sick people.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 虫歯が自然治癒することはありません。
Cavities don’t just spontaneously heal.

mnemonics.meaning: If you tranquilize yourself heavy enough you'll be just like all the other world leaders today. They're all pretty sedated. Tranquilize yourself too and you'll be just like them!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼の会社は、業界の重鎮達を次々と役員に迎え入れた。
That company ushered in leaders of industry one after another to their staff.

mnemonics.meaning: Nearby there is a beautiful view. Look on as the sun sets and the sky changes color. You would give up anything to be able to spectate this kind of thing all the time.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 私はイジメをただ傍観していました。
I only looked on at the bullying.

mnemonics.meaning: Your team was about to win the game but you decided to be frugal with your shots near the end and it resulted in failure, making it a loss of a close game. If you had just taken those shots your team probably would have won. What a regrettable defeat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: わが校は、惜敗でベスト8入りを逃しました。
Our school missed getting into the top eight by losing a close game.

mnemonics.meaning: At dawn what's the first thing you're supposed to see? Your master. He wants you to wake him up and bring his slippers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 旦那は出張で今週ずっと留守にしています。
The master will be away all week.

mnemonics.meaning: Erase your need for normal tea by drinking matcha. It is far superior to all others and you'll never turn back once you've had a taste.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎朝抹茶ラテを飲んでいます。
I drink a matcha latte every morning.

mnemonics.meaning: Only accept new people moving in nearby once you've finished properly monitoring them! Tapping into their phones will probably help too, but don't tell anyone I told you to do that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察は、犯罪捜査のために、通信の傍受を行うことがあります。
The police may perform correspondence monitoring for the sake of the criminal investigation.

mnemonics.meaning: Follow people who grieve by mourning with them. You don't want to be the only one who doesn't seem sad.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You learned this reading with the word 追随, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case: You're mourning the loss of your pet bird. You can't help but yell TWEET (つい) to the sky, hoping she'll come back to life. It doesn't work so you stay in a state of mourning for the rest of your life. She was your best bird friend, after all.

sentences: みんなで奴の追悼コンサートを開かないか？
Why don’t we open his memorial concert with everyone?

mnemonics.meaning: Proceed to a new place to do your duty. That's just a fancy way to say you're about to move for a different job. This is usually a job at the same company you're already at, it's just a different position for you.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 今度、中国に赴任することになりました。
I’ve decided to relocate to China now.

mnemonics.meaning: Something nearby is near to you. It's very close.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  There is a restaurant near your house that only sells dishes with soba (そば) noodles in them. They're delicious, but it's so close to your home that you can smell them all the time. Sometimes it feels like that's all you'll ever smell anymore.

sentences: いつまでも君の傍にいるよ。
I'll always be by your side.
傍から見ていても全然わからなかった。
I couldn't understand it even when I was watching from close by.
旦那なら、今京王百貨店の傍の居酒屋に飲みに行っているよ。
If it's my husband you're looking for, he's out drinking at an izakaya near the Keio Department Store right now.

mnemonics.meaning: The origin of dawn can be found on New Year's Day. That's when the new sun is born and rises above the earth for a whole year until it dies. And that's the origin of dawn, children. Don't let your teachers tell you otherwise.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 元 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who's always there on the dawn of New Year's Day welcoming the new sun? Gandhi (がん). He sits on the edge of the earth and makes sure the sun feels welcome. What a nice guy.

sentences: 元旦には家族で初詣に行きます。
I’m going to visit a shrine with my family on New Year’s Day.

mnemonics.meaning: A valuable VIP is a noble visitor. They're probably a queen or a diplomat or something. So you better treat them really well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 社長が外国の貴賓を接待する際に、通訳として同行しました。
When the company president went to welcome a distinguished foreign visitor, I attended as an interpreter.

mnemonics.meaning: To erase or kill something results in total obliteration. This word refers to the erasure, denial, ignoring, or killing of something's very existence. It can even mean murder in some cases.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この日大臣がしていたことは、陳情の抹殺ばかりだった。
All the minister did that day was kill off the petition.
村民の抹殺が我々の目標だ。
Obliteration of the villagers is our objective.
あの男は、組織に歯向かったため、社会から抹殺されたんだよ。
That man rose against the system and was erased from society.

mnemonics.meaning: You must not consider this a theory, because of course it's a fact. Needless to say, this is the way things are. This word is often written in kana, but it's worth knowing the kanji version too.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. Needless to say, you should be able to read this on your own!

sentences: その商品なら、うちの店にも勿論ありますよ。
Of course we have that product in our store.
日本語も勿論ですが、フランス語も喋れるようになりたいです。
Of course I want to be able to speak Japanese, but I also want to be able to speak French.
勿論、子育ての合間に勉強が出来る人もいるだろうけど、私には難しいです。
Needless to say, there are people who can study in between looking after children, but it's difficult for me.

mnemonics.meaning: An elderly shop is an old shop.
mnemonics.reading: This reading is an exception, but there is another way you can say it that uses the jukugo (on'yomi) readings instead! But to help you remember the more common, exception, here's a mnemonic: If you go to an old shop you can get what's called a shiny sale (しにせ). A shiny sale is if you can find something in the shop that's still new and shiny it's on sale! It's hard when you're at an old shop though. And that's the challenge!

sentences: 彼らは、まさに老舗の意地を見せたんだ。
They naturally showed the old shop’s spirit.

mnemonics.meaning: You only have time to do one thing at dawn once. Dawn is really short so you can do whatever it is for a moment, but that's it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この話は一旦なかったことにしてもらえませんか。
Will you forget that conversation for a moment?

mnemonics.meaning: Trace the enclosure of a wheel on paper and you'll have drawn its outline.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 涙で輪郭が霞んで見えました。
The outline grew hazy from my tears.

mnemonics.meaning: If you ask me to tell the truth I'll say your face is shaped like a melon. No no, it's not a bad thing! You just have a really oval face!
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 瓜 and 顔, but in the middle there, 実 has a bit of an exceptional reading. You certainly haven't learned this weirdness before, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You know who has an oval face? Zayn (ざね) formerly from One Direction. When you think of handsome oval faces, picture Zayn's.

sentences: 瓜実顔で雰囲気のある女優を探しています。
I’m looking for a woman who has an atmosphere with classic features.

mnemonics.meaning: Tranquilize your pain with a strong dose of painkillers! Yum yum. Don't take too many though!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 医者に鎮痛剤を注射してもらいました。
I received a shot of the painkiller from the doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: Whenever something bad happens to your country to feel an exceptional amount of grief for your fellow country people. This is some serious patriotic concern you've got going on. Let's hope you use those concerns for something good and don't get too carried away.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 憂国の若きサムライたちよ、今こそ立ち上がれ！
Young warriors of patriotism, now is the time to stand up!

mnemonics.meaning: A pleasant pleasant person is super pleasant! They're happy and nice to everybody all the time!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 昔、「僕は殺しが愉快でたまらない」と言った少年殺人犯がいました。
A long time ago, a young murderer said, "I can’t help but find murder pleasant."

mnemonics.meaning: Catch a captive and he'll be a prisoner of war. Or, if you're not in a war, just an ordinary captive.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 大変だ。捕虜が脱走したぞ！
We're in trouble. A POW has escaped!
太平洋戦争では、 約13万人もの米兵が日本の捕虜となった。
In the Pacific War, about 130,000 American soldiers were taken as prisoners of war in Japan.
我が国の兵と引き換えに、敵国の捕虜１０人を解放した。
In exchange for our soldiers, we released 10 enemy prisoners of war.

mnemonics.meaning: Overgrown prosperity is still prosperity. Why, it's even thriving. Nice!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 商売が繁昌するように、神社でお祈りをしてきました。
I went to pray at a Shinto shrine in order for the company to prosper.

mnemonics.meaning: Melons from the south are lumpy and orange, sometimes orange and green because they try to look like the hot sun. Wait, those aren't melons, they're pumpkins and squash. Or... kind of a mix of the two, if you already know what kabocha tastes like.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this is an exception, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it: Japanese pumpkins don't taste like American pumpkins. They taste more like canned boiled chocolate (かぼちゃ). Oh, you don't know that either? Well then just taste the pumpkin and you'll know what that tastes like too.

sentences: 南瓜の煮物を炊きました。
I’m cooking boiled kabocha.

mnemonics.meaning: If you leave behind something and it makes you feel remorse it's a really regrettable situation. You should probably go back for whatever it was so you won't lead an unsatisfactory life.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 裁判は誠に遺憾な結果に終わりました。
The trial ended with an absolutely unsatisfactory result.

mnemonics.meaning: To tranquilize souls you have to a have a mass repose of souls. Then their souls will move on to the next life and stop hanging around here, haunting umbrellas.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 星祭りは、平和を祈り、戦死者を鎮魂する儀式です。
Tanabata is a ritual to pray for peace and give repose to people killed in the war.

mnemonics.meaning: Your home is out in the middle of a coarse looking field. Whenever you bring friends over the only word they say to describe your dirt and grass home is that it's rustic. That's pretty rude of them, you love your dirt home! Even if it is kinda small and stinky and in a field.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼女は、決して他人に対して粗野に振る舞うことがなかった。
She’s never treated another person rudely.

mnemonics.meaning: Distant fat makes up the Japanese given name Ryota. Imagine soccer player Noguchi Ryota (野口 遼太) kicking a fat soccer ball into the distance while voice actor Asari Ryota (浅利 遼太) commentates.
mnemonics.reading: This name uses the on'yomi for both kanji. You haven't learned this particular on'yomi for 太 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Ryota's diet consists only of tacos (た). Tacos, tacos, tacos for breakfast, lunch and dinner. Yum!

sentences: 今朝、夢に遼太君が現れた。
This morning, Ryota-kun appeared in my dream.
遼太と綾乃ちゃん、付き合ってるらしいよ。
I heard that Ryota and Ayano are dating.
遼太、早く起きないと遅刻するよ！
Ryota, wake up quickly or you'll be late!

mnemonics.meaning: Dedicate yourself to the public by doing community service!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: お礼奉公とは看護婦が、看護学生時代に借りた奨学金の返済制度の一つです。
Oreiboukou, which means "free service after finishing an apprenticeship," is a system for nurses to pay back the student loans they took out while they were at school.

mnemonics.meaning: People made from simple elements are also pretty simple. And they can be naive too. But that's just how they're built.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: みなさんの素朴な疑問にお答えします。
I'll respond to everyone’s simple questions.

mnemonics.meaning: Your pudding congealed and is all hard. How on earth did it solidify like this? It shouldn't freeze unless you put it in the freezer. Unless, did you? Oh...
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 煮詰めたジャムは、冷めてくると粘性が強まり、ゼリー状に凝固します。
When the jam I boiled cools it will become viscous and solidify into jelly.

mnemonics.meaning: Marrow that gives you stature is inside of your spinal cord.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 事故で脊髄に傷がついてしまったのです。
My spinal cord was damaged in the accident.

mnemonics.meaning: Freeze and look at me. Your stare is giving me the creeps! You can move now. Hey. You can move now. Stop I said!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: タイプの女性がいたので、思わず凝視してしまいました。
She was my type of woman so I stared unintentionally.

mnemonics.meaning: A VIP from another country is a state guest.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: アメリカ大統領が国賓として来日しました。
The American President visited Japan as a state guest.

mnemonics.meaning: Accumulate enough of a good reputation at your company in advance and you'll be able to have successive promotions. You'll be boss in no time!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 彼は若くして部長に累進した。
He was promoted to section head at a very young age.

mnemonics.meaning: Tranquilize pressure with medication that helps with its suppression. Then you won't have to feel it anymore.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察が三日がかりでデモ隊を鎮圧しました。
The police suppressed the demonstrators by the third day.

mnemonics.meaning: Bow as you descend into enemy territory. This is how you have to surrender if you want to live. Keep your head nice and low and descend into their ranks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 絶対にあいつらを降伏させてみせる。
I let them surrender unconditionally.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: よかったら之も持って行きなさい。
Take this too, if you want.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tranquilize, so the verb version is what happens when you've already been able to tranquilize someone. It's to appease or to suppress.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You want to appease her because she's (しず) SUPER mad. She's pissed and she's angry and she's going to beat you up if you don't find out how to calm her down!

sentences: 神の怒りを鎮めるには、生贄を捧げる必要があります。
In order to appease the god’s anger we need to offer a sacrifice.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means congeal or freeze, so the verb version is to grow stiff. But it's also used to mean what happens when your emotions or interests freeze on one thing. You start to be absorbed in whatever that thing is. Try to remember both meanings.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  What have all your friends started to be absorbed in? Their 子s (こ). They all keep having kids and now that's all they seem to care about. Damn kids.

sentences: 妻の料理の盛り付けは、いつも凝っています。
I’m always absorbed in the arrangement of my wife’s food.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means grieve, so the verb version is to grieve or to be anxious.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Your aunt starts to grieve really loudly at your Uncle Ray's funeral. "Ooh, Ray (うれ)! OOoh, Ray why did you have to leave me!" It's really sad. You even hear it in your head after you've left and gone home. You've never seen someone start to be distressed like that in public.

sentences: 親が子供の将来を憂えるのは当然のことだ。
It’s natural for parents to be anxious about their children’s’ futures.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frugal, so the verb version is to be frugal or to be sparing.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  You should try to be frugal when you go to the ocean (おし). There are lots of things to buy, like delicious food, sun hats, and tofugu dolls, but you really shouldn't spend all your money there. Try to plan on spending less when you head to the ocean next time, okay?

sentences: お前がちょっとした手間を惜しんだために、全ての計画がおじゃんになったんだぞ！
You wouldn’t spare even a little time so all your plans fell through!

mnemonics.meaning: The prefecture with lots of horse chestnut trees is Tochigi prefecture.
mnemonics.reading: This word consists of the kun'yomi readings for 栃 and 木 and the on'yomi for 県, like most with prefectures. As long as you remember that き is changed to ぎ here, you should be able to remember this reading easily!

sentences: 栃木県の出身なんですか？
Are you from Tochigi Prefecture?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means bow or lay, so the verb version is what when you try to cover or to hide something. You're doing the action to something, you're not the one hiding.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Who's that you're trying to cover up? It's your fool (ふ) brother. He keeps doing embarrassing things and trying to get you in trouble. So you're trying to hide him with your jacket. Well we see him, we know he's a fool, so you can stop now.

sentences: どうして弟が犯罪者であることを伏せていたんだ。
Why would I cover up my younger brother being a criminal?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a combination of the words 据える, meaning "to install," and 付ける, meaning "to attach." Put them together and you're still going to install something or to equip something. There's just more hands on work happening.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them when you learned the kanji, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここに戸棚を据え付けるつもりだよ。
I’m planning to install cupboards here.

mnemonics.meaning: Wake up, now lay down, now wake up again, okay now lay again. What you're doing is called undulation. If your emotions do it it's called ups and downs. Everyone goes through stuff like this sometimes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 生理前はどうしても感情の起伏が激しくなってしまう。
Before my period I always get violent emotional ups and downs.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 病院で尿検査をして、妊娠していると言われました。
I took a urinalysis test at the hospital and it said I was pregnant.

mnemonics.meaning: If you dig up hollyhocks in the mountains, and grind up their roots, you'll have wasabi! Don't eat too much, or you'll burn your tongue off.
mnemonics.reading: This reading is an exception, but I'm sure (at least I hope) that you've heard the word wasabi before. It's the same in Japanese so just remember the meaning and you'll know the reading too!

sentences: やはり、すりたての山葵は美味しいね。
Of course, freshly shaven wasabi is delicious.

mnemonics.meaning: You already learned that 披露 means "announcement" or "display," so add a banquet to that and you're at a wedding reception! Or if no one's getting married but they're showing off something at a big place with food and stuff it's a just a normal reception.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 友人の披露宴に出席する際のマナーを教えてください。
Please teach me manners for when I attend my friend’s wedding reception.

mnemonics.meaning: Life in Japan was increasing at its fastest rate during the Yayoi Period. It's one of the earliest periods of history in Japan that we know about! You should look it up, if you don't already know about it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for this word is an exception but it's the same in Japanese as it is in English. So if you just remember it's Yayoi (やよい) in English, you'll remember the Japanese too!

sentences: 弥生時代のはじまりは紀元前300年頃です。
The beginning of the Yayoi Period was approximately 300 BCE.
